paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FLAVIUS, MURELLUS, a CARPENTER, a COBBLER, and certain other COMMONERS over the stage$NEWLINE$FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$MURELLUS$NEWLINE$CARPENTER$NEWLINE$COBBLER$NEWLINE$COMMONERS
paragraphs.translated: FLAVIUS and MURELLUS enter and speak to a CARPENTER, a COBBLER, and some other commoners.$NEWLINE$FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$MURELLUS$NEWLINE$CARPENTER$NEWLINE$COBBLER

paragraphs.original: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$Hence! Home, you idle creatures get you home!$NEWLINE$Is this a holiday? What, know you not,$NEWLINE$Being mechanical, you ought not walk$NEWLINE$Upon a laboring day without the sign$NEWLINE$Of your profession?—Speak, what trade art thou?
paragraphs.translated: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$Get out of here! Go home, you lazy men. What, is today a holiday? Don’t you know that working men aren’t supposed to walk around on a workday without wearing their work clothes? You there, speak up. What’s your occupation?

paragraphs.original: CARPENTER$NEWLINE$Why, sir, a carpenter.
paragraphs.translated: CARPENTER$NEWLINE$I’m a carpenter, sir.

paragraphs.original: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?$NEWLINE$What dost thou with thy best apparel on?$NEWLINE$—You, sir, what trade are you?
paragraphs.translated: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$Where are your leather apron and your ruler? What are you doing, wearing your best clothes? And you, sir, what’s your trade?$NEWLINE$your

paragraphs.original: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler.
paragraphs.translated: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Well, compared to a fine workman, you might call me a mere cobbler.

paragraphs.original: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$But what trade art thou? Answer me directly.
paragraphs.translated: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$But what’s your trade? Answer me straightforwardly.

paragraphs.original: COBBLER$NEWLINE$A trade, sir, that I hope I may use with a safe conscience, which is, indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.
paragraphs.translated: COBBLER$NEWLINE$It is a trade, sir, that I practice with a clear conscience. I am a mender of worn soles.

paragraphs.original: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$What trade, thou knave? Thou naughty knave, what trade?
paragraphs.translated: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$What trade, boy? You insolent rascal, what trade?

paragraphs.original: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me. Yet, if you be out, sir, I can mend you.
paragraphs.translated: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Sir, please, don’t be angry. But if your soles are worn out, I can mend you.

paragraphs.original: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$What mean’st thou by that? “Mend” me, thou saucy fellow?
paragraphs.translated: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$What do you mean by that? “Mend” me, you impertinent fellow?!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Why, sir, cobble you.
paragraphs.translated: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Cobble you, sir.

paragraphs.original: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$Thou art a cobbler, art thou?
paragraphs.translated: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$You’re a cobbler, are you?

paragraphs.original: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl. I meddle with no tradesman’s matters nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes. When they are in great danger, I recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon neat’s leather have gone upon my handiwork.
paragraphs.translated: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Sir, I make my living using an awl. I stick to my work; I don’t meddle in politics or chase women. I’m a surgeon to old shoes. When they’re endangered, I save them. The noblest men who ever walked on leather have walked on my handiwork.

paragraphs.original: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$But wherefore art not in thy shop today?$NEWLINE$Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?
paragraphs.translated: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$But why aren’t you in your shop today? Why are you leading these men through the streets?

paragraphs.original: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes to get myself into more work. But indeed, sir, we make holiday to see Caesar and to rejoice in his triumph.
paragraphs.translated: COBBLER$NEWLINE$Well, to wear out their shoes and get myself more work. Seriously, though, we took the day off to see Caesar, sir, and celebrate his triumph.

paragraphs.original: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?$NEWLINE$What tributaries follow him to Rome$NEWLINE$To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels?$NEWLINE$You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things,$NEWLINE$O you hard hearts, you cruèl men of Rome,$NEWLINE$Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft$NEWLINE$Have you climbed up to walls and battlements,$NEWLINE$To towers and windows, yea, to chimney tops,$NEWLINE$Your infants in your arms, and there have sat$NEWLINE$The livelong day with patient expectation$NEWLINE$To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome.$NEWLINE$And when you saw his chariot but appear,$NEWLINE$Have you not made an universal shout$NEWLINE$That Tiber trembled underneath her banks$NEWLINE$To hear the replication of your sounds$NEWLINE$Made in her concave shores?$NEWLINE$And do you now put on your best attire?$NEWLINE$And do you now cull out a holiday?
paragraphs.translated:
MURELLUS$NEWLINE$Why would you celebrate it? What victory does he bring home? What foreign lands has he conquered and captive foreigners chained to his chariot wheels? You blockheads, you unfeeling men! You hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome, didn’t you know
Pompey? Many times you climbed up on walls and battlements, towers and windows—even chimney tops—with your babies in your arms, and sat there patiently all day waiting to see great Pompey ride through the streets of Rome. And when you caught a glimpse of his chariot, didn’t you shout so loud that the river Tiber shook as it echoed? And now you put on your best clothes? And now you take a holiday?$NEWLINE$Pompey$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And do you now strew flowers in his way$NEWLINE$That comes in triumph over Pompey’s blood?$NEWLINE$Be gone!$NEWLINE$Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,$NEWLINE$Pray to the gods to intermit the plague$NEWLINE$That needs must light on this ingratitude.
paragraphs.translated: And now you toss flowers in the path of Caesar, who comes in triumph over Pompey’s defeated sons? Go home! Run to your houses, fall on your knees, and pray to the gods to spare you the pain that you deserve for such ingratitude.

paragraphs.original: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$Go, go, good countrymen, and for this fault,$NEWLINE$Assemble all the poor men of your sort,$NEWLINE$Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears$NEWLINE$Into the channel till the lowest stream$NEWLINE$Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
paragraphs.translated: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$Go, go, good countrymen, and to make up for having done wrong, gather up all the poor men like yourselves, lead them to the Tiber, and weep into the river until it overflows its banks.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CARPENTER, COBBLER, and all the other commoners$NEWLINE$CARPENTER$NEWLINE$COBBLER
paragraphs.translated: The CARPENTER, COBBLER, and all the commoners exit.$NEWLINE$CARPENTER$NEWLINE$COBBLER

paragraphs.original: See whether their basest metal be not moved.$NEWLINE$They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness.$NEWLINE$Go you down that way towards the Capitol.$NEWLINE$This way will I. Disrobe the images$NEWLINE$If you do find them decked with ceremonies.
paragraphs.translated: Well, that ought to move even the most thickheaded of them. There they go, feeling so guilty they’re now tongue-tied—they don’t have a thing to say. You go down toward the Capitol, and I’ll go this way. Undress the statues if they’re decorated in honor of Caesar.

paragraphs.original: MURELLUS$NEWLINE$May we do so?$NEWLINE$You know it is the feast of Lupercal.
paragraphs.translated:
MURELLUS$NEWLINE$Can we do that? You know it’s the feast of
Lupercal.$NEWLINE$Lupercal$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$It is no matter. Let no images$NEWLINE$Be hung with Caesar’s trophies. I’ll about$NEWLINE$And drive away the vulgar from the streets.$NEWLINE$So do you too, where you perceive them thick.$NEWLINE$These growing feathers plucked from Caesar’s wing$NEWLINE$Will make him fly an ordinary pitch,$NEWLINE$Who else would soar above the view of men$NEWLINE$And keep us all in servile fearfulness.
paragraphs.translated: FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$It doesn’t matter. Make sure that none of the statues are decorated in tribute to Caesar. I’ll walk around and force the commoners off the streets. You do the same, wherever the crowds are thick. If we take away Caesar’s support, he’ll have to come back down to earth; otherwise, he’ll fly too high and keep the rest of us in a state of fear and obedience.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in different directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish Enter CAESAR, ANTONY, dressed for the course, CALPHURNIA, PORTIA, DECIUS, CICERO, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, CASCA, and a SOOTHSAYER in a throng of plebians. After them, MURELLUS and FLAVIUS$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$DECIUS$NEWLINE$CICERO$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated:
A trumpet sounds. CAESAR enters, followed by ANTONY, dressed formally for a foot race, then CALPHURNIA, PORTIA, DECIUS, CICERO, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and CASCA. A great crowd follows, among them a
SOOTHSAYER .$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$DECIUS$NEWLINE$CICERO$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Calphurnia!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Calphurnia!

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Peace, ho! Caesar speaks.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Quiet! Caesar’s talking.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Calphurnia!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Calphurnia!

paragraphs.original: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$Here, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$I’m here, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Stand you directly in Antonius' way$NEWLINE$When he doth run his course.—Antonius!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Stand right in Antonius’s path when he runs the race. Antonius!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Caesar, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Yes, Caesar?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Forget not in your speed, Antonius,$NEWLINE$To touch Calphurnia, for our elders say$NEWLINE$The barren, touchèd in this holy chase,$NEWLINE$Shake off their sterile curse.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Antonius, after you take off, don’t forget to touch Calphurnia, because our wise elders say that if you touch an infertile woman during this holy race, she’ll be freed from the curse of sterility.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I shall remember.$NEWLINE$When Caesar says, “do this,” it is performed.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ll remember. When Caesar says “do this,” it is done.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Set on, and leave no ceremony out.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Continue, then, and don’t forget to perform all of the rituals.

paragraphs.original: Music
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet plays.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Caesar!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Ha! Who calls?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Who’s calling me?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Bid every noise be still. Peace yet again.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Quiet, everyone! Quiet!

paragraphs.original: Music ceases
paragraphs.translated: The trumpet stops playing.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Who is it in the press that calls on me?$NEWLINE$I hear a tongue, shriller than all the music,$NEWLINE$Cry “Caesar!”—Speak. Caesar is turned to hear.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Who in the crowd is calling me? I hear a voice more piercing than the music of these trumpets calling “Caesar!” Speak. Caesar is listening.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Beware the ides of March.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Beware of March 15th.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What man is that?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Who’s that?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$A soothsayer tells you to beware of March 15th.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Set him before me. Let me see his face.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Bring him in front of me. Let me see his face.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Fellow, come from the throng. Look upon Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You, fellow, step out of the crowd. This is Caesar you’re looking at.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER approaches$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: The SOOTHSAYER approaches.$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What sayst thou to me now? Speak once again.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What do you have to say to me now? Speak once again.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Beware the ides of March.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Beware of March 15th.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$He is a dreamer. Let us leave him. Pass!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$He’s insane. Let’s leave him. Let’s move.

paragraphs.original: Sennet. Exeunt. Manent BRUTUS and CASSIUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. Everyone exits except BRUTUS and CASSIUS.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Will you go see the order of the course?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Are you going to watch the race?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Not I.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Not me.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I pray you, do.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Please, come.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I am not gamesome. I do lack some part$NEWLINE$Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.$NEWLINE$Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires.$NEWLINE$I’ll leave you.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I don’t like sports. I’m not competitive like Antony. But don’t let me keep you from going, Cassius. I’ll go my own way.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, I do observe you now of late$NEWLINE$I have not from your eyes that gentleness$NEWLINE$And show of love as I was wont to have.$NEWLINE$You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand$NEWLINE$Over your friend that loves you.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, I’ve been watching you lately. You seem less good-natured and affectionate toward me than usual. You’ve been stubborn and unfamiliar with me, your friend who loves you.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Cassius,$NEWLINE$Be not deceived. If I have veiled my look,$NEWLINE$I turn the trouble of my countenance$NEWLINE$Merely upon myself. Vexèd I am$NEWLINE$Of late with passions of some difference,$NEWLINE$Conceptions only proper to myself,$NEWLINE$Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors.$NEWLINE$But let not therefore, my good friends, be grieved—$NEWLINE$Among which number, Cassius, be you one—$NEWLINE$Nor construe any further my neglect$NEWLINE$Than that poor Brutus, with himself at war,$NEWLINE$Forgets the shows of love to other men.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Cassius, don’t take it badly. If I seem guarded, it’s only because I’m uneasy with myself. Lately I’ve been overwhelmed with private thoughts and inner conflicts, which have affected my behavior. But this shouldn’t trouble my good friends—and I consider you a good friend, Cassius. Don’t think anything more about my distraction than that poor Brutus, who is at war with himself, forgets to show affection to others.$NEWLINE$myself

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion,$NEWLINE$By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried$NEWLINE$Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations.$NEWLINE$Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, I misunderstood your feelings, and therefore kept to myself certain thoughts I might have shared. Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, Cassius, for the eye sees not itself$NEWLINE$But by reflection, by some other things.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, Cassius. The eye can’t see itself, except by reflection in other surfaces.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$'Tis just.$NEWLINE$And it is very much lamented, Brutus,$NEWLINE$That you have no such mirrors as will turn$NEWLINE$Your hidden worthiness into your eye$NEWLINE$That you might see your shadow. I have heard$NEWLINE$Where many of the best respect in Rome,$NEWLINE$Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus$NEWLINE$And groaning underneath this age’s yoke,$NEWLINE$Have wished that noble Brutus had his eyes.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$That’s true. And it’s too bad, Brutus, that you don’t have any mirrors that could display your hidden excellence to yourself. I’ve heard many of the noblest Romans—next to immortal Caesar—speaking of you, complaining of the tyranny of today’s government, and wishing that your eyes were working better.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius,$NEWLINE$That you would have me seek into myself$NEWLINE$For that which is not in me?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What dangers are you trying to lead me into, Cassius, that you want me to look inside myself for something that’s not there?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear.$NEWLINE$And since you know you cannot see yourself$NEWLINE$So well as by reflection, I, your glass,$NEWLINE$Will modestly discover to yourself$NEWLINE$That of yourself which you yet know not of.$NEWLINE$And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus.$NEWLINE$Were I a common laugher, or did use$NEWLINE$To stale with ordinary oaths my love$NEWLINE$To every new protester, if you know$NEWLINE$That I do fawn on men and hug them hard$NEWLINE$And, after, scandal them, or if you know$NEWLINE$That I profess myself in banqueting$NEWLINE$To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you, good Brutus. And since you know you can see yourself best by reflection, I’ll be your mirror and show you, without exaggeration, things inside you that you can’t see. And don’t be suspicious of me, noble Brutus. If I were your average fool, or if I made my feelings for you worthless by making the same promises of friendship to everybody, or if you’d seen me first flattering men, hugging them tightly, and later slandering them behind their backs, or if you hear that I drunkenly declare friendship at banquets with all the rabble, only then, of course, go ahead and assume I’m dangerous.

paragraphs.original: Flourish, and shout within
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play offstage, and then a shout is heard.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What means this shouting? I do fear, the people$NEWLINE$Choose Caesar for their king.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why are they shouting? I’m afraid the people have made Caesar their king.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Ay, do you fear it?$NEWLINE$Then must I think you would not have it so.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Really, are you afraid of that? Then I have to assume you don’t want him to be king.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I would not, Cassius. Yet I love him well.$NEWLINE$But wherefore do you hold me here so long?$NEWLINE$What is it that you would impart to me?$NEWLINE$If it be aught toward the general good,$NEWLINE$Set honor in one eye and death i' th' other,$NEWLINE$And I will look on both indifferently,$NEWLINE$For let the gods so speed me as I love$NEWLINE$The name of honor more than I fear death.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I don’t, Cassius, though I love Caesar very much. But why do you keep me here so long? What do you want to tell me? If it’s for the good of all Romans, I’d do it even if it meant my death. Let the gods give me good luck only as long as I love honor more than I fear death.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus,$NEWLINE$As well as I do know your outward favor.$NEWLINE$Well, honor is the subject of my story.$NEWLINE$I cannot tell what you and other men$NEWLINE$Think of this life, but, for my single self,$NEWLINE$I had as lief not be as live to be$NEWLINE$In awe of such a thing as I myself.$NEWLINE$I was born free as Caesar. So were you.$NEWLINE$We both have fed as well, and we can both$NEWLINE$Endure the winter’s cold as well as he.$NEWLINE$For once upon a raw and gusty day,$NEWLINE$The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores,$NEWLINE$Caesar said to me, “Darest thou, Cassius, now$NEWLINE$Leap in with me into this angry flood$NEWLINE$And swim to yonder point?” Upon the word,$NEWLINE$Accoutred as I was, I plungèd in$NEWLINE$And bade him follow. So indeed he did.$NEWLINE$The torrent roared, and we did buffet it$NEWLINE$With lusty sinews, throwing it aside$NEWLINE$And stemming it with hearts of controversy.$NEWLINE$But ere we could arrive the point proposed,$NEWLINE$Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I sink!”$NEWLINE$I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor,$NEWLINE$Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder$NEWLINE$The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber$NEWLINE$Did I the tired Caesar. And this man
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I know this quality in you, Brutus—it’s as familiar to me as your face. Indeed, honor is what I want to talk to you about. I don’t know what you and other men think of this life, but as for me, I’d rather not live at all than live to worship a man as ordinary as myself. I was born as free as Caesar. So were you. We both have eaten as well, and we can both endure the cold winter as well as he. Once, on a cold and windy day, when the river Tiber was crashing against its banks, Caesar said to me, “Cassius, I dare you to jump into this rough water with me and swim to that point there.” As soon as he spoke, though I was fully dressed, I plunged in and called for him to follow. And he did. The water roared, and we fought against it with vigorous arms. And, thanks to our fierce competitiveness, we made progress. But before we reached the end point, Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I will sink!” And just as Aeneas, the hero who founded Rome, emerged from the fires of Troy with his elderly father Anchises on his shoulder, so I emerged from the Tiber carrying the tired Caesar.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Is now become a god, and Cassius is$NEWLINE$A wretched creature and must bend his body$NEWLINE$If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.$NEWLINE$He had a fever when he was in Spain,$NEWLINE$And when the fit was on him, I did mark$NEWLINE$How he did shake. 'Tis true, this god did shake!$NEWLINE$His coward lips did from their color fly,$NEWLINE$And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world$NEWLINE$Did lose his luster. I did hear him groan,$NEWLINE$Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans$NEWLINE$Mark him and write his speeches in their books—$NEWLINE$“Alas,” it cried, “give me some drink, Titinius,”$NEWLINE$As a sick girl. Ye gods, it doth amaze me$NEWLINE$A man of such a feeble temper should$NEWLINE$So get the start of the majestic world$NEWLINE$And bear the palm alone.
paragraphs.translated: And this is the man who has now become a god, and I’m a wretched creature who must bow down if Caesar so much as carelessly nods my way. In Spain, Caesar had a fever, and it made him shake. It’s true, this so-called “god”—he shook. His cowardly lips turned white, and the same eye whose gaze terrifies the world lost its gleam. I heard him groan—yes, I did—and the same tongue that ordered the Romans to obey him and transcribe his speeches in their books cried, “Give me some water, Titinius,” like a sick girl. It astounds me that such a weak man could beat the whole world and carry the trophy of victory alone.

paragraphs.original: Shout within. Flourish
paragraphs.translated: A shout offstage. Trumpets play.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Another general shout!$NEWLINE$I do believe that these applauses are$NEWLINE$For some new honors that are heaped on Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$More shouting! I think this applause is for some new honors awarded to Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world$NEWLINE$Like a Colossus, and we petty men$NEWLINE$Walk under his huge legs and peep about$NEWLINE$To find ourselves dishonorable graves.$NEWLINE$Men at some time are masters of their fates.$NEWLINE$The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars$NEWLINE$But in ourselves, that we are underlings.$NEWLINE$Brutus and Caesar—what should be in that “Caesar”?$NEWLINE$Why should that name be sounded more than yours?$NEWLINE$Write them together, yours is as fair a name.$NEWLINE$Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well.$NEWLINE$Weigh them, it is as heavy. Conjure with 'em,
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Why, Caesar straddles the narrow world like a giant, and we petty men walk under his huge legs and look forward only to dying dishonorably, as slaves. Men can be masters of their fate. It is not destiny’s fault, but our own faults, that we’re slaves. “Brutus” and “Caesar.” What’s so special about “Caesar”? Why should that name be proclaimed more than yours? Write them together—yours is just as good a name. Pronounce them—it is just as nice to say. Weigh them—it’s just as heavy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: “Brutus” will start a spirit as soon as “Caesar.”$NEWLINE$Now in the names of all the gods at once,$NEWLINE$Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed$NEWLINE$That he is grown so great? Age, thou art shamed!$NEWLINE$Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods!$NEWLINE$When went there by an age, since the great flood,$NEWLINE$But it was famed with more than with one man?$NEWLINE$When could they say till now, that talked of Rome,$NEWLINE$That her wide walks encompassed but one man?$NEWLINE$Now is it Rome indeed, and room enough,$NEWLINE$When there is in it but one only man.$NEWLINE$Oh, you and I have heard our fathers say,$NEWLINE$There was a Brutus once that would have brooked$NEWLINE$Th' eternal devil to keep his state in Rome$NEWLINE$As easily as a king.
paragraphs.translated: Cast spells with them, and “Brutus” will call up a ghost as well as “Caesar.” Now, in the name of all the gods, I ask you what food does Caesar eat that has made him grow so great? Our era should be ashamed! Rome has lost the ability to raise noble men! When was there ever an age, since the beginning of time, that didn’t feature more than one famous man? Until now, no one could say that only one man mattered in all of vast Rome. Now, though, in all of Rome, there’s room for only one man. You and I have heard our fathers talk of another Brutus—your ancestor—who would’ve let the devil himself reign in his Roman Republic before he let a king rule.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$That you do love me, I am nothing jealous.$NEWLINE$What you would work me to, I have some aim.$NEWLINE$How I have thought of this and of these times$NEWLINE$I shall recount hereafter. For this present,$NEWLINE$I would not, so with love I might entreat you,$NEWLINE$Be any further moved. What you have said$NEWLINE$I will consider, what you have to say$NEWLINE$I will with patience hear, and find a time$NEWLINE$Both meet to hear and answer such high things.$NEWLINE$Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this:$NEWLINE$Brutus had rather be a villager$NEWLINE$Than to repute himself a son of Rome$NEWLINE$Under these hard conditions as this time$NEWLINE$Is like to lay upon us.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I have no doubt that you love me. I’m beginning to understand what you want me to do. What I think about this, and about what’s happening here in Rome, I’ll tell you later. For now, don’t try to persuade me anymore—I ask you as a friend. I’ll think over what you’ve said, I’ll listen patiently to whatever else you have to say, and I’ll find a good time for us to discuss further such weighty matters. Until then, my noble friend, think about this: I’d rather be a poor villager than call myself a citizen of Rome under the hard conditions that this time is likely to put us through.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I am glad that my weak words$NEWLINE$Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I’m glad that my weak words have provoked even this small show of protest from you.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR and his train, which includes CASCA$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$CASCA
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR enters with his followers, who include CASCA.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$CASCA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The games are done and Caesar is returning.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The games are done and Caesar is returning.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve,$NEWLINE$And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you$NEWLINE$What hath proceeded worthy note today.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$As they pass by, grab Casca by the sleeve, and he’ll tell you if anything important happened today—in his usual sour way.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I will do so. But, look you, Cassius,$NEWLINE$The angry spot doth glow on Caesar’s brow,$NEWLINE$And all the rest look like a chidden train.$NEWLINE$Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero$NEWLINE$Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes$NEWLINE$As we have seen him in the Capitol$NEWLINE$Being crossed in conference by some senators.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I’ll do so. But look, Cassius, Caesar looks angry and everyone else looks as if they’ve been scolded. Calphurnia’s face is pale, and Cicero’s eyes are as red and fiery as they get when senators are arguing with him at the Capitol.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Casca will tell us what the matter is.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Casca will tell us what’s the matter.

paragraphs.original: During the exchange between CAESAR and ANTONY, BRUTUS pulls CASCA by the sleeve$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASCA
paragraphs.translated: During the exchange between CAESAR and ANTONY, BRUTUS pulls CASCA by the sleeve.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASCA

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Antonio.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Antonio!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Caesar?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(aside to ANTONY) Let me have men about me that are fat,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Sleek-headed men and such as sleep a-nights.$NEWLINE$Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look.$NEWLINE$He thinks too much. Such men are dangerous.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only ANTONY can hear) I want the men around me to be fat, healthy-looking men who sleep at night. That Cassius over there has a lean and hungry look. He thinks too much. Men like him are dangerous.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(aside to CAESAR) Fear him not, Caesar. He’s not dangerous.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$He is a noble Roman and well given.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only CAESAR can hear) Don’t be afraid of him, Caesar. He isn’t dangerous. He’s a noble Roman with a good disposition.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(aside to ANTONY) Would he were fatter! But I fear him not.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Yet if my name were liable to fear,$NEWLINE$I do not know the man I should avoid$NEWLINE$So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much.$NEWLINE$He is a great observer, and he looks$NEWLINE$Quite through the deeds of men. He loves no plays,$NEWLINE$As thou dost, Antony. He hears no music.$NEWLINE$Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort$NEWLINE$As if he mocked himself and scorned his spirit$NEWLINE$That could be moved to smile at anything.$NEWLINE$Such men as he be never at heart’s ease$NEWLINE$Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,$NEWLINE$And therefore are they very dangerous.$NEWLINE$I rather tell thee what is to be feared$NEWLINE$Than what I fear, for always I am Caesar.$NEWLINE$Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,$NEWLINE$And tell me truly what thou think’st of him.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only ANTONY can hear) I wish he were fatter! But I’m not afraid of him. And yet, if I were capable of fearing anyone, Cassius would be the first man I’d avoid. He reads a lot, he’s a keen observer, and he sees the hidden motives in what men do. He doesn’t like plays the way you do, Antony. He doesn’t listen to music. He rarely smiles, and when he does smile, he does so in a self-mocking way, as if he scorns himself for smiling at all. Men like him will never be comfortable while someone ranks higher than themselves, and therefore they’re very dangerous. I’m telling you what should be feared, not what I fear—because after all, I am Caesar. Come over to my right side, because this ear is deaf, and tell me what you really think of Cassius.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: Sennet. Exeunt CAESAR and all his train except CASCA$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$CASCA
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. CAESAR exits with all his followers except CASCA.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$CASCA

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$(to BRUTUS)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You pulled me by the cloak. Would you speak with me?
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$(to BRUTUS) You tugged on my cloak. Do you want to speak with me?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Ay, Casca. Tell us what hath chanced today$NEWLINE$That Caesar looks so sad.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yes, Casca. Tell us what happened today that put Caesar in such a serious mood.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Why, you were with him, were you not?
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$But you were with him, weren’t you?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$If I were, I wouldn’t need to ask you what happened.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Why, there was a crown offered him; and, being offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand, thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$A crown was offered to him, and he pushed it away with the back of his hand, like this—and then the people started shouting.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What was the second noise for?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What was the second noise for?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Why, for that too.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$The same thing.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$They shouted thrice. What was the last cry for?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$They shouted three times. What was the last cry for?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Why, for that too.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$For the same thing.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Was the crown offered him thrice?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The crown was offered to him three times?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Ay, marry, was ’t, and he put it by thrice, every time gentler than other, and at every putting-by mine honest neighbors shouted.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Yes, indeed, it was, and he pushed it away three times, each time more gently than the last; and at each refusal my countrymen shouted.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Who offered him the crown?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Who offered him the crown?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Why, Antony.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Antony.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Tell us how it happened, noble Casca.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it. It was mere foolery. I did not mark it. I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (yet ’twas not a crown neither, ’twas one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once—but, for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he offered it to him again, then he put it by again—but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his fingers off it. And then he offered it the third time. He put it the third time by. And still, as he refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked Caesar—for he swooned and fell down at it. And for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$I can’t explain it. It was all silly and so I paid no attention. I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown—though it wasn’t a real crown, just a small circlet—and, as I told you, he refused it once—though in my opinion he would’ve liked to have it. Then Antony offered it to him again, and he refused it again (though, in my opinion, he was reluctant to take his hand off it). Then Antony offered it the third time. He refused it the third time, and as he refused it the commoners hooted and clapped their chapped hands, and threw up their sweaty hats, and let loose such a great deal of stinking breath because Caesar refused the crown that it nearly choked Caesar, because he fainted and fell down. As for myself, I didn’t dare laugh, for fear of opening my lips and inhaling the stinking air.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$But soft, I pray you. What, did Caesar swoon?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$But wait a minute, please. Did you say Caesar fainted?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$He fell down in the marketplace, and foamed at mouth, and was speechless.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at the mouth and was speechless.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$'Tis very like. He hath the falling sickness.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$That’s very likely. He has epilepsy, a disease where you fall down.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$No, Caesar hath it not. But you and I$NEWLINE$And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$No, Caesar doesn’t have epilepsy. You and I, and honest Casca, we have epilepsy—we’ve fallen.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$I know not what you mean by that, but I am sure Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not clap him and hiss him according as he pleased and displeased them, as they use to do the players in the theatre, I am no true man.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$I don’t know what you mean by that, but I’m sure Caesar fell down. The rabble applauded and hissed him according to whether he pleased them or displeased them, just like they do to actors in the theater. If they didn’t, I’m a liar.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What said he when he came unto himself?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What did he say when he regained consciousness?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut. An I had been a man of any occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so he fell. When he came to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amiss, he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three or four wenches where I stood cried, “Alas, good soul!” and forgave him with all their hearts. But there’s no heed to be taken of them. If Caesar had stabbed their mothers they would have done no less.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Indeed, before he fell down, when he realized the commoners were glad he refused the crown, he pulled open his robe and offered them his throat to cut. If I’d been a common laborer and hadn’t taken him up on his offer, to hell with me. And so he fainted. When he regained consciousness again, he said that if he’d done or said anything wrong, he wanted them to know that it was all because of his sickness. Three or four women near me cried, “Alas, good soul!” and forgave him with all their hearts. But never mind them—if Caesar had stabbed their mothers, they would’ve forgiven him.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$And after that he came thus sad away?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$And after that he came back here looking so serious?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Ay.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Yes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Did Cicero say anything?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Did Cicero say anything?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Ay, he spoke Greek.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Yes, he said something in Greek.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$To what effect?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What did he say?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Nay, an I tell you that, I’ll ne'er look you i' th' face again. But those that understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads. But, for mine own part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more news too. Murellus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs off Caesar’s images, are put to silence. Fare you well. There was more foolery yet, if I could remember it.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$If I told you I understood Greek, I’d be lying. But those who understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads. As for myself, it was Greek to me. I have more news too. Murellus and Flavius have been punished for pulling scarves off statues of Caesar. There you go. There was even more foolishness, if I could only remember it.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Will you sup with me tonight, Casca?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Will you have dinner with me tonight, Casca?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$No, I am promised forth.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$No, I have a commitment.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Will you dine with me tomorrow?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Will you dine with me tomorrow?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner worth the eating.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Yes, if I’m still alive, and you’re still sane, and your dinner is worth eating.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Good. I will expect you.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Good. I’ll expect you.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Do so. Farewell both.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Do so. Farewell to you both.

paragraphs.original: Exit CASCA$NEWLINE$CASCA
paragraphs.translated: CASCA exits.$NEWLINE$CASCA

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!$NEWLINE$He was quick mettle when he went to school.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What a stupid man he’s become! He was so sharp when he was in school.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$So is he now in execution$NEWLINE$Of any bold or noble enterprise,$NEWLINE$However he puts on this tardy form.$NEWLINE$This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit,$NEWLINE$Which gives men stomach to digest his words$NEWLINE$With better appetite.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$He’s still sharp when it comes to carrying out a bold or noble enterprise, though he puts on this show of stupidity. He speaks roughly, but what he says is smart, and his roughness makes other people enjoy listening to him.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$And so it is. For this time I will leave you.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, if you please to speak with me,$NEWLINE$I will come home to you. Or, if you will,$NEWLINE$Come home to me, and I will wait for you.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You’re right, that’s how it is. I’ll leave you for now. If you’d like to talk tomorrow, I’ll come to your home. Or, if you don’t mind, come to my home, and I’ll wait for you.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I will do so. Till then, think of the world.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll do so. Until then, think about the well-being of Rome.

paragraphs.original: Exit BRUTUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS exits.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS

paragraphs.original: Well, Brutus, thou art noble. Yet I see$NEWLINE$Thy honorable mettle may be wrought$NEWLINE$From that it is disposed. Therefore it is meet$NEWLINE$That noble minds keep ever with their likes,$NEWLINE$For who so firm that cannot be seduced?$NEWLINE$Caesar doth bear me hard, but he loves Brutus.$NEWLINE$If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius,$NEWLINE$He should not humor me. I will this night,$NEWLINE$In several hands, in at his windows throw,$NEWLINE$As if they came from several citizens,$NEWLINE$Writings all tending to the great opinion$NEWLINE$That Rome holds of his name, wherein obscurely$NEWLINE$Caesar’s ambition shall be glancèd at.$NEWLINE$And after this let Caesar seat him sure,$NEWLINE$For we will shake him, or worse days endure.
paragraphs.translated: Well, Brutus, you’re noble. Yet I see that your honorable character can be bent from its usual shape, which proves that good men should stick only to the company of other good men, because who is so firm that he can’t be seduced? Caesar resents me, but he loves Brutus. If I were Brutus now and Brutus were me, I wouldn’t have let him influence me. Tonight I’ll throw through his window a few letters in different handwriting—as if they came from several citizens—all testifying to the great respect Romans have for Brutus, and all alluding to Caesar’s unseemly ambition. And after this, let Caesar brace himself, for we’ll either dethrone him or suffer even worse than now.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS exits.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thunder and lightning. Enter CASCA and CICERO$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$CICERO
paragraphs.translated: Thunder and lightning. CASCA and CICERO enter.$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$CICERO

paragraphs.original: CICERO$NEWLINE$Good even, Casca. Brought you Caesar home?$NEWLINE$Why are you breathless? And why stare you so?
paragraphs.translated: CICERO$NEWLINE$Good evening, Casca. Did you accompany Caesar home? Why are you breathless, and why are you staring like that?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Are not you moved when all the sway of earth$NEWLINE$Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,$NEWLINE$I have seen tempests when the scolding winds$NEWLINE$Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen$NEWLINE$Th' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam$NEWLINE$To be exalted with the threatening clouds,$NEWLINE$But never till tonight, never till now,$NEWLINE$Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.$NEWLINE$Either there is a civil strife in heaven,$NEWLINE$Or else the world, too saucy with the gods,$NEWLINE$Incenses them to send destruction.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Aren’t you disturbed when the earth itself is shaking and swaying as if it were a flimsy thing? Cicero, I’ve seen storms in which the angry winds split old oak trees, and I’ve seen the ocean swell, rage, and foam, as if it wanted to reach the storm clouds, but never before tonight, never until now, have I experienced a storm that drops fire. Either there are wars in heaven, or else the world, too insolent toward the gods, provokes them to send destruction.

paragraphs.original: CICERO$NEWLINE$Why, saw you anything more wonderful?
paragraphs.translated: CICERO$NEWLINE$What—have you seen something so strange that it is clearly an omen from the gods?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$A common slave—you know him well by sight—$NEWLINE$Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn$NEWLINE$Like twenty torches joined, and yet his hand,$NEWLINE$Not sensible of fire, remained unscorched.$NEWLINE$Besides—I ha' not since put up my sword—$NEWLINE$Against the Capitol I met a lion,$NEWLINE$Who glared upon me and went surly by,$NEWLINE$Without annoying me. And there were drawn$NEWLINE$Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women,$NEWLINE$Transformèd with their fear, who swore they saw$NEWLINE$Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$A common slave—you’d know him if you saw him—held up his left hand, which flamed and burned like twenty torches together. And yet his hand was immune to the fire and didn’t get burned. Also—I’ve kept my sword unsheathed since I saw this—in front of the Capitol I met a lion who looked at me and strutted by without bothering to attack me. And there were a hundred spooked women huddled together in fear who swore they saw men on fire walk up and down the streets.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And yesterday the bird of night did sit$NEWLINE$Even at noon-day upon the marketplace,$NEWLINE$Hooting and shrieking. When these prodigies$NEWLINE$Do so conjointly meet, let not men say,$NEWLINE$“These are their reasons. They are natural.”$NEWLINE$For I believe they are portentous things$NEWLINE$Unto the climate that they point upon.
paragraphs.translated: And yesterday the night owl sat hooting and shrieking in the marketplace at noon. When all these extraordinary things happen at once, we shouldn’t say, “These happenings can be explained rationally. They’re natural enough.” I think these things are omens of things to come in our country.

paragraphs.original: CICERO$NEWLINE$Indeed, it is a strange-disposèd time.$NEWLINE$But men may construe things after their fashion,$NEWLINE$Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.$NEWLINE$Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow?
paragraphs.translated: CICERO$NEWLINE$Indeed, it’s a strange time. But men tend to interpret things however suits them and totally miss the actual meaning of the things themselves. Is Caesar visiting the Capitol tomorrow?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$He doth, for he did bid Antonius$NEWLINE$Send word to you he would be there tomorrow.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$He is, because he told Antonius to tell you he’d be there tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: CICERO$NEWLINE$Good night then, Casca. This disturbèd sky$NEWLINE$Is not to walk in.
paragraphs.translated: CICERO$NEWLINE$Good night then, Casca. This bad weather isn’t good to walk around in.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Farewell, Cicero.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Farewell, Cicero

paragraphs.original: Exit CICERO$NEWLINE$CICERO
paragraphs.translated: CICERO exits.$NEWLINE$CICERO

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS enters.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$A Roman.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$A Roman.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Casca, by your voice.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$It’s Casca—I know your voice.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Your ear is good. Cassius, what a night this is!

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$A very pleasing night to honest men.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$It’s a very pleasing night to honest men.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Who ever knew the heavens menace so?
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Who ever saw the heavens threaten like this?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Those that have known the earth so full of faults.$NEWLINE$For my part, I have walked about the streets,$NEWLINE$Submitting me unto the perilous night,$NEWLINE$And, thus unbracèd, Casca, as you see,$NEWLINE$Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone.$NEWLINE$And when the cross blue lightning seemed to open$NEWLINE$The breast of heaven, I did present myself$NEWLINE$Even in the aim and very flash of it.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Those who have known how bad things are here on earth. I have walked around the streets, exposing myself to the perilous night, unbuttoned like this, as you see, Casca, baring my chest to the thunderbolt. When the forked blue lightning seemed to break open the sky, I put myself right where I thought it would hit.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?$NEWLINE$It is the part of men to fear and tremble$NEWLINE$When the most mighty gods by tokens send$NEWLINE$Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$But why did you tempt the heavens like that? Mankind’s role is to fear and tremble when the almighty gods send warning signals.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life$NEWLINE$That should be in a Roman you do want,$NEWLINE$Or else you use not. You look pale, and gaze,$NEWLINE$And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder$NEWLINE$To see the strange impatience of the heavens.$NEWLINE$But if you would consider the true cause$NEWLINE$Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,$NEWLINE$Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,$NEWLINE$Why old men fool and children calculate,$NEWLINE$Why all these things change from their ordinance$NEWLINE$Their natures and preformèd faculties$NEWLINE$To monstrous quality—why, you shall find$NEWLINE$That heaven hath infused them with these spirits$NEWLINE$To make them instruments of fear and warning$NEWLINE$Unto some monstrous state.$NEWLINE$Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man$NEWLINE$Most like this dreadful night,$NEWLINE$That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars$NEWLINE$As doth the lion in the Capitol—
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You’re acting stupid, Casca, and you lack the quick wits that a Roman should have—or else you don’t use them. You go pale, you stare, and you act in awe of the strange disturbance in the heavens. But if you thought about the real reason for all these fires, all these gliding ghosts, for why birds and animals abandon their natural behavior, why old men, fools, and children make predictions, why all sorts of things have departed from the usual course of their natures and become monstrosities, then you’d understand that heaven had them act this way so they would serve as frightening warnings of an unnatural state to come. Right this minute, Casca, I could name a man who’s just like this dreadful night. A man who thunders, throws lightning, splits open graves, and roars like the lion in the Capitol.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: A man no mightier than thyself or me$NEWLINE$In personal action, yet prodigious grown,$NEWLINE$And fearful as these strange eruptions are.
paragraphs.translated: A man no mightier than you or I in ability, yet grown as huge and frightening as tonight’s strange happenings.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$'Tis Caesar that you mean. Is it not, Cassius?
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$You’re talking about Caesar, right, Cassius?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Let it be who it is. For Romans now$NEWLINE$Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors,$NEWLINE$But—woe the while!—our fathers' minds are dead,$NEWLINE$And we are governed with our mothers' spirits.$NEWLINE$Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Let it be who it is. Romans today still have the powerful bodies of their ancestors, but, unfortunately, we don’t have their manly spirits, and instead we take after our mothers. Our tolerance for slavery and oppression shows us to be weak, like women.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow$NEWLINE$Mean to establish Caesar as a king,$NEWLINE$And he shall wear his crown by sea and land$NEWLINE$In every place save here in Italy.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Indeed, they say that the senators plan to establish Caesar as a king tomorrow, and he’ll wear his crown at sea and on land everywhere except here in Italy.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I know where I will wear this dagger then.$NEWLINE$Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius.$NEWLINE$Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong.$NEWLINE$Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat.$NEWLINE$Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,$NEWLINE$Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron$NEWLINE$Can be retentive to the strength of spirit.$NEWLINE$But life, being weary of these worldly bars,$NEWLINE$Never lacks power to dismiss itself.$NEWLINE$If I know this, know all the world besides,$NEWLINE$That part of tyranny that I do bear$NEWLINE$I can shake off at pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I know where I’ll wear this dagger, then. I’ll kill myself to save myself from slavery. In suicide, gods make the weak strong. In suicide, gods allow tyrants to be defeated. No stony tower, no brass walls, no airless dungeon, no iron chains can contain a strong mind. But if a man becomes weary of these obstacles, he can always kill himself. Let everyone beware: I can shake off the tyranny that now oppresses me whenever I choose.

paragraphs.original: Thunder still
paragraphs.translated: Thunder continues.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$So can I.$NEWLINE$So every bondman in his own hand bears$NEWLINE$The power to cancel his captivity.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$So can I. In fact, every imprisoned man holds in his own hand the tool to free himself.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?$NEWLINE$Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf$NEWLINE$But that he sees the Romans are but sheep.$NEWLINE$He were no lion were not Romans hinds.$NEWLINE$Those that with haste will make a mighty fire$NEWLINE$Begin it with weak straws. What trash is Rome,$NEWLINE$What rubbish and what offal, when it serves$NEWLINE$For the base matter to illuminate$NEWLINE$So vile a thing as Caesar! But, O grief,$NEWLINE$Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this$NEWLINE$Before a willing bondman. Then I know$NEWLINE$My answer must be made. But I am armed,$NEWLINE$And dangers are to me indifferent.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$How can Caesar be a tyrant then? Poor man! I know he wouldn’t be a wolf if the Romans didn’t act like sheep. He couldn’t be a lion if the Romans weren’t such easy prey. People who want to start a big fire quickly start with little twigs. Rome becomes complete trash, nothing but rubbish and garbage, when it works to light up the ambitions of someone as worthless as Caesar. But, oh no! What have I said in my grief? I might be speaking to someone who wants to be a slave, in which case I’ll be held accountable for my words. But I’m armed and I don’t care about danger.$NEWLINE$wants

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$You speak to Casca, and to such a man$NEWLINE$That is no fleering telltale. Hold, my hand.$NEWLINE$Be factious for redress of all these griefs,$NEWLINE$And I will set this foot of mine as far$NEWLINE$As who goes farthest.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$You’re talking to Casca, not to some smiling, two-faced tattletale. Say no more. Shake my hand. If you’re joining together to right these wrongs, I’ll go as far as any one of you.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$There’s a bargain made.$NEWLINE$Now know you, Casca, I have moved already$NEWLINE$Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans$NEWLINE$To undergo with me an enterprise$NEWLINE$Of honorable-dangerous consequence.$NEWLINE$And I do know by this they stay for me$NEWLINE$In Pompey’s porch. For now, this fearful night,$NEWLINE$There is no stir or walking in the streets,$NEWLINE$And the complexion of the element$NEWLINE$In favor’s like the work we have in hand,$NEWLINE$Most bloody, fiery, and most terrible.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$That’s a deal. Now let me tell you, Casca, I have already convinced some of the noblest Romans to join me in an honorable but dangerous mission. And I know that by now they’re waiting for me on the porch outside Pompey’s theater. We’re meeting on this fearful night because no one is out on the streets. The sky tonight looks bloody, fiery, and terrible, just like the work we have to do.

paragraphs.original: Enter CINNA$NEWLINE$CINNA
paragraphs.translated: CINNA enters.$NEWLINE$CINNA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Hide for a minute—someone’s approaching fast.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$'Tis Cinna. I do know him by his gait.$NEWLINE$He is a friend.—Cinna, where haste you so?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$It’s Cinna. I recognize his walk. He’s a friend. Cinna, where are you going in such a hurry?

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$To find out you. Who’s that? Metellus Cimber?
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$To find you. Who’s that? Metellus Cimber?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$No, it is Casca, one incorporate$NEWLINE$To our attempts. Am I not stayed for, Cinna?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$No, it’s Casca, someone who’s going to work with us. Aren’t the others waiting for me, Cinna?

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$I am glad on ’t. What a fearful night is this!$NEWLINE$There’s two or three of us have seen strange sights.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$I’m glad Casca is with us. What a fearful night this is! Two or three of us have seen strange things.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Am I not stayed for? Tell me.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Are the others waiting? Tell me.

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$Yes, you are.$NEWLINE$O Cassius, if you could$NEWLINE$But win the noble Brutus to our party—
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$Yes, they are. Oh, Cassius, if you could only convince Brutus to join us—

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Be you content. Good Cinna, take this paper,$NEWLINE$And look you lay it in the praetor’s chair$NEWLINE$Where Brutus may but find it. And throw this$NEWLINE$In at his window. Set this up with wax$NEWLINE$Upon old Brutus' statue. All this done,$NEWLINE$Repair to Pompey’s porch, where you shall find us.$NEWLINE$Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Don’t worry. Good Cinna, take this paper and be sure to lay it in the judge’s chair where Brutus sits, so he’ll find it. And throw this one in his window, and attach this one with wax to the statue of Brutus’s ancestor, old Brutus. When you’ve finished all this, return to the porch of Pompey’s theater, where you’ll find us. Are Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$All but Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone$NEWLINE$To seek you at your house. Well, I will hie,$NEWLINE$And so bestow these papers as you bade me.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$Everyone’s there except Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone to look for you at your house. Well, I’ll hurry and put these papers where you told me.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$That done, repair to Pompey’s theatre.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$When you’ve finished, go back to Pompey’s theater.

paragraphs.original: Exit CINNA$NEWLINE$CINNA
paragraphs.translated: CINNA exits.$NEWLINE$CINNA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day$NEWLINE$See Brutus at his house. Three parts of him$NEWLINE$Is ours already, and the man entire$NEWLINE$Upon the next encounter yields him ours.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, Casca, you and I will go see Brutus at his house before sunrise. He’s three-quarters on our side already, and we’ll win him over entirely at this meeting.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Oh, he sits high in all the people’s hearts,$NEWLINE$And that which would appear offense in us,$NEWLINE$His countenance, like richest alchemy,$NEWLINE$Will change to virtue and to worthiness.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Oh, the people love him well. Things that would look bad if we did them, Brutus could do and look virtuous—just like an alchemist turns worthless tin to gold.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Him and his worth and our great need of him$NEWLINE$You have right well conceited. Let us go,$NEWLINE$For it is after midnight, and ere day$NEWLINE$We will awake him and be sure of him.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Yes, you’re absolutely right about how worthy Brutus is and how much we need him. Let’s go, because it’s already after midnight, and we want him on our side before daylight.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BRUTUS in his orchard$NEWLINE$BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS enters in his orchard.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What, Lucius, ho!—$NEWLINE$I cannot by the progress of the stars$NEWLINE$Give guess how near to day.—Lucius, I say!—$NEWLINE$I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.—$NEWLINE$When, Lucius, when? Awake, I say! What, Lucius!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucius, are you there? I can’t tell by the position of the stars how near it is to daybreak—Lucius, are you there? I wish I had that weakness, to sleep too soundly. Come on, Lucius! Wake up, I say! Lucius!

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS enters.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Called you, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Did you call me, my lord?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Get me a taper in my study, Lucius.$NEWLINE$When it is lighted, come and call me here.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Put a candle in my study, Lucius. Call me when it’s lit.

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I will, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$It must be by his death, and for my part$NEWLINE$I know no personal cause to spurn at him$NEWLINE$But for the general. He would be crowned.$NEWLINE$How that might change his nature, there’s the question.$NEWLINE$It is the bright day that brings forth the adder$NEWLINE$And that craves wary walking. Crown him that,$NEWLINE$And then I grant we put a sting in him$NEWLINE$That at his will he may do danger with.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The only way is to kill Caesar. I have no personal reason to strike at him—only the best interest of the people. He wants to be crowned. The question is, how would being king change him? Evil can come from good, just as poisonous snakes tend to come out into the open on bright sunny days—which means we have to walk carefully. If we crown him, I have to admit we’d be giving him the power to do damage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Th' abuse of greatness is when it disjoins$NEWLINE$Remorse from power. And, to speak truth of Caesar,$NEWLINE$I have not known when his affections swayed$NEWLINE$More than his reason. But ’tis a common proof$NEWLINE$That lowliness is young ambition’s ladder,$NEWLINE$Whereto the climber upward turns his face.$NEWLINE$But when he once attains the upmost round,$NEWLINE$He then unto the ladder turns his back,$NEWLINE$Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees$NEWLINE$By which he did ascend. So Caesar may.$NEWLINE$Then, lest he may, prevent. And since the quarrel$NEWLINE$Will bear no color for the thing he is,$NEWLINE$Fashion it thus: that what he is, augmented,$NEWLINE$Would run to these and these extremities.$NEWLINE$And therefore think him as a serpent’s egg—$NEWLINE$Which, hatched, would as his kind grow mischievous—$NEWLINE$And kill him in the shell.
paragraphs.translated: Rulers abuse their power when they separate it from compassion. To be honest, I’ve never known Caesar to let his emotions get the better of his reason. But everyone knows that an ambitious young man uses humility to advance himself, but when he reaches the top, he turns his back on his supporters and reaches for the skies while scorning those who helped him get where he is. Caesar might act like that. Therefore, in case he does, we must hold him back. And since our quarrel is with his future behavior, not what he does now, I must frame the argument like this: if his position is furthered, his character will fulfill these predictions. And therefore we should liken him to a serpent’s egg—once it has hatched, it becomes dangerous, like all serpents. Thus we must kill him while he’s still in the shell.

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS enters.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$The taper burneth in your closet, sir.$NEWLINE$Searching the window for a flint, I found$NEWLINE$This paper, thus sealed up, and I am sure$NEWLINE$It did not lie there when I went to bed.$NEWLINE$(gives him a letter)$NEWLINE$(gives him a letter)
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$The candle is burning in your study, sir. While I was looking for a flint to light it, I found this paper on the window, sealed up like this, and I’m sure it wasn’t there when I went to bed. (he gives BRUTUS the letter)$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$the letter)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Get you to bed again. It is not day.$NEWLINE$Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Go back to bed. It isn’t daybreak yet. Is tomorrow the 15th of March, boy?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I know not, sir.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I don’t know, sir.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Look in the calendar and bring me word.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Check the calendar and come tell me.

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I will, sir.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I will, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The exhalations whizzing in the air$NEWLINE$Give so much light that I may read by them.$NEWLINE$(opens the letter and reads)$NEWLINE$(opens the letter and reads)$NEWLINE$“Brutus, thou sleep’st. Awake, and see thyself.$NEWLINE$Shall Rome, etc. Speak, strike, redress!”$NEWLINE$“Brutus, thou sleep’st. Awake.”$NEWLINE$Such instigations have been often dropped$NEWLINE$Where I have took them up.$NEWLINE$—“Shall Rome, etc.” Thus must I piece it out:$NEWLINE$“Shall Rome stand under one man’s awe?” What, Rome?$NEWLINE$My ancestors did from the streets of Rome$NEWLINE$The Tarquin drive when he was called a king.$NEWLINE$—“Speak, strike, redress!” Am I entreated$NEWLINE$To speak and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise,$NEWLINE$If the redress will follow, thou receivest$NEWLINE$Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The meteors whizzing in the sky are so bright that I can read by them. (he opens the letter and reads) “Brutus, you’re sleeping. Wake up and look at yourself. Is Rome going to … etc. Speak, strike, fix the wrongs!” “Brutus, you’re sleeping. Wake up.” I’ve noticed many such calls to action left where I would find them. “Is Rome going to … etc.” What does this mean? Will Rome submit to one man’s power? My ancestors drove Tarquin from the streets of Rome when he was pronounced a king. “Speak, strike, fix it!” Is this asking me to speak and strike? Oh, Rome, I promise you, if you’re meant to receive justice, you’ll receive it by my hand!$NEWLINE$(he opens the letter and reads)

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS enters.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Sir, fifteen days of March have gone by.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: The sound of a knock offstage.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$'Tis good. Go to the gate. Somebody knocks.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good. Go to the gate. Somebody’s knocking.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,$NEWLINE$I have not slept.
paragraphs.translated: I haven’t slept since Cassius first began to turn me against Caesar.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Between the acting of a dreadful thing$NEWLINE$And the first motion, all the interim is$NEWLINE$Like a phantasma or a hideous dream.$NEWLINE$The genius and the mortal instruments$NEWLINE$Are then in council, and the state of man,$NEWLINE$Like to a little kingdom, suffers then$NEWLINE$The nature of an insurrection.
paragraphs.translated: From the time when you decide to do something terrible to the moment you do it, everything feels unreal, like a horrible dream. The unconscious and the body work together and rebel against the conscious mind.

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS enters.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Sir, ’tis your brother Cassius at the door,$NEWLINE$Who doth desire to see you.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Sir, it’s your brother-in-law Cassius at the door. He wants to see you.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Is he alone?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Is he alone?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$No, sir, there are more with him.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$No, sir. There are others with him.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Do you know them?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Do you know them?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$No, sir. Their hats are plucked about their ears,$NEWLINE$And half their faces buried in their cloaks,$NEWLINE$That by no means I may discover them$NEWLINE$By any mark of favor.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$No, sir, their hats are pulled down over their ears and their faces are half buried under their cloaks, so there’s no way to tell who they are.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Let 'em enter.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Let them in.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: They are the faction. O conspiracy,$NEWLINE$Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night$NEWLINE$When evils are most free? O, then by day$NEWLINE$Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough$NEWLINE$To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy.$NEWLINE$Hide it in smiles and affability.
paragraphs.translated: It’s the faction that wants to kill Caesar. Oh, conspiracy, are you ashamed to show your face even at night, when evil things are most free? If so, when it’s day, where are you going to find a cave dark enough to hide your monstrous face? No, don’t bother to find a cave, conspiracy. Instead, hide your true face behind smiles and friendliness.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: For if thou path, thy native semblance on,$NEWLINE$Not Erebus itself were dim enough$NEWLINE$To hide thee from prevention.
paragraphs.translated: If you went ahead and exposed your true face, Hell itself wouldn’t be dark enough to keep you from being found and stopped.

paragraphs.original: Enter the conspirators: CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS, CINNA, METELLUS, and TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$DECIUS$NEWLINE$CINNA$NEWLINE$METELLUS$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS
paragraphs.translated: The conspirators—CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS, CINNA, METELLUS, and TREBONIUS—enter.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$DECIUS$NEWLINE$CINNA$NEWLINE$METELLUS$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I think we are too bold upon your rest.$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Brutus. Do we trouble you?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I’m afraid we’re intruding too boldly on your sleep time. Good morning, Brutus. Are we bothering you?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I have been up this hour, awake all night.$NEWLINE$Know I these men that come along with you?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I was awake. I’ve been up all night. Do I know these men who are with you?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Yes, every man of them, and no man here$NEWLINE$But honors you, and every one doth wish$NEWLINE$You had but that opinion of yourself$NEWLINE$Which every noble Roman bears of you.$NEWLINE$This is Trebonius.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Yes, every one of them. There isn’t one of them who doesn’t admire you, and each one of them wishes you had as high an opinion of yourself as every noble Roman has of you. This is Trebonius.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He is welcome hither.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He’s welcome here.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$This, Decius Brutus.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$This is Decius Brutus.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He is welcome too.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He’s welcome too.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$This, Casca. This, Cinna. And this, Metellus Cimber.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$This is Casca. This is Cinna. And this is Metellus Cimber.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$They are all welcome.$NEWLINE$What watchful cares do interpose themselves$NEWLINE$Betwixt your eyes and night?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$They’re all welcome. What worries have kept you awake tonight?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Shall I entreat a word?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Can I have a word with you?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS and CASSIUS withdraw and whisper$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS and CASSIUS whisper together.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Here lies the east. Doth not the day break here?
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Here’s the east. Won’t the dawn come from here?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$No.
