paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$O, pardon, sir, it doth, and yon gray lines$NEWLINE$That fret the clouds are messengers of day.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$Excuse me, sir, it will. These gray lines that lace the clouds are the beginnings of the dawn.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$You shall confess that you are both deceived.$NEWLINE$(points his sword)$NEWLINE$(points his sword)$NEWLINE$Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises,$NEWLINE$Which is a great way growing on the south,$NEWLINE$Weighing the youthful season of the year.$NEWLINE$Some two months hence up higher toward the north$NEWLINE$He first presents his fire, and the high east$NEWLINE$Stands, as the Capitol, directly here.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$You’re both wrong. (pointing his sword) Here, where I point my sword, the sun rises. It’s quite near the south, since it’s still winter. About two months from now, the dawn will break further toward the north, and due east is where the Capitol stands, here.$NEWLINE$(pointing his sword)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(comes forward with CASSIUS)$NEWLINE$(comes forward with$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Give me your hands all over, one by one.$NEWLINE$(shakes their hands)$NEWLINE$(shakes their hands)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(coming forward with CASSIUS) Give me your hands, all of you, one by one. (he shakes their hands)$NEWLINE$(coming forward with$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(he shakes their hands)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And let us swear our resolution.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And let us swear to our resolution.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, not an oath. If not the face of men,$NEWLINE$The sufferance of our souls, the time’s abuse—$NEWLINE$If these be motives weak, break off betimes,$NEWLINE$And every man hence to his idle bed.$NEWLINE$So let high-sighted tyranny range on$NEWLINE$Till each man drop by lottery. But if these—$NEWLINE$As I am sure they do—bear fire enough$NEWLINE$To kindle cowards and to steel with valor$NEWLINE$The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen,$NEWLINE$What need we any spur but our own cause$NEWLINE$To prick us to redress? What other bond$NEWLINE$Than secret Romans that have spoke the word$NEWLINE$And will not palter? And what other oath$NEWLINE$Than honesty to honesty engaged,$NEWLINE$That this shall be, or we will fall for it?$NEWLINE$Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous,$NEWLINE$Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls$NEWLINE$That welcome wrongs. Unto bad causes swear$NEWLINE$Such creatures as men doubt. But do not stain$NEWLINE$The even virtue of our enterprise,$NEWLINE$Nor th' insuppressive mettle of our spirits,$NEWLINE$To think that or our cause or our performance$NEWLINE$Did need an oath, when every drop of blood$NEWLINE$That every Roman bears—and nobly bears—$NEWLINE$Is guilty of a several bastardy$NEWLINE$If he do break the smallest particle$NEWLINE$Of any promise that hath passed from him.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, let’s not swear an oath. If the sad faces of our fellow men, the suffering of our own souls, and the corruption of the present time aren’t enough to motivate us, let’s break it off now and each of us go back to bed. Then we can let this ambitious tyrant continue unchallenged until each of us is killed at his whim. But if we have reasons that are strong enough to ignite cowards into action and to make weak women brave—and I think we do—then, countrymen, what else could we possibly need to spur us to action? What bond do we need other than that of discreet Romans who have said what they’re going to do and won’t back down? And what oath do we need other than that we honest men have told each other that this will happen or we will die trying? Swearing is for priests, cowards, overly cautious men, feeble old people, and those long-suffering weaklings who welcome abuse. Only men whom you wouldn’t trust anyway would swear oaths, and for the worst reasons. Don’t spoil the justness and virtue of our endeavor nor weaken our own irrepressible spirits by thinking that we need a binding oath, when the blood that every noble Roman contains within him would be proven bastard’s blood if he broke the smallest part of any promise he had made.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$But what of Cicero? Shall we sound him?$NEWLINE$I think he will stand very strong with us.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$But what about Cicero? Should we see what he thinks? I think he will stand strong with us.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Let us not leave him out.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Let’s not leave him out.

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$No, by no means.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$No, by no means.

paragraphs.original: METELLUS$NEWLINE$O, let us have him, for his silver hairs$NEWLINE$Will purchase us a good opinion$NEWLINE$And buy men’s voices to commend our deeds.$NEWLINE$It shall be said his judgment ruled our hands.$NEWLINE$Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear,$NEWLINE$But all be buried in his gravity.
paragraphs.translated: METELLUS$NEWLINE$Yes, we should get his support, for his mature presence will make others think well of us and speak out in support of our actions. They’ll assume that Cicero, with his sound judgment, ordered the actions. His dignified maturity will distract attention from our youth and wildness.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$O, name him not. Let us not break with him,$NEWLINE$For he will never follow anything$NEWLINE$That other men begin.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, don’t even mention him. We shouldn’t tell him about our plans. He’ll never follow anything that other men have started.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Then leave him out.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Then leave him out.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Indeed he is not fit.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Indeed, he’s not right for this.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Shall no man else be touched but only Caesar?
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$But should we only go after Caesar? No one else?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Decius, well urged. I think it is not meet$NEWLINE$Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar,$NEWLINE$Should outlive Caesar. We shall find of him$NEWLINE$A shrewd contriver. And, you know, his means,$NEWLINE$If he improve them, may well stretch so far$NEWLINE$As to annoy us all; which to prevent,$NEWLINE$Let Antony and Caesar fall together.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Good point, Decius. I don’t think it would be wise to let Mark Antony, whom Caesar is so fond of, outlive Caesar. We’d find that he was a dangerous plotter. And as you know, his connections, if he put them to good use, might be enough to hurt us all. To prevent this, Mark Antony should die along with Caesar.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius,$NEWLINE$To cut the head off and then hack the limbs,$NEWLINE$Like wrath in death and envy afterwards,$NEWLINE$For Antony is but a limb of Caesar.$NEWLINE$Let us be sacrificers but not butchers, Caius.$NEWLINE$We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar,$NEWLINE$And in the spirit of men there is no blood.$NEWLINE$Oh, that we then could come by Caesar’s spirit$NEWLINE$And not dismember Caesar! But, alas,$NEWLINE$Caesar must bleed for it. And, gentle friends,$NEWLINE$Let’s kill him boldly but not wrathfully.$NEWLINE$Let’s carve him as a dish fit for the gods,$NEWLINE$Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds.$NEWLINE$And let our hearts, as subtle masters do,$NEWLINE$Stir up their servants to an act of rage$NEWLINE$And after seem to chide 'em. This shall make$NEWLINE$Our purpose necessary and not envious,$NEWLINE$Which so appearing to the common eyes,$NEWLINE$We shall be called purgers, not murderers.$NEWLINE$And for Mark Antony, think not of him,$NEWLINE$For he can do no more than Caesar’s arm$NEWLINE$When Caesar’s head is off.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Our action will seem too bloody if we cut off Caesar’s head and then hack at his arms and legs too, Caius Cassius—because Mark Antony is merely one of Caesar’s arms. It’ll look like we killed Caesar out of anger and Mark Antony out of envy. Let’s be sacrificers but not butchers, Caius. We’re all against what Caesar stands for, and there’s no blood in that. Oh, how I wish we could oppose Caesar’s spirit—his overblown ambition—and not hack up Caesar himself! But, unfortunately, Caesar has to bleed if we’re going to stop him. Noble friends, let’s kill him boldly but not with anger. Let’s carve him up like a dish fit for the gods, not chop him up like a carcass fit for dogs. Let’s be angry only long enough to do the deed, and then let’s act like we’re disgusted by what we had to do. This will make our actions seem practical and not vengeful. If we appear calm to the people, they’ll call us surgeons rather than murderers. As for Mark Antony—forget him. He’ll be as useless as Caesar’s arm after Caesar’s head is cut off.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Yet I fear him.$NEWLINE$For in the engrafted love he bears to Caesar—
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$But I’m still afraid of him, because the deep-rooted love he has for Caesar—

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him.$NEWLINE$If he love Caesar, all that he can do$NEWLINE$Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar.$NEWLINE$And that were much he should, for he is given$NEWLINE$To sports, to wildness and much company.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Alas, good Cassius, don’t think about him. If he loves Caesar, then he can only hurt himself—by grieving and dying for Caesar. And I’d be surprised if he even did that, for he prefers sports, fun, and friends.

paragraphs.original: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$There is no fear in him. Let him not die,$NEWLINE$For he will live and laugh at this hereafter.
paragraphs.translated: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$There’s nothing to fear in him. Let’s not kill him. He’ll live and laugh at this afterward.

paragraphs.original: Clock strikes
paragraphs.translated: A clock strikes.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Peace! Count the clock.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Quiet! Count how many times the clock chimes.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$The clock hath stricken three.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$The clock struck three.

paragraphs.original: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$'Tis time to part.
paragraphs.translated: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$It’s time to leave.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$But it is doubtful yet$NEWLINE$Whether Caesar will come forth today or no.$NEWLINE$For he is superstitious grown of late,$NEWLINE$Quite from the main opinion he held once$NEWLINE$Of fantasy, of dreams and ceremonies.$NEWLINE$It may be, these apparent prodigies,$NEWLINE$The unaccustomed terror of this night,$NEWLINE$And the persuasion of his augurers$NEWLINE$May hold him from the Capitol today.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$But we still don’t know whether Caesar will go out in public today or not, because he’s become superstitious lately, a complete turnaround from when he used to have such a bad opinion of fortune-tellers, dream interpreters, and ritual mumbo-jumbo. It might happen that these strange signs, the unusual terror of this night, and the urgings of his fortune-tellers will keep him away from the Capitol today.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Never fear that. If he be so resolved,$NEWLINE$I can o'ersway him. For he loves to hear$NEWLINE$That unicorns may be betrayed with trees,$NEWLINE$And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,$NEWLINE$Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.$NEWLINE$But when I tell him he hates flatterers,$NEWLINE$He says he does, being then most flatterèd.$NEWLINE$Let me work.$NEWLINE$For I can give his humor the true bent,$NEWLINE$And I will bring him to the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Don’t worry about that. If he’s reluctant, I can convince him. He loves to hear me tell him how men can be snared by flatterers, just like unicorns can be captured in trees, elephants in holes, and lions with nets. When I tell him he hates flatterers, he agrees, just at the moment when I’m flattering him the most.$NEWLINE$Let me work on him. I can put him in the right mood, and I’ll bring him to the Capitol.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$No, we’ll all go there to bring him.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$By the eighth hour. Is that the uttermost?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$By eight o'clock. Is that the latest we can do it?

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$Let’s make that the latest, but be sure to get there before then.

paragraphs.original: METELLUS$NEWLINE$Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,$NEWLINE$Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey.$NEWLINE$I wonder none of you have thought of him.
paragraphs.translated: METELLUS$NEWLINE$Caius Ligarius doesn’t like Caesar, who berated him for speaking well of Pompey. I wonder that none of you thought about getting his support.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Now, good Metellus, go along by him.$NEWLINE$He loves me well, and I have given him reasons.$NEWLINE$Send him but hither and I’ll fashion him.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good Metellus, go to him now. He likes me, and I’ve given him good reason to. Just send him here, and I’ll persuade him.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$The morning comes upon ’s. We’ll leave you, Brutus.$NEWLINE$—And, friends, disperse yourselves. But all remember$NEWLINE$What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$The morning is approaching. We’ll leave, Brutus. Friends, go your separate ways. But all of you, remember what you’ve said and prove yourselves true Romans.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily.$NEWLINE$Let not our looks put on our purposes,$NEWLINE$But bear it as our Roman actors do,$NEWLINE$With untired spirits and formal constancy.$NEWLINE$And so good morrow to you every one.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good gentlemen, look like you’re rested and happy. Don’t let our faces betray our plans. Instead, carry yourselves like Roman actors, with cheerful spirits and well-composed faces. And so, good morning to all of you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt. Manet BRUTUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except BRUTUS exits.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Boy! Lucius!—Fast asleep? It is no matter.$NEWLINE$Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber.$NEWLINE$Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,$NEWLINE$Which busy care draws in the brains of men.$NEWLINE$Therefore thou sleep’st so sound.
paragraphs.translated: Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? Well, enjoy the sweetness of deep sleep. Your brain isn’t stuffed with the strange shapes and fantasies that come to men who are overwhelmed by worries. That’s why you sleep so soundly.

paragraphs.original: Enter PORTIA$NEWLINE$PORTIA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA enters.$NEWLINE$PORTIA

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Brutus, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Brutus, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Portia, what mean you? Wherefore rise you now?$NEWLINE$It is not for your health thus to commit$NEWLINE$Your weak condition to the raw, cold morning.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Portia, what are you doing awake? It isn’t good for your health to expose your weak body to the raw, cold morning.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Nor for yours neither. Y' have ungently, Brutus,$NEWLINE$Stole from my bed. And yesternight, at supper,$NEWLINE$You suddenly arose and walked about,$NEWLINE$Musing and sighing, with your arms across,$NEWLINE$And when I asked you what the matter was,$NEWLINE$You stared upon me with ungentle looks.$NEWLINE$I urged you further, then you scratched your head$NEWLINE$And too impatiently stamped with your foot.$NEWLINE$Yet I insisted; yet you answered not,$NEWLINE$But with an angry wafture of your hand$NEWLINE$Gave sign for me to leave you. So I did,$NEWLINE$Fearing to strengthen that impatience$NEWLINE$Which seemed too much enkindled, and withal$NEWLINE$Hoping it was but an effect of humor,$NEWLINE$Which sometime hath his hour with every man.$NEWLINE$It will not let you eat nor talk nor sleep,$NEWLINE$And could it work so much upon your shape$NEWLINE$As it hath much prevailed on your condition,$NEWLINE$I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord,$NEWLINE$Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$It’s not good for your health, either. You rudely snuck out of bed. And last night at dinner, you got up abruptly and paced back and forth with your arms crossed, brooding and sighing, and when I asked you what was the matter, you gave me a dirty look. I asked you again, and you scratched your head and stamped your foot impatiently. I still insisted on knowing what the matter was, but you wouldn’t answer me, instead giving me an angry wave of your hand and telling me to leave you alone. So I left, afraid of further provoking anger that was already inflamed but still hoping this was merely moodiness, which everyone is affected by once in awhile. Your strange mood won’t let you eat or talk or sleep. If it had changed your outward appearance as much as it has affected you on the inside, I wouldn’t even be able to recognize you, Brutus. My dear lord, tell me what’s bothering you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I am not well in health, and that is all.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I’m not feeling well—that’s all.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Brutus is wise, and were he not in health,$NEWLINE$He would embrace the means to come by it.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You’re smart, though, and if you were sick, you’d take what you needed to get better.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I’m doing so. Good Portia, go to bed.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is Brutus sick? And is it physical$NEWLINE$To walk unbracèd and suck up the humors$NEWLINE$Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,$NEWLINE$And will he steal out of his wholesome bed,$NEWLINE$To dare the vile contagion of the night$NEWLINE$And tempt the rheumy and unpurgèd air$NEWLINE$To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus.$NEWLINE$You have some sick offense within your mind,$NEWLINE$Which by the right and virtue of my place$NEWLINE$I ought to know of.$NEWLINE$(kneels) And upon my knees$NEWLINE$(kneels)$NEWLINE$I charm you, by my once-commended beauty,$NEWLINE$By all your vows of love and that great vow$NEWLINE$Which did incorporate and make us one$NEWLINE$That you unfold to me, your self, your half,$NEWLINE$Why you are heavy, and what men tonight$NEWLINE$Have had to resort to you. For here have been$NEWLINE$Some six or seven who did hide their faces$NEWLINE$Even from darkness.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Are you sick? And is it healthy to walk uncovered and breathe in the dampness of the morning? You’re sick, yet you sneak out of your warm bed and let the humid and disease-infested air make you sicker? No, my Brutus, you have some sickness within your mind, which by virtue of my position I deserve to know about. (she kneels) And on my knees, I urge you, by my once-praised beauty, by all your vows of love and that great vow of marriage which made the two of us one person, that you should reveal to me, who is one half of yourself, why you’re troubled and what men have visited you tonight. For there were six or seven men here, who hid their faces even in the darkness.$NEWLINE$(she kneels)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Kneel not, gentle Portia.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Don’t kneel, noble Portia.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(rising) I should not need if you were gentle, Brutus.$NEWLINE$(rising)$NEWLINE$Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,$NEWLINE$Is it excepted I should know no secrets$NEWLINE$That appertain to you? Am I yourself$NEWLINE$But, as it were, in sort or limitation,$NEWLINE$To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,$NEWLINE$And talk to you sometimes?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(getting up) I wouldn’t need to if you were acting nobly. Tell me, Brutus, as your wife, aren’t I supposed to be told the secrets that concern you? Am I part of you only in a limited sense—I get to have dinner with you, sleep with you, and talk to you sometimes?$NEWLINE$(getting up)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Dwell I but in the suburbs$NEWLINE$Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,$NEWLINE$Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.
paragraphs.translated: Is my place only on the outskirts of your happiness? If it’s nothing more than that, then I’m your whore, not your wife.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You are my true and honorable wife,$NEWLINE$As dear to me as are the ruddy drops$NEWLINE$That visit my sad heart.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You’re my true and honorable wife, as dear to me as the blood that runs through my sad heart.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If this were true, then should I know this secret.$NEWLINE$I grant I am a woman, but withal$NEWLINE$A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife.$NEWLINE$I grant I am a woman, but withal$NEWLINE$A woman well-reputed, Cato’s daughter.$NEWLINE$Think you I am no stronger than my sex,$NEWLINE$Being so fathered and so husbanded?$NEWLINE$Tell me your counsels. I will not disclose 'em.$NEWLINE$I have made strong proof of my constancy,$NEWLINE$Giving myself a voluntary wound$NEWLINE$Here in the thigh. Can I bear that with patience,$NEWLINE$And not my husband’s secrets?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If that were true, then I’d know your secret. I admit I’m only a woman, but nevertheless I’m the woman Lord Brutus took for his wife. I admit I’m only a woman, but I’m still a woman from a noble family—I’m Cato’s daughter. Do you really think I’m no stronger than the rest of my sex, with such a father and such a husband? Tell me your secrets. I won’t betray them. I’ve proved my trustworthiness by giving myself a voluntary wound here in my thigh. If I can bear that pain, then I can bear my husband’s secrets.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$O ye gods,$NEWLINE$Render me worthy of this noble wife!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh, gods, make me worthy of this noble wife!

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A knocking sound offstage.

paragraphs.original: Hark, hark! One knocks. Portia, go in awhile.$NEWLINE$And by and by thy bosom shall partake$NEWLINE$The secrets of my heart.$NEWLINE$All my engagements I will construe to thee,$NEWLINE$All the charactery of my sad brows.$NEWLINE$Leave me with haste.
paragraphs.translated: Listen! Someone knocks. Portia, go inside awhile, and soon enough you’ll share the secrets of my heart. I’ll explain all that I have committed to do and all the reasons for my sad face. Leave me quickly.

paragraphs.original: Exit PORTIA$NEWLINE$PORTIA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA exits.$NEWLINE$PORTIA

paragraphs.original: Lucius, who’s that knocking?
paragraphs.translated: Lucius, who’s that knocking?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS and LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LIGARIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS and LIGARIUS enter. Ligarius wears a cloth wrapped around his head, indicating that he’s sick.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LIGARIUS

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$He is a sick man that would speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Here’s a sick man who wants to speak with you.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of.—$NEWLINE$Boy, stand aside.—Caius Ligarius, how?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$It’s Caius Ligarius, whom Metellus spoke of. Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius! How are you?

paragraphs.original: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.
paragraphs.translated: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$Please accept my feeble “good morning.”

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius,$NEWLINE$To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh, what a time you’ve chosen to be sick, brave Caius! How I wish you felt better!

paragraphs.original: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$I am not sick if Brutus have in hand$NEWLINE$Any exploit worthy the name of honor.
paragraphs.translated: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$I’m not sick if you’ve prepared some honorable exploit for me.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius,$NEWLINE$Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Indeed, I would have such an exploit for you, Ligarius, if you were healthy enough to hear it.

paragraphs.original: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$(removes his kerchief)$NEWLINE$(removes his kerchief)$NEWLINE$By all the gods that Romans bow before,$NEWLINE$I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome,$NEWLINE$Brave son derived from honorable loins,$NEWLINE$Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up$NEWLINE$My mortifièd spirit. Now bid me run,$NEWLINE$And I will strive with things impossible,$NEWLINE$Yea, get the better of them. What’s to do?
paragraphs.translated: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$(takes off his head covering) By all the gods that Romans worship, I hereby throw off my sickness! Soul of Rome! Brave son of honorable ancestors! You’ve conjured up my deadened spirit like an exorcist. Now say the word, and I will tackle all kinds of impossible things, and succeed too. What is there to do?$NEWLINE$(takes off his head covering)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$A piece of work that will make sick men whole.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$A deed that will make sick men healthy.

paragraphs.original: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$But are not some whole that we must make sick?
paragraphs.translated: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$But aren’t there some healthy men whom we have to make sick?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$That must we also. What it is, my Caius,$NEWLINE$I shall unfold to thee as we are going$NEWLINE$To whom it must be done.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$That too. My dear Caius, I’ll explain the task at hand to you as we walk toward the man we must do it to.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$Set on your foot,$NEWLINE$And with a heart new-fired I follow you,$NEWLINE$To do I know not what. But it sufficeth$NEWLINE$That Brutus leads me on.
paragraphs.translated: LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$Start walking, and with an energized heart, I’ll follow you—to what, I don’t know, but I’m satisfied, simply knowing that Brutus leads me.

paragraphs.original: Thunder
paragraphs.translated: Thunder.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Follow me, then.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Follow me, then.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thunder and lightning Enter Julius CAESAR in his nightgown$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: Thunder and lightning. CAESAR enters in his nightgown.$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight.$NEWLINE$Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out,$NEWLINE$“Help, ho! They murder Caesar!”—Who’s within?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Neither the sky nor the earth have been quiet tonight. Calphurnia cried out three times in her sleep, “Help, someone! They’re murdering Caesar!” Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$My lord.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Go bid the priests do present sacrifice$NEWLINE$And bring me their opinions of success.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Go tell the priests to perform a sacrifice immediately, and bring me their interpretation of the results.

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$I will, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Enter CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$CALPHURNIA
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA enters.$NEWLINE$CALPHURNIA

paragraphs.original: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$What mean you, Caesar? Think you to walk forth?$NEWLINE$You shall not stir out of your house today.
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$What are you doing, Caesar? Are you planning to go out? You’re not leaving the house today.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Caesar shall forth. The things that threatened me$NEWLINE$Ne'er looked but on my back. When they shall see$NEWLINE$The face of Caesar, they are vanishèd.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I will go out. The things that threaten me have only seen my back. When they see the face of Caesar, they will vanish.

paragraphs.original: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies,$NEWLINE$Yet now they fright me. There is one within,$NEWLINE$Besides the things that we have heard and seen,$NEWLINE$Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.$NEWLINE$A lioness hath whelpèd in the streets,$NEWLINE$And graves have yawned and yielded up their dead.
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$Caesar, I never believed in omens, but now they frighten me. A servant told me the night-watchmen saw horrid sights too, but different ones from what we heard and saw. A lioness gave birth in the streets, and graves cracked open and thrust out their dead.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds$NEWLINE$In ranks and squadrons and right form of war,$NEWLINE$Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol.$NEWLINE$The noise of battle hurtled in the air.$NEWLINE$Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan,$NEWLINE$And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.$NEWLINE$O Caesar! These things are beyond all use,$NEWLINE$And I do fear them.
paragraphs.translated: Fierce, fiery warriors fought in the clouds in the usual formations of war—ranks and squadrons—until the clouds drizzled blood onto the Capitol. The noise of battle filled the air, and horses neighed, and dying men groaned, and ghosts shrieked and squealed in the streets. Oh, Caesar! These things are beyond anything we’ve seen before, and I’m afraid.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What can be avoided$NEWLINE$Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?$NEWLINE$Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions$NEWLINE$Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$How can we avoid what the gods want to happen? But I will go out, for these bad omens apply to the world in general as much as they do to me.

paragraphs.original: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$When beggars die there are no comets seen.$NEWLINE$The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$When beggars die there are no comets in the sky. The heavens only announce the deaths of princes.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Cowards die many times before their deaths.$NEWLINE$The valiant never taste of death but once.$NEWLINE$Of all the wonders that I yet have heard,$NEWLINE$It seems to me most strange that men should fear,$NEWLINE$Seeing that death, a necessary end,$NEWLINE$Will come when it will come.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Cowards die many times before their deaths. The brave experience death only once. Of all the strange things I’ve ever heard, it seems most strange to me that men fear death, given that death, which can’t be avoided, will come whenever it wants.

paragraphs.original: Enter SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: What say the augurers?
paragraphs.translated: What do the priests say?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$They would not have you to stir forth today.$NEWLINE$Plucking the entrails of an offering forth,$NEWLINE$They could not find a heart within the beast.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$They don’t want you to go out today. They pulled out the guts of the sacrificed animal and couldn’t find its heart.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$The gods do this in shame of cowardice.$NEWLINE$Caesar should be a beast without a heart$NEWLINE$If he should stay at home today for fear.$NEWLINE$No, Caesar shall not. Danger knows full well
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$The gods do this to test my bravery. They’re saying I’d be an animal without a heart if I stayed home today out of fear. So, I won’t.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That Caesar is more dangerous than he.$NEWLINE$We are two lions littered in one day,$NEWLINE$And I the elder and more terrible.$NEWLINE$And Caesar shall go forth.
paragraphs.translated: Danger knows that Caesar is more dangerous than he is. We’re two lions born on the same day in the same litter, and I’m the older and more terrible. I will go out.

paragraphs.original: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$Alas, my lord,$NEWLINE$Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.$NEWLINE$Do not go forth today. Call it my fear$NEWLINE$That keeps you in the house, and not your own.$NEWLINE$We’ll send Mark Antony to the senate house,$NEWLINE$And he shall say you are not well today.$NEWLINE$(kneels) Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this.$NEWLINE$(kneels)
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$Alas, my lord, your confidence is getting the better of your wisdom. Don’t go out today. Say that it’s my fear that keeps you inside and not your own. We’ll send Mark Antony to the senate house, and he’ll say that you’re sick today. (she kneels) Let me, on my knees, win you over to this plan.$NEWLINE$(she kneels)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Mark Antony shall say I am not well,$NEWLINE$And for thy humor I will stay at home.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$All right. Mark Antony will say I’m not well, and to please you I’ll stay at home.

paragraphs.original: CALPHURNIA rises$NEWLINE$CALPHURNIA
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA gets up.$NEWLINE$CALPHURNIA

paragraphs.original: Enter DECIUS$NEWLINE$DECIUS
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS enters.$NEWLINE$DECIUS

paragraphs.original: Here’s Decius Brutus. He shall tell them so.
paragraphs.translated: Here’s Decius Brutus. He’ll tell them so.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Caesar, all hail! Good morrow, worthy Caesar.$NEWLINE$I come to fetch you to the senate house.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Hail, Caesar! Good morning, worthy Caesar. I’ve come to take you to the senate house.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$And you are come in very happy time$NEWLINE$To bear my greeting to the senators$NEWLINE$And tell them that I will not come today.$NEWLINE$“Cannot” is false, and that I dare not, falser.$NEWLINE$I will not come today. Tell them so, Decius.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$And you’ve come at a good time, so you can convey my greetings to the senators and tell them I won’t come today. It wouldn’t be true to say that I can’t come, and even less true to say that I don’t dare come. I simply won’t come today. Tell them so, Decius.$NEWLINE$can’t$NEWLINE$dare$NEWLINE$won’t

paragraphs.original: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$Say he is sick.
paragraphs.translated: CALPHURNIA$NEWLINE$Say he’s sick.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Shall Caesar send a lie?$NEWLINE$Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far$NEWLINE$To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Would I send a lie? Have I accomplished so much in battle, but now I’m afraid to tell some old men the truth?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.
paragraphs.translated: Decius, go tell them that Caesar won’t come.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,$NEWLINE$Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Most mighty Caesar, give me some reason, so I won’t be laughed at when I tell them so.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$The cause is in my will. I will not come.$NEWLINE$That is enough to satisfy the senate.$NEWLINE$But for your private satisfaction,$NEWLINE$Because I love you, I will let you know.$NEWLINE$Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home.$NEWLINE$She dreamt tonight she saw my statue,$NEWLINE$Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts,$NEWLINE$Did run pure blood. And many lusty Romans$NEWLINE$Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it.$NEWLINE$And these does she apply for warnings and portents$NEWLINE$And evils imminent, and on her knee$NEWLINE$Hath begged that I will stay at home today.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$The reason is that it’s what I want. I’m not coming. That’s enough for the senate. But for your private satisfaction, because I love you, I’ll tell you. Calphurnia, my wife, is keeping me at home. Last night, she dreamed she saw a statue of me with a hundred holes in it, like a fountain with pure blood flowing from it, and many happy Romans came smiling and washed their hands in it. She takes these signs for warnings and predictions of terrible evils to come, and, on her knee, she begged me to stay home today.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$This dream is all amiss interpreted.$NEWLINE$It was a vision fair and fortunate.$NEWLINE$Your statue spouting blood in many pipes,$NEWLINE$In which so many smiling Romans bathed,$NEWLINE$Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck$NEWLINE$Reviving blood, and that great men shall press$NEWLINE$For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance.$NEWLINE$This by Calphurnia’s dream is signified.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$This dream has been interpreted all wrong. It was a good and lucky vision. Your statue spouting blood through many holes, in which many smiling Romans bathed, means that you’ll provide great Rome with sustaining blood, and that great men will strive to get some token of approval from your holy blood. This is what Calphurnia’s dream means.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$And this way have you well expounded it.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You’ve offered an excellent interpretation.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$I have, when you have heard what I can say.$NEWLINE$And know it now: the senate have concluded$NEWLINE$To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$I will have when you hear the rest of what I have to say. The senate has decided to give mighty Caesar a crown today.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If you shall send them word you will not come,$NEWLINE$Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock$NEWLINE$Apt to be rendered for someone to say,$NEWLINE$“Break up the senate till another time$NEWLINE$When Caesar’s wife shall meet with better dreams.”$NEWLINE$If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper,$NEWLINE$“Lo, Caesar is afraid”?$NEWLINE$Pardon me, Caesar. For my dear, dear love$NEWLINE$To your proceeding bids me tell you this,$NEWLINE$And reason to my love is liable.
paragraphs.translated: If you send them word that you won’t come, they might change their minds. Besides, someone’s likely to joke, “Adjourn the senate until some other time, when Caesar’s wife has had better dreams.” If you hide yourself, won’t they whisper, “Caesar is afraid?” Pardon me, Caesar. My high hopes for your advancement force me to tell you this. My love gets the better of my manners.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$How foolish do your fears seem now, Calphurnia!$NEWLINE$I am ashamèd I did yield to them.$NEWLINE$Give me my robe, for I will go.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$How foolish your fears seem now, Calphurnia! I’m ashamed that I yielded to them. Give me my robe, because I’m going.

paragraphs.original: Enter BRUTUS, LIGARIUS, METELLUS, CASCA, TREBONIUS, CINNA, and PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$METELLUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$CINNA$NEWLINE$PUBLIUS
paragraphs.translated: PUBLIUS, BRUTUS, LIGARIUS, METELLUS, CASCA, TREBONIUS, and CINNA enter.$NEWLINE$PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$LIGARIUS$NEWLINE$METELLUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$CINNA

paragraphs.original: And look, where Publius is come to fetch me.
paragraphs.translated: And look, here’s Publius, come to fetch me.

paragraphs.original: PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$Good morning, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Welcome, Publius.$NEWLINE$—What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?$NEWLINE$—Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,$NEWLINE$Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy$NEWLINE$As that same ague which hath made you lean.$NEWLINE$—What is ’t o'clock?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Welcome, Publius. What, Brutus? Are you up this early too? Good morning, Casca. Caius Ligarius, I was never your enemy so much as the sickness that’s made you so thin. What time is it?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Caesar, ’tis strucken eight.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Caesar, the clock has struck eight.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I thank you all for your trouble and courtesy.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: See, Antony, that revels long a-nights,$NEWLINE$Is notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony.
paragraphs.translated: See! Even Antony, who stays up all night partying, is awake. Good morning, Antony.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$So to most noble Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$And to you, most noble Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Bid them prepare within.$NEWLINE$I am to blame to be thus waited for.$NEWLINE$—Now, Cinna.—Now, Metellus.—What, Trebonius,$NEWLINE$I have an hour’s talk in store for you.$NEWLINE$Remember that you call on me today.$NEWLINE$Be near me, that I may remember you.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Tell them to prepare the other room for guests. I’m to blame for making you wait for me. Now, Cinna. Now, Metellus. Trebonius! I have an hour-long matter to discuss with you. Remember to see me today. Stay near me so I’ll remember.

paragraphs.original: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$Caesar, I will. (aside) And so near will I be$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$That your best friends shall wish I had been further.
paragraphs.translated: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$Caesar, I will. (speaking quietly to himself) In fact, I’ll be so near that your best friends will wish I’d been further away.$NEWLINE$(speaking quietly to himself)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Good friends, go in and taste some wine with me.$NEWLINE$And we, like friends, will straightway go together.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Good friends, go in and have some wine with me. And we’ll leave together, like friends.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(aside) That every “like” is not the same, O Caesar,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$The heart of Brutus earns to think upon.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(quietly to himself) That we are now only “like” friends—Oh Caesar—makes my heart ache.$NEWLINE$(quietly to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ARTEMIDORUS, reading a letter$NEWLINE$ARTEMIDORUS
paragraphs.translated: ARTEMIDORUS enters, reading a letter.$NEWLINE$ARTEMIDORUS

paragraphs.original: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$(reads aloud)$NEWLINE$(reads aloud)$NEWLINE$“Caesar, beware of Brutus. Take heed of Cassius. Come not near Casca. Have an eye to Cinna. Trust not Trebonius. Mark well Metellus Cimber. Decius Brutus loves thee not. Thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius. There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar. If thou beest not immortal, look about you. Security gives way to conspiracy. The mighty gods defend thee!$NEWLINE$Thy lover,$NEWLINE$Artemidorus”$NEWLINE$Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,$NEWLINE$And as a suitor will I give him this.$NEWLINE$My heart laments that virtue cannot live$NEWLINE$Out of the teeth of emulation.$NEWLINE$If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live.$NEWLINE$If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.
paragraphs.translated: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$(reading aloud from the letter)$NEWLINE$(reading aloud from the letter)$NEWLINE$“Caesar, beware of Brutus. Watch Cassius. Don’t go near Casca. Keep an eye on Cinna. Don’t trust Trebonius. Pay attention to Metellus Cimber. Decius Brutus doesn’t love you. You’ve wronged Caius Ligarius. These men all have one intention, and it’s directed against Caesar. If you aren’t immortal, watch those around you. A sense of security opens the door to conspiracy. I pray that the mighty gods defend you!$NEWLINE$Your friend,$NEWLINE$Artemidorus.”$NEWLINE$I’ll stand here until Caesar passes by, and I’ll give him this as though it’s a petition. My heart regrets that good men aren’t safe from the bite of jealous rivals. If you read this, Caesar, you might live. If not, the Fates are on the side of the traitors.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PORTIA and LUCIUS$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA and LUCIUS enter.$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I prithee, boy, run to the senate house.$NEWLINE$Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone.$NEWLINE$Why dost thou stay?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Boy, I beg you to run to the senate house. Don’t stay to answer me—get going. Why are you still standing there?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$To know my errand, madam.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$To find out what you want me to do there, madam.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I would have had thee there and here again$NEWLINE$Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.$NEWLINE$—O constancy, be strong upon my side,$NEWLINE$Set a huge mountain ’tween my heart and tongue!$NEWLINE$I have a man’s mind but a woman’s might.$NEWLINE$How hard it is for women to keep counsel!$NEWLINE$—Art thou here yet?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I want you there and back again before I can even tell you what you should do there. (to herself, so that no one can hear her) Oh, let my determination keep me from speaking what is in my heart! I have a man’s mind, but only a woman’s strength. How hard it is for women to keep secrets! (to LUCIUS) Are you still here?$NEWLINE$(to herself, so that no one can hear her)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Madam, what should I do?$NEWLINE$Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?$NEWLINE$And so return to you, and nothing else?
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Madam, what should I do? Run to the Capitol and nothing else? And then return to you and nothing else?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well,$NEWLINE$For he went sickly forth. And take good note$NEWLINE$What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.$NEWLINE$Hark, boy! What noise is that?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes, return and tell me if your master looks well, because he was sick when he left. And pay attention to what Caesar does and which men are close to him. Listen, boy! What’s that noise?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I hear none, madam.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I don’t hear anything, madam.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Prithee, listen well.$NEWLINE$I heard a bustling rumor like a fray,$NEWLINE$And the wind brings it from the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I beg you, listen well. I heard a noise like a scuffle. The wind brings it from the Capitol.

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Truly, madam, I don’t hear anything.

paragraphs.original: Enter the SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: The SOOTHSAYER enters.$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Come hither, fellow. Which way hast thou been?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Come here, you. Where are you coming from?

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$At mine own house, good lady.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$My own house, good lady.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What is ’t o'clock?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What time is it?

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$About the ninth hour, lady.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Around nine o'clock, madam.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Has Caesar gone to the Capital yet?

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Madam, not yet. I go to take my stand$NEWLINE$To see him pass on to the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Madam, not yet. I’m going to stand so I can see him pass on the way to the Capitol.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You have some plea for Caesar, don’t you?

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$That I have, lady. If it will please Caesar$NEWLINE$To be so good to Caesar as to hear me,$NEWLINE$I shall beseech him to befriend himself.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Yes, I do, lady. If it pleases Caesar to be so good to himself as to hear me, I’ll try to get him to do what’s good for him.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Why, know’st thou any harm’s intended towards him?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Why, do you know of any harm intended toward him?

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$None that I know will be; much that I fear may chance.$NEWLINE$Good morrow to you. Here the street is narrow.$NEWLINE$The throng that follows Caesar at the heels,$NEWLINE$Of senators, of praetors, common suitors,$NEWLINE$Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.$NEWLINE$I’ll get me to a place more void, and there$NEWLINE$Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Nothing that I know for sure, but a lot that I’m afraid might happen. Good morning to you. The street is narrow here. The crowd that follows Caesar at his heels—senators, justices, common petitioners—will suffocate a feeble man almost to death. I’ll move to a more open place and there speak to great Caesar as he walks past.

paragraphs.original: Exit SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I must go in. (aside) Ay me, how weak a thing$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$The heart of woman is! O Brutus,$NEWLINE$The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise!$NEWLINE$Sure, the boy heard me. (to LUCIUS) Brutus hath a suit$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That Caesar will not grant.—Oh, I grow faint.—$NEWLINE$Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord.$NEWLINE$Say I am merry. Come to me again,$NEWLINE$And bring me word what he doth say to thee.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I must go in. (speaking quietly to herself) Oh, a woman’s heart is so weak! Oh Brutus, may the gods aid you in your endeavor! Surely, the boy heard me. (to LUCIUS) Brutus has a claim that Caesar won’t grant. Oh, I feel faint. Run, Lucius, and speak well of me to my lord. Say that I’m happy. Then return to me and tell me what he says to you.$NEWLINE$(speaking quietly to herself)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish Enter CAESAR, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS, METELLUS, TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, PUBLIUS, and POPILLIUS LENA with a crowd of people, including ARTEMIDORUS and the SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$DECIUS$NEWLINE$METELLUS$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$CINNA$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$POPILLIUS LENA$NEWLINE$ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: A crowd of people enters, among them ARTEMIDORUS and the SOOTHSAYER. A trumpet plays. CAESAR, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS, METELLUS, TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, POPILLIUS, PUBLIUS, and others enter.$NEWLINE$ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$DECIUS$NEWLINE$METELLUS$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$CINNA$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$POPILLIUS$NEWLINE$PUBLIUS

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(to the SOOTHSAYER) The ides of March are come.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(to the SOOTHSAYER) March 15th has come.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Ay, Caesar, but not gone.
paragraphs.translated: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Yes, Caesar, but it’s not gone yet.

paragraphs.original: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$(offering his letter) Hail, Caesar! Read this schedule.$NEWLINE$(offering his letter)
paragraphs.translated: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$(offering his letter) Hail, Caesar! Read this schedule.$NEWLINE$(offering his letter)

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$(offering CAESAR another paper)$NEWLINE$(offering$NEWLINE$another paper)$NEWLINE$Trebonius doth desire you to o'er-read,$NEWLINE$At your best leisure, this his humble suit.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$(offering CAESAR another paper) Trebonius wants you to look over his humble petition, at your leisure.$NEWLINE$(offering$NEWLINE$another paper)

paragraphs.original: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$O Caesar, read mine first, for mine’s a suit$NEWLINE$That touches Caesar nearer. Read it, great Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Caesar, read mine first, for my petition affects you more directly. Read it, great Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What touches us ourself shall be last served.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Whatever pertains to myself I will deal with last.

paragraphs.original: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$Delay not, Caesar. Read it instantly.
paragraphs.translated: ARTEMIDORUS$NEWLINE$Don’t delay, Caesar. Read it instantly.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What, is the fellow mad?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What, is the man insane?

paragraphs.original: PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$(to ARTEMIDORUS)    Sirrah, give place.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$(to ARTEMIDORUS) Stand aside, you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(to ARTEMIDORUS)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$What, urge you your petitions in the street?$NEWLINE$Come to the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(to ARTEMIDORUS) What? Are you pressing your petition on the street? Go to the Capitol.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR’s party moves aside to the senate house$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR goes up to the senate house, the rest following.$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: POPILLIUS$NEWLINE$(to CASSIUS) I wish your enterprise today may thrive.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: POPILLIUS$NEWLINE$(to CASSIUS) I hope your endeavor goes well today.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What enterprise, Popillius?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What endeavor, Popillius?

paragraphs.original: POPILLIUS$NEWLINE$Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: POPILLIUS$NEWLINE$Good luck.

paragraphs.original: (approaches CAESAR)$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: POPILLIUS approaches CAESAR.$NEWLINE$POPILLIUS$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(to CASSIUS) What said Popillius Lena?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(to CASSIUS) What did Popillius Lena say?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(aside to BRUTUS)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$He wished today our enterprise might thrive.$NEWLINE$I fear our purpose is discoverèd.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only BRUTUS can hear) He wished that our endeavor would go well today. I’m afraid we’ve been found out.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Look how he makes to Caesar. Mark him.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Look, he’s approaching Caesar. Keep an eye on him.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention$NEWLINE$—Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,$NEWLINE$Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,$NEWLINE$For I will slay myself.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Casca, be quick, because we’re worried we might be stopped. Brutus, what will we do? If our secret’s known, either Caesar or I will die, for I’ll kill myself.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Cassius, be constant.$NEWLINE$Popillius Lena speaks not of our purposes.$NEWLINE$For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Cassius, stand firm. Popillius Lena wasn’t talking about our plot—for, look, he’s smiling, and Caesar’s expression is the same.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Trebonius knows his time. For, look you, Brutus.$NEWLINE$He draws Mark Antony out of the way.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Trebonius knows his cue. See, Brutus, he’s pulling Mark Antony aside.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt TREBONIUS and ANTONY$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: TREBONIUS and ANTONY exit.$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go$NEWLINE$And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Where’s Metellus Cimber? He should go up and offer his petition to Caesar now.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He is addressed. Press near and second him.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$They’re speaking to him. Go up there and second his petition.

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$Casca, you’ll be the first to raise your hand.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Are we all ready? What is now amiss$NEWLINE$That Caesar and his senate must redress?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Are we all ready? What problem should I discuss with you first?

paragraphs.original: METELLUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling)$NEWLINE$(kneeling)$NEWLINE$Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar,$NEWLINE$Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat$NEWLINE$An humble heart—
paragraphs.translated: METELLUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Most high, most mighty, and most powerful Caesar, Metellus Cimber kneels before you with a humble heart—$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I must prevent thee, Cimber.$NEWLINE$These couchings and these lowly courtesies$NEWLINE$Might fire the blood of ordinary men$NEWLINE$And turn preordinance and first decree$NEWLINE$Into the law of children. Be not fond,$NEWLINE$To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood$NEWLINE$That will be thawed from the true quality$NEWLINE$With that which melteth fools—I mean, sweet words,$NEWLINE$Low-crookèd curtsies, and base spaniel fawning.$NEWLINE$Thy brother by decree is banishèd.$NEWLINE$If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him,$NEWLINE$I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.$NEWLINE$Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause$NEWLINE$Will he be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I have to stop you, Cimber. These kneelings and humble courtesies might excite ordinary men, flattering them into turning Roman law into children’s games. But don’t be so foolish as to think you can sway me from what’s right by using the tactics that persuade fools—I mean this flattery, low bows, and puppy-like fawning. Your brother has been banished by decree. If you kneel and beg and flatter for him, I’ll kick you out of my way like I would a dog. Know that I am not unjust, and I will not grant him a pardon without reason.$NEWLINE$me

paragraphs.original: METELLUS$NEWLINE$Is there no voice more worthy than my own$NEWLINE$To sound more sweetly in great Caesar’s ear$NEWLINE$For the repealing of my banished brother?
paragraphs.translated: METELLUS$NEWLINE$Is there no voice worthier than my own to appeal to Caesar to repeal the order that my brother be banished?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling) I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar,$NEWLINE$(kneeling)$NEWLINE$Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may$NEWLINE$Have an immediate freedom of repeal.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling) I kiss your hand, but not in flattery, Caesar. I ask you to repeal Publius Cimber’s banishment immediately.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What, Brutus?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What, even you, Brutus?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling)   Pardon, Caesar. Caesar, pardon.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)$NEWLINE$As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall$NEWLINE$To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Pardon him, Caesar, pardon him. I fall to your feet to beg you to restore Publius Cimber to citizenship.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I could be well moved if I were as you.$NEWLINE$If I could pray to move, prayers would move me.$NEWLINE$But I am constant as the northern star,$NEWLINE$Of whose true-fixed and resting quality$NEWLINE$There is no fellow in the firmament.$NEWLINE$The skies are painted with unnumbered sparks.$NEWLINE$They are all fire and every one doth shine,$NEWLINE$But there’s but one in all doth hold his place.$NEWLINE$So in the world. 'Tis furnished well with men,$NEWLINE$And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive,$NEWLINE$Yet in the number I do know but one$NEWLINE$That unassailable holds on his rank,$NEWLINE$Unshaked of motion. And that I am he$NEWLINE$Let me a little show it even in this:$NEWLINE$That I was constant Cimber should be banished,$NEWLINE$And constant do remain to keep him so.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I could be convinced if I were like you. If I could beg others to change their minds, begging would convince me, too. But I’m as immovable as the northern star, whose stable and stationary quality has no equal in the sky. The sky shows countless stars. They’re all made of fire, and each one shines. But only one among all of them remains in a fixed position. So it is on earth. The world is full of men, and men are flesh and blood, and they are capable of reason. Yet out of all of them, I know only one who is unassailable, who never moves from his position. To show you that that’s me, let me prove it a little even in this case. I was firm in ordering that Cimber be banished, and I remain firm in that decision.

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$(kneeling) O Caesar—$NEWLINE$(kneeling)
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Oh, Caesar—$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Hence! Wilt thou lift up Olympus?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Enough! Would you try to lift Mount Olympus?

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Great Caesar—$NEWLINE$(kneeling)
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Great Caesar—$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Haven’t I resisted even Brutus, begging from his knees?

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Speak, hands, for me!
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Hands, speak for me!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASCA and the other conspirators stab CAESAR, BRUTUS last$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated: CASCA and the other conspirators stab CAESAR. BRUTUS stabs him last.$NEWLINE$CASCA$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$BRUTUS

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Et tu, Bruté?—Then fall, Caesar.$NEWLINE$Et tu, Bruté?$NEWLINE$(dies)$NEWLINE$(dies)
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$And you too, Brutus? In that case, die, Caesar.$NEWLINE$(he dies)$NEWLINE$(he dies)

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!$NEWLINE$Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead! Run and proclaim it in the streets.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Some to the common pulpits, and cry out,$NEWLINE$“Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!”
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Some should go to the public platforms and cry out, “Liberty, freedom, and democracy!”

paragraphs.original: Confusion. Exeunt some plebians and senators
paragraphs.translated: Confusion. Some citizens and senators exit.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$People and senators, be not affrighted.$NEWLINE$Fly not. Stand still. Ambition’s debt is paid.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$People and senators, don’t be afraid. Don’t run away—stay where you are. Only Caesar had to die for his ambition.

paragraphs.original: CASCA$NEWLINE$Go to the pulpit, Brutus.
paragraphs.translated: CASCA$NEWLINE$Go to the platform, Brutus.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$And Cassius too.
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$And Cassius too.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Where’s Publius?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Where’s Publius?

paragraphs.original: CINNA$NEWLINE$Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA$NEWLINE$Here. He’s completely stunned by this mutiny.

paragraphs.original: METELLUS$NEWLINE$Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar’s$NEWLINE$Should chance—
paragraphs.translated: METELLUS$NEWLINE$Stand close together, in case someone loyal to Caesar tries to—

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Talk not of standing.—Publius, good cheer.$NEWLINE$There is no harm intended to your person,$NEWLINE$Nor to no Roman else. So tell them, Publius.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Don’t talk about standing together.—Publius, cheer up. We don’t intend any harm to you, nor to anyone else. Tell them this, Publius.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And leave us, Publius, lest that the people,$NEWLINE$Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And leave us, Publius, in case the people storming us should harm you.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Do so. And let no man abide this deed$NEWLINE$But we the doers.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Do so. And let no one suffer for this deed except us, the perpetrators.

paragraphs.original: Exit PUBLIUS$NEWLINE$PUBLIUS
paragraphs.translated: PUBLIUS exits.$NEWLINE$PUBLIUS

paragraphs.original: Enter TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS
paragraphs.translated: TREBONIUS enters.$NEWLINE$TREBONIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Where is Antony?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Where’s Antony?

paragraphs.original: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$Fled to his house amazed.$NEWLINE$Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run$NEWLINE$As it were doomsday.
paragraphs.translated: TREBONIUS$NEWLINE$He ran to his house, stunned. Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run in the streets as though it were doomsday.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Fates, we will know your pleasures.$NEWLINE$That we shall die, we know. 'Tis but the time,$NEWLINE$And drawing days out, that men stand upon.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$We’ll soon find out what fate has in store for us. All we know is that we’ll die sometime, which is all anyone ever knows, though we try to draw out our days for as long as possible.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life$NEWLINE$Cuts off so many years of fearing death.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Why, the man who shortens his life by twenty years cuts off twenty years of worrying about death.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Grant that, and then is death a benefit.$NEWLINE$So are we Caesar’s friends, that have abridged$NEWLINE$His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop,$NEWLINE$And let us bathe our hands in Caesar’s blood$NEWLINE$Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords.$NEWLINE$Then walk we forth, even to the marketplace,$NEWLINE$And waving our red weapons o'er our heads$NEWLINE$Let’s all cry, “Peace, freedom, and liberty!”
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$So, then, death is a gift, and we are Caesar’s friends, for we’ve done him a service by shortening his time spent fearing death. Kneel, Romans, kneel, and let’s wash our hands, up to the elbows, in Caesar’s blood and smear it on our swords. Then we’ll go out, even to the marketplace, and, waving our bloody swords over our heads, let’s cry, “Peace, freedom, and liberty!”

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Stoop, then, and wash.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Kneel then, and wash.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The conspirators smear their hands and swords with CAESAR’s blood$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: The conspirators smear their hands and swords with CAESAR’s blood.$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: How many ages hence$NEWLINE$Shall this our lofty scene be acted over$NEWLINE$In states unborn and accents yet unknown!
paragraphs.translated: How many years from now will this heroic scene be reenacted in countries that don’t even exist yet and in languages not yet known!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport,$NEWLINE$That now on Pompey’s basis lies along$NEWLINE$No worthier than the dust!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$How many times will Caesar bleed again in show, though he now lies at the base of Pompey’s statue, as worthless as dust!

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$So oft as that shall be,$NEWLINE$So often shall the knot of us be called$NEWLINE$“The men that gave their country liberty.”
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$As often as it’s replayed, our group will be hailed as the men who gave their country liberty.

paragraphs.original: DECIUS$NEWLINE$What, shall we forth?
paragraphs.translated: DECIUS$NEWLINE$Well, should we go out?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Ay, every man away.$NEWLINE$Brutus shall lead, and we will grace his heels$NEWLINE$With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Yes, every man forward. Brutus will lead, and we’ll follow him with the boldest and best hearts of Rome.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$ANTONY'S SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY'S SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONY'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Soft! Who comes here? A friend of Antony’s.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Wait a minute. Who’s that coming? It’s a friend of Antony’s.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)$NEWLINE$(falls prostrate) Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down,$NEWLINE$(falls prostrate)$NEWLINE$And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say:$NEWLINE$Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest.$NEWLINE$Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving.$NEWLINE$Say I love Brutus, and I honor him.$NEWLINE$Say I feared Caesar, honored him, and loved him.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$(kneeling) Brutus, my master ordered me to kneel like this. (he kneels, head bowed low) He ordered me to kneel low, and, from the ground, like this, he ordered me to say: “Brutus is noble, wise, brave, and honest. Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving. Antony loves Brutus and honors him. Antony feared Caesar, honored him, and loved him.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)$NEWLINE$(he kneels, head bowed low)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony$NEWLINE$May safely come to him and be resolved$NEWLINE$How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death,$NEWLINE$Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead$NEWLINE$So well as Brutus living, but will follow$NEWLINE$The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus$NEWLINE$Thorough the hazards of this untrod state$NEWLINE$With all true faith. So says my master Antony.
paragraphs.translated: If Brutus will swear that Antony may come to him safely and be convinced that Caesar deserved to be killed, Mark Antony will love dead Caesar not nearly as much as living Brutus, and with true faith he’ll follow the destiny and affairs of noble Brutus through the difficulties of this unprecedented state of affairs.” That’s what my master, Antony, says.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman.$NEWLINE$I never thought him worse.$NEWLINE$Tell him, so please him come unto this place,$NEWLINE$He shall be satisfied and, by my honor,$NEWLINE$Depart untouched.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Your master is a wise and honorable Roman. I never thought any less of him. Tell him, if he comes here, I’ll explain everything to him and, on my word, he’ll leave unharmed.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$(rising)    I’ll fetch him presently.$NEWLINE$(rising)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$(getting up) I’ll get him now.$NEWLINE$(getting up)

paragraphs.original: Exit ANTONY'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$ANTONY'S SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY'S SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$ANTONY'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I know that we shall have him well to friend.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I know that he’ll be on our side.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I wish we may. But yet have I a mind$NEWLINE$That fears him much, and my misgiving still$NEWLINE$Falls shrewdly to the purpose.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I hope we can count on him, but I still fear him, and my hunches are usually accurate.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$But here comes Antony.—Welcome, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$But here comes Antony.—Welcome, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$O mighty Caesar! Dost thou lie so low?$NEWLINE$Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils,$NEWLINE$Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.$NEWLINE$—I know not, gentlemen, what you intend,$NEWLINE$Who else must be let blood, who else is rank.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Oh, mighty Caesar! Do you lie so low? Have all your conquests, glories, triumphs, achievements, come to so little? Farewell. Gentlemen, I don’t know what you intend to do, who else you intend to kill, who else you consider corrupt.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If I myself, there is no hour so fit$NEWLINE$As Caesar’s death’s hour, nor no instrument$NEWLINE$Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich$NEWLINE$With the most noble blood of all this world.$NEWLINE$I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard,$NEWLINE$Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke,$NEWLINE$Fulfill your pleasure. Live a thousand years,$NEWLINE$I shall not find myself so apt to die.$NEWLINE$No place will please me so, no mean of death,$NEWLINE$As here by Caesar, and by you cut off,$NEWLINE$The choice and master spirits of this age.
paragraphs.translated: If it’s me, there’s no time as good as this hour of Caesar’s death, and no weapon better than your swords, covered with the noblest blood in the world. I ask you, if you have a grudge against me, to kill me now, while your stained hands still reek of blood. I could live a thousand years and I wouldn’t be as ready to die as I am now. There’s no place I’d rather die than here by Caesar, and no manner of death would please me more than being stabbed by you, the masters of this new era.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$O Antony, beg not your death of us.$NEWLINE$Though now we must appear bloody and cruel—$NEWLINE$As by our hands and this our present act$NEWLINE$You see we do—yet see you but our hands$NEWLINE$And this the bleeding business they have done.$NEWLINE$Our hearts you see not. They are pitiful.$NEWLINE$And pity to the general wrong of Rome—$NEWLINE$As fire drives out fire, so pity pity—$NEWLINE$Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part,$NEWLINE$To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony.$NEWLINE$Our arms in strength of malice and our hearts$NEWLINE$Of brothers' temper do receive you in$NEWLINE$With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Antony, don’t beg us to kill you. Though we seem bloody and cruel right now, with our bloody hands and this deed we’ve done, you’ve only seen our hands and their bloody business; you haven’t looked into our hearts. They are full of pity for Caesar. But a stronger pity, for the wrongs committed against Rome, drove out our pity for Caesar, as fire drives out fire, and so we killed him. For you, our swords have blunt edges, too dull to harm you, Mark Antony. Our arms, which can be strong and cruel, and our hearts, filled with brotherly love, embrace you with kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Your voice shall be as strong as any man’s$NEWLINE$In the disposing of new dignities.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Your vote will be as strong as anyone’s in the reordering of the government.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Only be patient till we have appeased$NEWLINE$The multitude, beside themselves with fear,$NEWLINE$And then we will deliver you the cause,$NEWLINE$Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him,$NEWLINE$Have thus proceeded.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$But just be patient until we’ve calmed the masses, who are beside themselves with fear. Then we’ll explain to you why I, who loved Caesar even while I stabbed him, have taken this course of action.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT
