paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I doubt not of your wisdom.$NEWLINE$Let each man render me his bloody hand.$NEWLINE$(shakes hands with the conspirators)$NEWLINE$(shakes hands with the conspirators)$NEWLINE$First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you.$NEWLINE$—Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand.$NEWLINE$—Now, Decius Brutus, yours.—Now yours, Metellus.$NEWLINE$—Yours, Cinna.—And, my valiant Casca, yours.$NEWLINE$—Though last, not last in love, yours, good Trebonius.$NEWLINE$—Gentlemen all, alas, what shall I say?$NEWLINE$My credit now stands on such slippery ground$NEWLINE$That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,$NEWLINE$Either a coward or a flatterer$NEWLINE$—That I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true.$NEWLINE$If then thy spirit look upon us now,$NEWLINE$Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death$NEWLINE$To see thy Antony making his peace,$NEWLINE$Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes—$NEWLINE$Most noble!—in the presence of thy corse?$NEWLINE$Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,$NEWLINE$Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,$NEWLINE$It would become me better than to close$NEWLINE$In terms of friendship with thine enemies.$NEWLINE$Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave hart;$NEWLINE$Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand,$NEWLINE$Signed in thy spoil, and crimsoned in thy lethe.$NEWLINE$O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,$NEWLINE$And this indeed, O world, the heart of thee.$NEWLINE$How like a deer, strucken by many princes,$NEWLINE$Dost thou here lie!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I don’t doubt your wisdom. Each of you, give me your bloody hand. (he shakes hands with the conspirators) First, Marcus Brutus, I shake your hand. Next, Caius Cassius, I take your hand. Now, Decius Brutus, yours. Now yours, Metellus. Yours, Cinna. And yours, my brave Casca. Last but not least, yours, good Trebonius. You are all gentlemen—alas, what can I say? Now that I’ve shaken your hands, you’ll take me for either a coward or a flatterer—in either case, my credibility stands on slippery ground. It’s true that I loved you, Caesar—nothing could be truer. If your spirit is looking down upon us now, it must hurt you more than even your death to see your Antony making peace—shaking the bloody hands of your enemies—in front of your corpse. If I had as many eyes as you have wounds, and they wept as fast as your wounds stream blood—even that would be more becoming than joining your enemies in friendship. Forgive me, Julius! On this very spot you were hunted down, like a brave deer. And here you fell, where your hunters are now standing. The spot is marked by your death and stained by your blood. Oh world, you were the forest to this deer, and this deer, oh world, was your dear. Now you lie here, stabbed by many princes!$NEWLINE$(he shakes hands with the conspirators)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony—
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony—

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Pardon me, Caius Cassius.$NEWLINE$The enemies of Caesar shall say this;$NEWLINE$Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Pardon me, Caius Cassius. Even Caesar’s enemies would say the same. From a friend, it’s a cool assessment—no more than that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I blame you not for praising Caesar so.$NEWLINE$But what compact mean you to have with us?$NEWLINE$Will you be pricked in number of our friends?$NEWLINE$Or shall we on, and not depend on you?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I don’t blame you for praising Caesar like this, but what agreement do you intend to reach with us? Will you be counted as our friend, or should we proceed without depending on you?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed$NEWLINE$Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar.$NEWLINE$Friends am I with you all and love you all$NEWLINE$Upon this hope: that you shall give me reasons$NEWLINE$Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I took your hands in friendship, but, indeed, I was distracted when I looked down at Caesar. I am friends with you all and love you all, on one condition—that you prove to me that Caesar was dangerous.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Or else were this a savage spectacle!$NEWLINE$Our reasons are so full of good regard$NEWLINE$That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,$NEWLINE$You should be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Without that proof, this would’ve been a savage action! Our reasons are so well considered that even if you, Antony, were Caesar’s son, you would be satisfied with them.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$That’s all I seek.$NEWLINE$And am moreover suitor that I may$NEWLINE$Produce his body to the marketplace,$NEWLINE$And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,$NEWLINE$Speak in the order of his funeral.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$That’s all I ask—and that you let me carry his body to the marketplace and, as a friend ought to do, stand on the platform and give a proper funeral oration.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You shall, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You may, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, a word with you.$NEWLINE$(aside to BRUTUS) You know not what you do.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Do not consent$NEWLINE$That Antony speak in his funeral.$NEWLINE$Know you how much the people may be moved$NEWLINE$By that which he will utter?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, may I have a word with you? (speaking so that only BRUTUS can hear) You don’t know what you’re doing. Don’t let Antony speak at his funeral. Don’t you know how much the people could be affected by what he says?$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(aside to CASSIUS)    By your pardon.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I will myself into the pulpit first,$NEWLINE$And show the reason of our Caesar’s death.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only CASSIUS can hear) With your permission, I’ll stand on the platform first and explain the reason for Caesar’s death.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What Antony shall speak, I will protest,$NEWLINE$He speaks by leave and by permission,$NEWLINE$And that we are contented Caesar shall$NEWLINE$Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.$NEWLINE$It shall advantage more than do us wrong.
paragraphs.translated: What Antony says, I’ll announce, he says only by our permission and by our conviction that Caesar should be honored with all the usual and lawful ceremonies. It’ll help us more than hurt us.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(aside to BRUTUS) I know not what may fall. I like it not.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only BRUTUS can hear) I’m worried about the outcome of his speech. I don’t like this plan.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar’s body.$NEWLINE$You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,$NEWLINE$But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,$NEWLINE$And say you do ’t by our permission.$NEWLINE$Else shall you not have any hand at all$NEWLINE$About his funeral. And you shall speak$NEWLINE$In the same pulpit whereto I am going,$NEWLINE$After my speech is ended.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony, take Caesar’s body. You will not blame us in your funeral speech, but will say all the good you want to about Caesar and that you do it by our permission. Otherwise, you’ll have no role at all in his funeral. And you’ll speak on the same platform as I do, after I’m done.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Be it so.$NEWLINE$I do desire no more.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$So be it. I don’t want anything more.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Prepare the body then, and follow us.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Prepare the body, then, and follow us.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt. Manet ANTONY$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except ANTONY exits.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth,$NEWLINE$That I am meek and gentle with these butchers!$NEWLINE$Thou art the ruins of the noblest man$NEWLINE$That ever livèd in the tide of times.$NEWLINE$Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!$NEWLINE$Over thy wounds now do I prophesy—$NEWLINE$Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips$NEWLINE$To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue—$NEWLINE$A curse shall light upon the limbs of men.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Oh, pardon me, you bleeding corpse, for speaking politely and acting mildly with these butchers! You are what’s left of the noblest man that ever lived. Pity the hand that shed this valuable blood. Over your wounds—which, like speechless mouths, open their red lips, as though to beg me to speak—I predict that a curse will fall upon the bodies of men.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Domestic fury and fierce civil strife$NEWLINE$Shall cumber all the parts of Italy.$NEWLINE$Blood and destruction shall be so in use,$NEWLINE$And dreadful objects so familiar,$NEWLINE$That mothers shall but smile when they behold$NEWLINE$Their infants quartered with the hands of war,$NEWLINE$All pity choked with custom of fell deeds,$NEWLINE$And Caesar’s spirit, ranging for revenge,$NEWLINE$With Ate by his side come hot from hell,$NEWLINE$Shall in these confines with a monarch’s voice$NEWLINE$Cry “Havoc!” and let slip the dogs of war,$NEWLINE$That this foul deed shall smell above the earth$NEWLINE$With carrion men, groaning for burial.
paragraphs.translated:
Fierce civil war will paralyze all of Italy. Blood and destruction will be so common and familiar that mothers will merely smile when their infants are cut to pieces by the hands of war. People’s capacity for sympathy will grow tired and weak from the sheer quantity of cruel deeds. And Caesar’s ghost, searching for revenge with the goddess
Ate by his side, just up from Hell, will cry in the voice of a king, “Havoc!” and unleash the dogs of war. This foul deed will stink up to the sky with men’s corpses, which will beg to be buried.$NEWLINE$Ate$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original: You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?
paragraphs.translated: You serve Octavius Caesar, right?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$I do, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$I do, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Caesar wrote for him to come to Rome.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$He did receive his letters and is coming.$NEWLINE$And bid me say to you by word of mouth—$NEWLINE$(sees CAESAR’s body) O Caesar!—$NEWLINE$(sees$NEWLINE$’s body)
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$He received Caesar’s letters, and he is coming. He told me to say to you—(seeing CAESAR's body) Oh, Caesar!—$NEWLINE$(seeing$NEWLINE$s$NEWLINE$body)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep.$NEWLINE$Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes,$NEWLINE$Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,$NEWLINE$Began to water. Is thy master coming?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Your heart is big; go ahead and weep. Grief seems to be contagious, for my eyes, seeing the tears in yours, began to fill. Is your master coming?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$He rests tonight within twenty-one miles of Rome.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced.$NEWLINE$Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,$NEWLINE$No Rome of safety for Octavius yet.$NEWLINE$Hie hence, and tell him so.—Yet, stay awhile.$NEWLINE$Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse$NEWLINE$Into the marketplace. There shall I try,$NEWLINE$In my oration, how the people take$NEWLINE$The cruèl issue of these bloody men.$NEWLINE$According to the which, thou shalt discourse$NEWLINE$To young Octavius of the state of things.$NEWLINE$Lend me your hand.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Report back to him fast and tell him what has happened. This is now a Rome in mourning, a dangerous Rome. It’s not safe enough for Octavius yet. Hurry away and tell him so. No, wait, stay a minute. Don’t go back until I’ve carried the corpse into the marketplace. There I’ll use my speech to test what the people think of these bloody men’s cruel action. You’ll report back to young Octavius how they respond. Help me here.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt with CAESAR’s body$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: They exit with CAESAR’s body.$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS with the PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS and CASSIUS enter with a throng of
PLEBEIANS .$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$We will be satisfied! Let us be satisfied!
paragraphs.translated: PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$We want answers. Give us answers.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Then follow me and give me audience, friends.$NEWLINE$—Cassius, go you into the other street$NEWLINE$And part the numbers.$NEWLINE$—Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here.$NEWLINE$Those that will follow Cassius, go with him,$NEWLINE$And public reasons shall be renderèd$NEWLINE$Of Caesar’s death.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Then follow me and listen to my speech, friends. Cassius, go to the next street and divide the crowd. Let those who will hear me speak stay. Lead those away who will follow you, and we’ll explain publicly the reasons for Caesar’s death.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$I will hear Brutus speak.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll listen to Brutus.

paragraphs.original: ANOTHER PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$I will hear Cassius and compare their reasons$NEWLINE$When severally we hear them renderèd.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll listen to Cassius, and we will compare their reasons.

paragraphs.original: Exit CASSIUS with some of the PLEBEIANS BRUTUS goes into the pulpit$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS exits with some of the PLEBEIANS. BRUTUS gets up on the platform.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$The noble Brutus is ascended. Silence!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Quiet! Noble Brutus has mounted the platform.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Be patient till the last. Romans, countrymen, and lovers! Hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear. Believe me for mine honor, and have respect to mine honor that you may believe. Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses that you may the better judge. If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his. If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Be patient until I finish. Romans, countrymen, and friends! Listen to my reasons and be silent so you can hear. Believe me on my honor and keep my honor in mind, so you may believe me. Be wise when you criticize me and keep your minds alert so you can judge me fairly. If there’s anyone in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, I say to him that my love for Caesar was no less than his. If, then, that friend demands to know why I rose up against Caesar, this is my answer: it’s not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him. As he was fortunate, I rejoice at it. As he was valiant, I honor him. But, as he was ambitious, I slew him. There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, and death for his ambition. Who is here so base that would be a bondman? If any, speak—for him have I offended. Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If any, speak—for him have I offended. Who is here so vile that will not love his country? If any, speak—for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.
paragraphs.translated: Would you rather that Caesar were living and we would all go to our graves as slaves, or that Caesar were dead and we all lived as free men? I weep for Caesar in that he was good to me. I rejoice in his good fortune. I honor him for being brave. But his ambition—for that, I killed him. There are tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his bravery, and death for his ambition. Who here is so low that he wants to be a slave? If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I’ve offended. Who here is so barbarous that he doesn’t want to be a Roman? If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I’ve offended. Who here is so vile that he doesn’t love his country? If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I have offended. I will pause for a reply.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$None, Brutus, none.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$No one, Brutus, no one.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Then none have I offended. I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of his death is enrolled in the Capitol. His glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor his offenses enforced for which he suffered death.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Then I have offended no one. I’ve done no more to Caesar than you will do to me. The reasons for his death are recorded in the Capitol. His glory has not been diminished where he earned it, nor have those offenses for which he was killed been exaggerated.

paragraphs.original: Enter Mark ANTONY with CAESAR’s body$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters with CAESAR’s body.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying—a place in the commonwealth—as which of you shall not? With this I depart: that, as I slew my best lover for the good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself when it shall please my country to need my death.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no part in the killing, will benefit from his death—receiving a share in the commonwealth, as you all will. With these words I leave. Just as I killed my best friend for the good of Rome, so will I kill myself when my country requires my death.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Live, Brutus! Live, live!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Live, Brutus! Live, live!

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Bring him with triumph home unto his house!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let’s carry him in triumph to his house!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Give him a statue with his ancestors!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let’s build a statue of him, near those of his ancestors!

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let him be Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let him become Caesar!

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Caesar’s better parts$NEWLINE$Shall be crowned in Brutus!
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Caesar’s better qualities exist in Brutus, and we will crown him.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and celebration!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$My countrymen—
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$My countrymen—

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Silence! Brutus speaks.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Peace, ho!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Quiet there!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good countrymen, let me depart alone.$NEWLINE$And, for my sake, stay here with Antony.$NEWLINE$Do grace to Caesar’s corpse, and grace his speech$NEWLINE$Tending to Caesar’s glories, which Mark Antony$NEWLINE$By our permission is allowed to make.$NEWLINE$I do entreat you, not a man depart,$NEWLINE$Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good countrymen, let me leave alone. I want you to stay here with Antony to pay respects to Caesar’s corpse and listen to Antony’s speech about Caesar’s glories, which he gives with our permission. I ask that none of you leave, except myself, until Antony has finished.

paragraphs.original: Exit BRUTUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS exits.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Stay, ho! And let us hear Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let’s stay and hear Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let him go up into the public chair.$NEWLINE$We’ll hear him.—Noble Antony, go up.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let him mount the pulpit. We’ll listen to him. Noble Antony, mount the podium.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.$NEWLINE$(ascends the pulpit)$NEWLINE$(ascends the pulpit)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$For Brutus’s sake, I am indebted to you.$NEWLINE$(he steps up into the pulpit)$NEWLINE$(he steps up into the pulpit)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$What does he say of Brutus?
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$What does he say about Brutus?

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$He says for Brutus' sake$NEWLINE$He finds himself beholding to us all.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$He says that for Brutus’s sake he finds himself indebted to us all.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$He’d better not speak badly of Brutus here.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$This Caesar was a tyrant.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Caesar was a tyrant.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Nay, that’s certain.$NEWLINE$We are blest that Rome is rid of him.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$That’s for sure. We’re lucky that Rome is rid of him.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Peace! Let us hear what Antony can say.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Quiet! Let’s hear what Antony has to say.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You gentle Romans—
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You gentle Romans—

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Peace, ho! Let us hear him.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Quiet there! Let us hear him.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears.$NEWLINE$I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.$NEWLINE$The evil that men do lives after them;$NEWLINE$The good is oft interrèd with their bones.$NEWLINE$So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus$NEWLINE$Hath told you Caesar was ambitious.$NEWLINE$If it were so, it was a grievous fault,$NEWLINE$And grievously hath Caesar answered it.$NEWLINE$Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest—$NEWLINE$For Brutus is an honorable man;$NEWLINE$So are they all, all honorable men—$NEWLINE$Come I to speak in Caesar’s funeral.$NEWLINE$He was my friend, faithful and just to me.$NEWLINE$But Brutus says he was ambitious,$NEWLINE$And Brutus is an honorable man.$NEWLINE$He hath brought many captives home to Rome$NEWLINE$Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Friends, Romans, countrymen, give me your attention. I have come here to bury Caesar, not to praise him. The evil that men do is remembered after their deaths, but the good is often buried with them. It might as well be the same with Caesar. The noble Brutus told you that Caesar was ambitious. If that’s true, it’s a serious fault, and Caesar has paid seriously for it. With the permission of Brutus and the others—for Brutus is an honorable man; they are all honorable men—I have come here to speak at Caesar’s funeral. He was my friend, he was faithful and just to me. But Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man. He brought many captives home to Rome whose ransoms brought wealth to the city.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?$NEWLINE$When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept.$NEWLINE$Ambition should be made of sterner stuff.$NEWLINE$Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,$NEWLINE$And Brutus is an honorable man.$NEWLINE$You all did see that on the Lupercal$NEWLINE$I thrice presented him a kingly crown,$NEWLINE$Which he did thrice refuse. Was this ambition?$NEWLINE$Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,$NEWLINE$And, sure, he is an honorable man.$NEWLINE$I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,$NEWLINE$But here I am to speak what I do know.$NEWLINE$You all did love him once, not without cause.$NEWLINE$What cause withholds you then to mourn for him?$NEWLINE$O judgment! Thou art fled to brutish beasts,$NEWLINE$And men have lost their reason. Bear with me.$NEWLINE$My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,$NEWLINE$And I must pause till it come back to me. (weeps)$NEWLINE$(weeps)
paragraphs.translated: Is this the work of an ambitious man? When the poor cried, Caesar cried too. Ambition shouldn’t be so soft. Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man. You all saw that on the Lupercal feast day I offered him a king’s crown three times, and he refused it three times. Was this ambition? Yet Brutus says he was ambitious. And, no question, Brutus is an honorable man. I am not here to disprove what Brutus has said, but to say what I know. You all loved him once, and not without reason. Then what reason holds you back from mourning him now? Men have become brutish beasts and lost their reason! Bear with me. My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar, and I must pause until it returns to me. (he weeps)$NEWLINE$I$NEWLINE$(he weeps)

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$I think there’s a lot of sense in what he says.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$If thou consider rightly of the matter,$NEWLINE$Caesar has had great wrong.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$If you think about it correctly, Caesar has suffered a great wrong.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Has he, masters?$NEWLINE$I fear there will a worse come in his place.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Has he, sirs? I’m worried there will be someone worse to replace him.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Marked ye his words? He would not take the crown.$NEWLINE$Therefore ’tis certain he was not ambitious.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Did you hear Antony? Caesar wouldn’t take the crown. Therefore it’s certain that he wasn’t ambitious.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$If it be found so, some will dear abide it.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$If it turns out he wasn’t, certain people are going to get it.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Poor soul! His eyes are red as fire with weeping.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Poor man! Antony’s eyes are fiery red from crying.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$There’s not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$There isn’t a nobler man than Antony in all of Rome.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Now mark him. He begins again to speak.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Now listen, he’s going to speak again.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$But yesterday the word of Caesar might$NEWLINE$Have stood against the world. Now lies he there,$NEWLINE$And none so poor to do him reverence.$NEWLINE$O masters, if I were disposed to stir$NEWLINE$Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage,$NEWLINE$I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong—$NEWLINE$Who, you all know, are honorable men.$NEWLINE$I will not do them wrong. I rather choose$NEWLINE$To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you,$NEWLINE$Than I will wrong such honorable men.$NEWLINE$But here’s a parchment with the seal of Caesar.$NEWLINE$I found it in his closet. 'Tis his will.$NEWLINE$Let but the commons hear this testament—$NEWLINE$Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read—$NEWLINE$And they would go and kiss dead Caesar’s wounds$NEWLINE$And dip their napkins in his sacred blood,$NEWLINE$Yea, beg a hair of him for memory,$NEWLINE$And, dying, mention it within their wills,$NEWLINE$Bequeathing it as a rich legacy$NEWLINE$Unto their issue.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Only yesterday the word of Caesar might have stood against the world. Now he lies there worth nothing, and no one is so humble as to show him respect. Oh, sirs, if I stirred your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I would offend Brutus and Cassius, who, you all know, are honorable men. I will not do them wrong. I would rather wrong the dead, and wrong myself and you, than wrong such honorable men. But here’s a paper with Caesar’s seal on it. I found it in his room—it’s his will. If you could only hear this testament—which, excuse me, I don’t intend to read aloud—you would kiss dead Caesar’s wounds and dip your handkerchiefs in his sacred blood, and beg for a lock of hair to remember him by. And when you died, you would mention the handkerchief or the hair in your will, bequeathing it to your heirs like a rich legacy.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll hear the will. Read it, Mark Antony!
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We want to hear the will. Read it, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$The will, the will! We will hear Caesar’s will.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$The will, the will! We want to hear Caesar’s will.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Have patience, gentle friends. I must not read it.$NEWLINE$It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.$NEWLINE$You are not wood, you are not stones, but men.$NEWLINE$And, being men, bearing the will of Caesar,$NEWLINE$It will inflame you, it will make you mad.$NEWLINE$'Tis good you know not that you are his heirs.$NEWLINE$For, if you should—Oh, what would come of it!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Be patient, gentle friends, I must not read it. It isn’t proper for you to know how much Caesar loved you. You aren’t wood, you aren’t stones—you’re men. And, being men, the contents of Caesar’s will would enrage you. It’s better that you don’t know you’re his heirs, for if you knew, just imagine what would come of it!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Read the will. We’ll hear it, Antony.$NEWLINE$You shall read us the will, Caesar’s will.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Read the will. We want to hear it, Antony. You have to read us the will, Caesar’s will.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Will you be patient? Will you stay awhile?$NEWLINE$I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it.$NEWLINE$I fear I wrong the honorable men$NEWLINE$Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar. I do fear it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Will you be patient? Will you wait awhile? I’ve said too much in telling you of it. I’m afraid that I wrong the honorable men whose daggers have stabbed Caesar.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$They were traitors! “Honorable men”!
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$They were traitors. “Honorable men!”

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$The will! The testament!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$The will! The testament!

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$They were villains, murderers. The will! Read the will!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$They were villains, murderers. The will! Read the will!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You will compel me, then, to read the will?$NEWLINE$Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar,$NEWLINE$And let me show you him that made the will.$NEWLINE$Shall I descend? And will you give me leave?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You force me to read the will, then? Then make a circle around Caesar’s corpse, and let me show you the man who made this will. Shall I come down? Will you let me?

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Come down.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Come down.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Descend.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Descend.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$You shall have leave.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll let you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY descends from the pulpit$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY descends from the pulpit.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$A ring!$NEWLINE$Stand round.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Make a circle; stand around him.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Stand from the hearse. Stand from the body.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Stand away from the hearse. Stand away from the body.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Room for Antony, most noble Antony!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Make room for Antony, most noble Antony!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Nay, press not so upon me. Stand far off.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, don’t press up against me. Stand further away.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Stand back. Room! Bear back.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Stand back. Give him room.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.$NEWLINE$You all do know this mantle. I remember$NEWLINE$The first time ever Caesar put it on.$NEWLINE$'Twas on a summer’s evening in his tent,$NEWLINE$That day he overcame the Nervii.$NEWLINE$Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through.$NEWLINE$See what a rent the envious Casca made.$NEWLINE$Through this the well-belovèd Brutus stabbed.$NEWLINE$And as he plucked his cursèd steel away,$NEWLINE$Mark how the blood of Caesar followed it,$NEWLINE$As rushing out of doors, to be resolved$NEWLINE$If Brutus so unkindly knocked, or no.$NEWLINE$For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.$NEWLINE$Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!$NEWLINE$This was the most unkindest cut of all.$NEWLINE$For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,$NEWLINE$Ingratitude, more strong than traitors' arms,$NEWLINE$Quite vanquished him. Then burst his mighty heart,$NEWLINE$And, in his mantle muffling up his face,$NEWLINE$Even at the base of Pompey’s statue,$NEWLINE$Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.$NEWLINE$O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!$NEWLINE$Then I, and you, and all of us fell down,$NEWLINE$Whilst bloody treason flourished over us.$NEWLINE$Oh, now you weep, and, I perceive, you feel$NEWLINE$The dint of pity. These are gracious drops.$NEWLINE$Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold$NEWLINE$Our Caesar’s vesture wounded? Look you here,$NEWLINE$Here is himself, marred, as you see, with traitors.$NEWLINE$(lifts up CAESAR's mantle)$NEWLINE$(lifts up$NEWLINE$s mantle)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$If you have tears, prepare to shed them now. You all know this cloak. I remember the first time Caesar ever put it on. It was a summer’s evening; he was in his tent. It was the day he overcame the Nervii warriors. Look, here’s where Cassius’s dagger pierced it. See the wound that Casca made. Through this hole beloved Brutus stabbed. And when he pulled out his cursed dagger, see how Caesar’s blood came with it, as if rushing out a door to see if it was really Brutus who was knocking so rudely. For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel. The gods know how dearly Caesar loved him! This was the most unkind cut of all. For when the noble Caesar saw him stab, he understood his beloved Brutus’s ingratitude; it was stronger than the violence of traitors, and it defeated him, bursting his mighty heart. And at the base of Pompey’s statue, with his cloak covering his face, which was dripping with blood the whole time, great Caesar fell. Oh, what a fall it was, my countrymen! Then you and I and all of us fell down, while bloody treason triumphed. Oh, now you weep, and I sense that you feel pity. These are gracious tears. But if it overwhelms you to look at Caesar’s wounded cloak, how will you feel, kind men, now? Look at this, here is the man—scarred, as you can see, by traitors. (he lifts up CAESAR's cloak)$NEWLINE$(he lifts up$NEWLINE$s cloak)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$O piteous spectacle!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, what a sad sight!

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$O noble Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, noble Caesar!

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$O woeful day!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, sad day!

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$O traitors, villains!
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, traitors, villains!

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$O most bloody sight!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, most bloody sight!

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We will be revenged.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We will get revenge.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill! Slay!$NEWLINE$Let not a traitor live!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Revenge! Let’s go after them! Seek! Burn! Set fire! Kill! Slay! Leave no traitors alive!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Stay, countrymen.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Wait, countrymen.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Peace there! Hear the noble Antony.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Quiet there! Listen to the noble Antony.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll hear him. We’ll follow him. We’ll die with him.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll listen to him, we’ll follow him, we’ll die with him.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Good friends, sweet friends! Let me not stir you up$NEWLINE$To such a sudden flood of mutiny.$NEWLINE$They that have done this deed are honorable.$NEWLINE$What private griefs they have, alas, I know not,$NEWLINE$That made them do it. They are wise and honorable,$NEWLINE$And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.$NEWLINE$I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts.$NEWLINE$I am no orator, as Brutus is,$NEWLINE$But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man$NEWLINE$That love my friend. And that they know full well$NEWLINE$That gave me public leave to speak of him.$NEWLINE$For I have neither wit nor words nor worth,$NEWLINE$Action nor utterance nor the power of speech,$NEWLINE$To stir men’s blood. I only speak right on.$NEWLINE$I tell you that which you yourselves do know,$NEWLINE$Show you sweet Caesar’s wounds, poor poor dumb mouths,$NEWLINE$And bid them speak for me. But were I Brutus,$NEWLINE$And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony$NEWLINE$Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue$NEWLINE$In every wound of Caesar that should move$NEWLINE$The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Good friends, sweet friends, don’t let me stir you up to such a sudden mutiny. Those who have done this deed are honorable. I don’t know what private grudges they had that made them do it. They’re wise and honorable, and will no doubt give you reasons for it. I haven’t come to steal your loyalty, friends. I’m no orator, as Brutus is. I’m only, as you know, a plain, blunt man who loved his friend, and the men who let me speak know this well. I have neither cleverness nor rhetorical skill nor the authority nor gesture nor eloquence nor the power of speech to stir men up. I just speak directly. I tell you what you already know. I show you sweet Caesar’s wounds—poor, speechless mouths!—and make them speak for me. But if I were Brutus and Brutus were me, then I’d stir you up, and install in each of Caesar’s wounds the kind of voice that could convince even stones to rise up and mutiny.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$We’ll mutiny.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$We’ll mutiny.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll burn the house of Brutus.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll burn Brutus’s house.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Away, then! Come, seek the conspirators.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Let’s go, then! Come, find the conspirators!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Yet hear me, countrymen. Yet hear me speak.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Wait, and listen to me, countrymen.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Peace, ho! Hear Antony. Most noble Antony!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Quiet! Wait! Listen to Antony. Most noble Antony!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Why, friends, you go to do you know not what.$NEWLINE$Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?$NEWLINE$Alas, you know not. I must tell you then.$NEWLINE$You have forgot the will I told you of.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Why, friends, you don’t even know what you’re doing yet. What has Caesar done to deserve your love? Alas, you don’t know. I must tell you then. You’ve forgotten the will I told you about.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Most true. The will! Let’s stay and hear the will.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Yes! The will! Let’s stay and hear the will!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Here is the will, and under Caesar’s seal$NEWLINE$To every Roman citizen he gives—$NEWLINE$To every several man—seventy-five drachmas.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Here’s the will, written under Caesar’s seal. To every Roman citizen he gives—to every individual man—seventy-five drachmas.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Most noble Caesar! We’ll revenge his death.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Most noble Caesar! We’ll revenge his death.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$O royal Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, royal Caesar!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Hear me with patience.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Listen to me patiently.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Peace, ho!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Quiet, there!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,$NEWLINE$His private arbors and new-planted orchards,$NEWLINE$On this side Tiber. He hath left them you$NEWLINE$And to your heirs forever—common pleasures,$NEWLINE$To walk abroad and recreate yourselves.$NEWLINE$Here was a Caesar! When comes such another?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Also, he’s left you all his walkways—in his private gardens and newly planted orchards—on this side of the Tiber River. He’s left them to you and to your heirs forever—public pleasures in which you will be able to stroll and relax. Here was a Caesar! When will there be another like him?

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Never, never.—Come, away, away!$NEWLINE$We’ll burn his body in the holy place,$NEWLINE$And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.$NEWLINE$Take up the body.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Never, never. Let’s go! We’ll burn his body in the holy place and use the brands to set the traitors' houses on fire. Take up the body.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Go fetch fire.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll start a fire.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Pluck down benches.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$We’ll use benches for wood—

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Pluck down forms, windows, anything.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$And windowsills, anything.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PLEBEIANS with CAESAR’s body$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: Citizens exit with CAESAR’s body.$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot.$NEWLINE$Take thou what course thou wilt!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now, let it work. Trouble, you have begun—take whatever course you choose!

paragraphs.original: Enter OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original: How now, fellow?
paragraphs.translated: What’s up, my man?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$Sir, Octavius has already arrived in Rome.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where is he?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where is he?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$And thither will I straight to visit him.$NEWLINE$He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry,$NEWLINE$And in this mood will give us anything.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I will go straight to visit him. I ask for him, and he comes. Fortune is happy today and, in this mood, will give us anything we want.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS' SERVANT$NEWLINE$I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius$NEWLINE$Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT$NEWLINE$I heard Octavius say that Brutus and Cassius have ridden like madmen through the gates of Rome.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Belike they had some notice of the people$NEWLINE$How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$They probably received warning about how much I stirred up the people. Take me to Octavius.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CINNA THE POET, and after him the PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET enters, followed by PLEBEIANS.$NEWLINE$CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar,$NEWLINE$And things unlucky charge my fantasy.$NEWLINE$I have no will to wander forth of doors,$NEWLINE$Yet something leads me forth.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$I dreamed last night that I feasted with Caesar, and unlucky signs overwhelmed my imagination. I have no desire to go outside, yet something leads me there.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$What is your name?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$What’s your name?

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Whither are you going?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Where are you going?

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Where do you dwell?
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Where do you live?

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Are you a married man or a bachelor?
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Are you a married man or a bachelor?

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Answer every man directly.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Answer all of us, now.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Ay, and briefly.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, and be brief.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Ay, and wisely.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, and be wise.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Ay, and truly, you were best.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, and be truthful, if you know what’s good for you.

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly—wisely I say, I am a bachelor.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$What’s my name? Where am I going? Where do I live? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to answer every man briefly, wisely, and truthfully—wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$That’s as much as to say they are fools that marry. You’ll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed, directly.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$You imply that married men are fools. You’ll get a blow from me for that, I think. Go on with what you were saying—right this instant.

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$Directly, I am going to Caesar’s funeral.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$Right this instant, I’m going to Caesar’s funeral.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$As a friend or an enemy?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$As a friend or an enemy?

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$As a friend.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$As a friend.

paragraphs.original: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$That matter is answered directly.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$He answered that question straight.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$For your dwelling—briefly.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$As for where you live, tell us quickly—get to the point.

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$Getting right to the point, I live near the Capitol.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Your name, sir, truly.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Tell us your name, sir, truthfully.

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$Truly, my name is Cinna.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$Truthfully, my name is Cinna.

paragraphs.original: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Tear him to pieces. He’s a conspirator.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Tear him to pieces. He’s a conspirator.

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$I am Cinna the poet. I am Cinna the poet.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet!

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Tear him for his bad verses! Tear him for his bad verses!
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Tear him apart for his bad verses, tear him up!

paragraphs.original: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$I am not Cinna the conspirator.
paragraphs.translated: CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$I’m not Cinna the conspirator.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$It is no matter. His name’s Cinna. Pluck but his name out of his heart and turn him going.
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$It doesn’t matter. His name’s Cinna. Pull only his name out of his heart and let him go.

paragraphs.original: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Tear him, tear him!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD PLEBEIAN$NEWLINE$Tear him apart, tear him up!

paragraphs.original: PLEBEIANS attack CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$CINNA THE POET
paragraphs.translated: The PLEBEIANS attack CINNA THE POET.$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$CINNA THE POET

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Come, brands, ho, firebrands. To Brutus', to Cassius', burn all. Some to Decius' house and some to Casca’s. Some to Ligarius'. Away, go!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Come, firebrands, over here! To Brutus’s, to Cassius’s, let’s burn them all. Some of you go to Decius’s house and some to Casca’s. Some to Ligarius’s. Go!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PLEBEIANS dragging CINNA THE POET$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$CINNA THE POET
paragraphs.translated: The PLEBEIANS exit, dragging CINNA THE POET.$NEWLINE$PLEBEIANS$NEWLINE$CINNA THE POET

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY, OCTAVIUS, and LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY, OCTAVIUS, and LEPIDUS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$These many, then, shall die. Their names are pricked.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$These ones, then, will be assassinated. Their names are marked.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$(to LEPIDUS)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Your brother too must die. Consent you, Lepidus?
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$(to LEPIDUS) Your brother has to die too. Do you agree, Lepidus?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$I do consent—
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$I agree—

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Prick him down, Antony.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Put a mark next to his name too, Antony.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Upon condition Publius shall not live,$NEWLINE$Who is your sister’s son, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$On the condition that your sister’s son, Publius, also must die, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$He shall not live. Look, with a spot I damn him.$NEWLINE$But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house.$NEWLINE$Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine$NEWLINE$How to cut off some charge in legacies.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$He will die. See—I’ve sealed his fate with this mark next to his name. But, Lepidus, go to Caesar’s house. Bring his will here, and we’ll figure out a way to reduce his bequests to the people.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$What, shall I find you here?
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Will you be here when I return?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Or here, or at the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Either here or at the Capitol.

paragraphs.original: Exit LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS exits.$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$This is a slight, unmeritable man,$NEWLINE$Meet to be sent on errands. Is it fit,$NEWLINE$The threefold world divided, he should stand$NEWLINE$One of the three to share it?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$He’s an unremarkable man, fit only to be sent on errands. Does it really make sense, once we divide the world into three parts, that he should be one of the three rulers?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$So you thought him.$NEWLINE$And took his voice who should be pricked to die$NEWLINE$In our black sentence and proscription.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$You thought it made sense, and you listened to him about who should be marked to die in these harsh death sentences.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Octavius, I have seen more days than you.$NEWLINE$And though we lay these honors on this man$NEWLINE$To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads,$NEWLINE$He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,$NEWLINE$To groan and sweat under the business,$NEWLINE$Either led or driven, as we point the way.$NEWLINE$And having brought our treasure where we will,$NEWLINE$Then take we down his load and turn him off,$NEWLINE$Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears$NEWLINE$And graze in commons.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Octavius, I’m older than you are. And although we’re giving these honors to this man so that he shares some of the blame for what we’re doing, he’ll carry these honors like a jackass carries gold—groaning and sweating under the load, either led or pushed, as we direct him. Once he’s carried our treasure where we want it, we’ll free him of the load and turn him loose like a jackass, to shake his ears and graze in the public pastures.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$You may do your will,$NEWLINE$But he’s a tried and valiant soldier.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$You can do what you want, but he’s an experienced and honorable soldier.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$So is my horse, Octavius, and for that$NEWLINE$I do appoint him store of provender.$NEWLINE$It is a creature that I teach to fight,$NEWLINE$To wind, to stop, to run directly on,$NEWLINE$His corporal motion governed by my spirit,$NEWLINE$And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so.$NEWLINE$He must be taught and trained and bid go forth,$NEWLINE$A barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds$NEWLINE$On objects, arts, and imitations,$NEWLINE$Which, out of use and staled by other men,$NEWLINE$Begin his fashion. Do not talk of him$NEWLINE$But as a property. And now, Octavius,$NEWLINE$Listen great things. Brutus and Cassius$NEWLINE$Are levying powers. We must straight make head.$NEWLINE$Therefore let our alliance be combined,$NEWLINE$Our best friends made, our means stretched.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$So is my horse, Octavius, and for that reason I give him all the hay he wants. But my horse is a creature that I teach to fight—to turn, to stop, to run in a straight line. I govern the motion of his body. And in some ways, Lepidus is just like that. He has to be taught and trained and told to go forward. He’s an empty man, who pays attention to fashions and tastes that other men took up and got tired of long ago. Don’t think about Lepidus except as a means to an end. And now, Octavius, listen to more important things. Brutus and Cassius are raising armies. We have to raise our own immediately. So, we should combine forces and organize our allies, pull together our friends, and stretch our resources as far as they’ll go.$NEWLINE$I

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And let us presently go sit in council$NEWLINE$How covert matters may be best disclosed,$NEWLINE$And open perils surest answered.
paragraphs.translated: Let’s immediately organize a council to discuss the best way to find out their secrets and the safest way to confront the threats we’re already faced with.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Let us do so. For we are at the stake$NEWLINE$And bayed about with many enemies.$NEWLINE$And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear,$NEWLINE$Millions of mischiefs.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Let’s do that, because we’re hemmed in by many enemies. And even some of the people who smile at us are in fact plotting against us, I’m afraid.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Drum. Enter BRUTUS with LUCIUS, LUCILLIUS, and the army. TITINIUS and PINDARUS meet them$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated: A drum plays. BRUTUS, LUCILLIUS, LUCIUS, and SOLDIERS enter. TITINIUS and PINDARUS meet them.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$PINDARUS

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Stand, ho!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Stop.

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$Give the word, ho, and stand.
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$Pass on the command to halt!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What now, Lucillius? Is Cassius near?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What’s happening now, Lucillius? Is Cassius nearby?

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$He is at hand, and Pindarus is come$NEWLINE$To do you salutation from his master.
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$He’s nearby, and Pindarus has come to salute you on behalf of his master.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He greets me well.—Your master, Pindarus,$NEWLINE$In his own change or by ill officers$NEWLINE$Hath given me some worthy cause to wish$NEWLINE$Things done, undone. But if he be at hand$NEWLINE$I shall be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He sends his greetings through a good man. Your master, Pindarus, either because he’s changed his mind or been influenced by bad officers, has made me wish we hadn’t done some of the things we did. If he’s nearby, I want an explanation.

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$I do not doubt$NEWLINE$But that my noble master will appear$NEWLINE$Such as he is, full of regard and honor.
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$I have no doubt that my noble master will prove himself to be what he is: honorable and noble.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He is not doubted.—A word, Lucillius.$NEWLINE$(takes LUCILLIUS aside)$NEWLINE$(takes$NEWLINE$aside)$NEWLINE$How he received you, let me be resolved.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I don’t doubt him. Can I have a word with you, Lucillius? (takes LUCILLIUS aside) Tell me how Cassius treated you. Put my mind at rest.$NEWLINE$(takes$NEWLINE$aside)

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$With courtesy and with respect enough.$NEWLINE$But not with such familiar instances$NEWLINE$Nor with such free and friendly conference$NEWLINE$As he hath used of old.
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$He received me with courtesy and sufficient respect, but not with affection, nor with as much open and friendly conversation as he once greeted me.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Thou hast described$NEWLINE$A hot friend cooling. Ever note, Lucillius,$NEWLINE$When love begins to sicken and decay,$NEWLINE$It useth an enforcèd ceremony.$NEWLINE$There are no tricks in plain and simple faith.$NEWLINE$But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,$NEWLINE$Make gallant show and promise of their mettle.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You’ve described a warm friend who’s cooling off. Remember this, Lucillius. When a friend starts to get sick of you, he treats you artificially. Plain and simple loyalty doesn’t make anyone act phony. But insincere men, like horses who are too lively at the start of a race, make a big show of their spirit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Low march within
paragraphs.translated: A low sound of drums and SOLDIERS marching.$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: But when they should endure the bloody spur,$NEWLINE$They fall their crests and, like deceitful jades,$NEWLINE$Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?
paragraphs.translated: But when push comes to shove, they droop like those horses that are all show and slow to a crawl. Is his army approaching?

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered.$NEWLINE$The greater part, the horse in general,$NEWLINE$Are come with Cassius.
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$They plan to spend the night in Sardis. The larger part, the main body of cavalry, are coming with Cassius.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Hark! He is arrived.$NEWLINE$March gently on to meet him.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Look! He’s arrived. March to meet him at a dignified pace.

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIUS and his powers$NEWLINE$CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS enters with his army.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Stand, ho!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Halt.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Stand, ho! Speak the word along.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Halt! Pass the order along.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Stand!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Halt!

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Stand!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Halt!

paragraphs.original: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Stand!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Halt!

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Judge me, you gods! Wrong I mine enemies?$NEWLINE$And if not so, how should I wrong a brother?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Let the gods judge me! Do I mistreat even my enemies? No. So how could I possibly wrong a brother?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs.$NEWLINE$And when you do them—
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, your sober expression is a mask to hide the fact that you’ve wronged me. And when you do—

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Cassius, be content.$NEWLINE$Speak your griefs softly. I do know you well.$NEWLINE$Before the eyes of both our armies here,$NEWLINE$Which should perceive nothing but love from us,$NEWLINE$Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away.$NEWLINE$Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,$NEWLINE$And I will give you audience.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Cassius, calm down. We know each other well, and you can speak your grievances quietly. Let’s not argue here in front of both our armies, which ought to see nothing but love between us. Order them to move back. Then, in my tent, you can elaborate on your complaints, and I’ll listen.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Pindarus,$NEWLINE$Bid our commanders lead their charges off$NEWLINE$A little from this ground.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Pindarus, order our commanders to lead their charges a little ways away from this ground.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucillius, do you the like. And let no man$NEWLINE$Come to our tent till we have done our conference.$NEWLINE$Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucillius, you do the same, and don’t allow anyone to come into our tent until we’ve finished our conference. Have Lucius and Titinius guard the door.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except BRUTUS and CASSIUS exits.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Manent BRUTUS and CASSIUS, now in the tent$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS and CASSIUS remain onstage. They are now in their tent.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$That you have wronged me doth appear in this:$NEWLINE$You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella$NEWLINE$For taking bribes here of the Sardians,$NEWLINE$Wherein my letters, praying on his side$NEWLINE$Because I knew the man, were slighted off.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$My evidence that you have wronged me is that you condemned and disgraced Lucius Pella for taking bribes here from the Sardinians, and you ignored my letters, where I argued that he was innocent; I know the man.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You wronged yourself to write in such a case.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You wronged yourself to write on behalf of such a man.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$In such a time as this it is not meet$NEWLINE$That every nice offense should bear his comment.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$In a time like this, it doesn’t make sense to criticize every offense.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself$NEWLINE$Are much condemned to have an itching palm,$NEWLINE$To sell and mart your offices for gold$NEWLINE$To undeservers.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you, Cassius, you yourself have been called greedy and been accused of giving your positions to undeserving men in exchange for gold.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I “an itching palm”!$NEWLINE$You know that you are Brutus that speak this,$NEWLINE$Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Me, “greedy”! You know, if you were anyone other than Brutus, that speech would be your last.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The name of Cassius honors this corruption,$NEWLINE$And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The name of Cassius gives credit to these corrupt actions, and so they go unpunished.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Chastisement!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Unpunished!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Remember March, the ides of March remember.$NEWLINE$Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Remember March, March 15th. Didn’t great Caesar bleed for the sake of justice?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What villain touched his body, that did stab,$NEWLINE$And not for justice? What, shall one of us$NEWLINE$That struck the foremost man of all this world$NEWLINE$But for supporting robbers, shall we now$NEWLINE$Contaminate our fingers with base bribes,$NEWLINE$And sell the mighty space of our large honors$NEWLINE$For so much trash as may be graspèd thus?$NEWLINE$I had rather be a dog and bay the moon$NEWLINE$Than such a Roman.
paragraphs.translated: Who among us stabbed him for any cause but justice? What—did one of us strike down the most powerful man in the world in order to support robbers? Should we now dirty our fingers with lowly bribes and sell the mighty offices that we hold for whatever money we can get our hands on? I’d rather be a dog and howl at the moon than be that kind of Roman.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, bait not me.$NEWLINE$I’ll not endure it. You forget yourself$NEWLINE$To hedge me in. I am a soldier, I,$NEWLINE$Older in practice, abler than yourself$NEWLINE$To make conditions.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Brutus, do not provoke me. I will not take it. You’re forgetting yourself when you back me into a corner. I’m a soldier, more experienced than you, and better able to give orders.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Go to. You are not, Cassius.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Get lost! You are not, Cassius.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I am.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I am.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I say you are not.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I say you’re not.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Urge me no more, I shall forget myself.$NEWLINE$Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Don’t provoke me any further or I’ll forget to restrain myself. If you care about your health, you won’t push me any further.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Away, slight man!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Leave, you little man.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Is ’t possible?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Is this possible?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Hear me, for I will speak.$NEWLINE$Must I give way and room to your rash choler?$NEWLINE$Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Listen to me, for I have something to tell you. Am I required to indulge your rash anger? Does a madman scare me when he stares at me?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$O ye gods, ye gods, must I endure all this?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Oh gods, oh gods! Must I endure all this?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$“All this”? Ay, more. Fret till your proud heart break.$NEWLINE$Go show your slaves how choleric you are$NEWLINE$And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge?$NEWLINE$Must I observe you? Must I stand and crouch$NEWLINE$Under your testy humor? By the gods,$NEWLINE$You shall digest the venom of your spleen,$NEWLINE$Though it do split you. For from this day forth,$NEWLINE$I’ll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,$NEWLINE$When you are waspish.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$“All this”? Yes, and more. Go ahead—rage till your proud heart breaks. Show your slaves how mad you are, and make your servants tremble. But me—am I going to cower at you and your irritable moods? You’ll have to swallow your own poison till it makes you burst before I’m going to respond; from now on, I’ll make you the butt of my jokes whenever you get sharp with me.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Is it come to this?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Has it come to this?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You say you are a better soldier.$NEWLINE$Let it appear so. Make your vaunting true,$NEWLINE$And it shall please me well. For mine own part,$NEWLINE$I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You say you’re a better soldier. Show it! Make your boasts come true, and I’ll be thrilled. I’m always happy to hear about brave men.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You wrong me every way. You wrong me, Brutus.$NEWLINE$I said an elder soldier, not a better.$NEWLINE$Did I say “better”?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You wrong me in every way. You wrong me, Brutus. I said an older soldier, not a better one. Did I say “better”?$NEWLINE$older

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$If you did, I care not.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$If you did, I don’t care.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$When Caesar was alive, even he wouldn’t dare anger me like this.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Peace, peace! You durst not so have tempted him.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh, be quiet. You wouldn’t have dared to tempt him so.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I durst not!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I wouldn’t have dared!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What, durst not tempt him?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What? Not dared to tempt him?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$For your life you durst not.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You wouldn’t have dared, out of fear for your life.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Do not presume too much upon my love.$NEWLINE$I may do that I shall be sorry for.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Don’t take my love for granted. I might do something I’ll be sorry for.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You have done that you should be sorry for.$NEWLINE$There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats,$NEWLINE$For I am armed so strong in honesty$NEWLINE$That they pass by me as the idle wind,$NEWLINE$Which I respect not. I did send to you$NEWLINE$For certain sums of gold, which you denied me,$NEWLINE$For I can raise no money by vile means.$NEWLINE$By heaven, I had rather coin my heart$NEWLINE$And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring$NEWLINE$From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash$NEWLINE$By any indirection. I did send$NEWLINE$To you for gold to pay my legions,$NEWLINE$Which you denied me. Was that done like Cassius?$NEWLINE$Should I have answered Caius Cassius so?$NEWLINE$When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous$NEWLINE$To lock such rascal counters from his friends,$NEWLINE$Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts.$NEWLINE$Dash him to pieces!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You’ve already done something you should be sorry for. Your threats don’t scare me, Cassius, because I’m so secure in my honesty and integrity that they pass me by like a weak breeze. I asked you for a certain amount of gold, which you wouldn’t give me. I myself can’t raise money by unethical means. I’d rather turn my heart into money and my drops of blood into coins than use crooked tactics to wring petty cash from the hardworking hands of peasants. I asked you for gold to pay my soldiers, and you wouldn’t give it to me. Was that the Caius Cassius that I knew? And would I have ever done that to you? If I ever get so greedy that I hoard such petty cash from my friends, may the gods dash me to pieces with their thunderbolts!

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I denied you not.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I didn’t refuse you.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You did.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$You did.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I did not. He was but a fool that brought$NEWLINE$My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart.$NEWLINE$A friend should bear his friend’s infirmities,$NEWLINE$But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I didn’t. The man who brought my answer to you was a fool. You have broken my heart. A friend should put up with his friend’s weaknesses, but you exaggerate mine.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I do not, till you practice them on me.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I don’t until you practice them on me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You love me not.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You don’t love me.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I do not like your faults.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I don’t like your faults.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$A friendly eye could never see such faults.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$A friend would never see those faults.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$A flatterer’s would not, though they do appear$NEWLINE$As huge as high Olympus.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, a flatterer wouldn’t, even if the faults were as huge as Mount Olympus.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,$NEWLINE$Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius,$NEWLINE$For Cassius is aweary of the world—$NEWLINE$Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;$NEWLINE$Checked like a bondman, all his faults observed,$NEWLINE$Set in a notebook, learned, and conned by rote$NEWLINE$To cast into my teeth. Oh, I could weep$NEWLINE$My spirit from mine eyes.$NEWLINE$(offers BRUTUS his bared dagger) There is my dagger.$NEWLINE$(offers$NEWLINE$his bared dagger)$NEWLINE$And here my naked breast. Within, a heart$NEWLINE$Dearer than Plutus' mine, richer than gold.$NEWLINE$If that thou beest a Roman, take it forth.$NEWLINE$I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart.$NEWLINE$Strike, as thou didst at Caesar. For I know$NEWLINE$When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better$NEWLINE$Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Come, Antony and young Octavius! Get your revenge on Cassius, because Cassius has grown tired of the world.
