He’s hated by someone he loves, defied by his brother, rebuked like a servant, all his faults observed, catalogued in a notebook, read, and committed to memory so they can be thrown in his face. Oh, I could weep my soul right out of myself! There’s my dagger (he offers BRUTUS his unsheathed dagger), and here’s my bare chest. Inside it is a heart more valuable than
Pluto’s silver mine and richer than gold. If you’re a Roman, take my heart out. I, who denied you gold, will give you my heart. Strike as you did at Caesar, for I know even when you hated him the most, you still loved him better than you ever loved me.$NEWLINE$(he offers$NEWLINE$his unsheathed dagger)$NEWLINE$Pluto’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Sheathe your dagger.$NEWLINE$Be angry when you will, it shall have scope.$NEWLINE$Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.$NEWLINE$O Cassius, you are yokèd with a lamb$NEWLINE$That carries anger as the flint bears fire,$NEWLINE$Who, much enforcèd, shows a hasty spark$NEWLINE$And straight is cold again.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Put away your dagger. Be angry whenever you like, it’s all right with me. Do whatever you want, and I’ll say your insults are just a bad mood. Oh, Cassius, you’re partners with a quiet lamb. My anger is like a flint striking—a brief spark, and then I’m cold again.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Hath Cassius lived$NEWLINE$To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,$NEWLINE$When grief and blood ill-tempered vexeth him?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Have I lived this long only to be the butt of a joke whenever you’re angry or frustrated?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$When I said that, I was angry too.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You admit it, then? Give me your hand.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$And my heart too.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$And my heart too.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS and BRUTUS shake hands$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS and BRUTUS shake hands.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$O Brutus!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Brutus!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Have not you love enough to bear with me,$NEWLINE$When that rash humor which my mother gave me$NEWLINE$Makes me forgetful?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Do you have enough love for me to be patient when my bad temper, which I inherited from my mother, makes me forget how I should behave?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yes, Cassius. And from henceforth$NEWLINE$When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,$NEWLINE$He’ll think your mother chides and leave you so.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yes, Cassius. And from now on, when you get hot with me, I’ll assume it’s your mother speaking and leave it at that.

paragraphs.original: POET$NEWLINE$(within) Let me go in to see the generals.$NEWLINE$(within)$NEWLINE$There is some grudge between 'em. 'Tis not meet$NEWLINE$They be alone.
paragraphs.translated: POET$NEWLINE$(offstage) Let me in to see the generals. There’s a grudge between them, and it isn’t a good idea for them to be alone.$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$(within)    You shall not come to them.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$(offstage) You can’t see them.$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: POET$NEWLINE$(within) Nothing but death shall stay me.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POET$NEWLINE$(offstage) You’d have to kill me to stop me.$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: Enter a POET followed by LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS$NEWLINE$POET$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated: A POET enters, followed by LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS.$NEWLINE$POET$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$How now? What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What’s this! What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: POET$NEWLINE$For shame, you generals! What do you mean?$NEWLINE$Love, and be friends as two such men should be.$NEWLINE$For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.
paragraphs.translated: POET$NEWLINE$You should be ashamed, generals! What do you think you’re doing?$NEWLINE$Love each other and be friends, like two such men should be.$NEWLINE$Listen to me, because I’m older than you, surely.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Ha ha! This man’s rhymes are terrible!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(to POET) Get you hence, sirrah. Saucy fellow, hence!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(to POET) Get out of here, you! Get away, you rude fellow!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Bear with him, Brutus. 'Tis his fashion.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Be patient with him, Brutus. That’s just how he is.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I’ll know his humor when he knows his time.$NEWLINE$What should the wars do with these jigging fools?$NEWLINE$—Companion, hence!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I’ll humor him when he learns how to behave. What should we do with all these rhyming fools that follow us from post to post? Get out of here, my friend.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Away, away, be gone.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Away, away, be gone.

paragraphs.original: Exit POET$NEWLINE$POET
paragraphs.translated: The POET exits.$NEWLINE$POET

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucillius and Titinius, bid the commanders$NEWLINE$Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucillius and Titinius, order the commanders to have the men camp for the night.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you,$NEWLINE$Immediately to us.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And return to us immediately, bringing Messala with you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS exit.$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(calls off)    Lucius, a bowl of wine!$NEWLINE$(calls off)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(calling offstage) Lucius, bring a bowl of wine.$NEWLINE$(calling offstage)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I did not think you could have been so angry.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I didn’t think you could even be so angry.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh Cassius, I’m tired out by many sorrows.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Of your philosophy you make no use$NEWLINE$If you give place to accidental evils.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS$NEWLINE$You’re forgetting your
Stoic philosophy if you allow chance misfortunes to upset you.$NEWLINE$Stoic$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No one bears sorrow better than me. Portia is dead.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Ha, Portia?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Portia!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$She is dead.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$She is dead.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$How ’scaped I killing when I crossed you so?$NEWLINE$O insupportable and touching loss!$NEWLINE$Upon what sickness?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$How did you manage not to kill me when we argued just now? What an irreplaceable and grievous loss! What sickness did she die of?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Impatient of my absence,$NEWLINE$And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony$NEWLINE$Have made themselves so strong—for with her death$NEWLINE$That tidings came—with this she fell distract$NEWLINE$And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$She was worried about my absence, and about the fact that young Octavius and Mark Antony have grown so strong—which I found out at the same time as the news of her death. She became full of despair and, when her attendants were away, swallowed burning coals.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And died so?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$And that’s how she died?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Even so.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yes, like that.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$O ye immortal gods!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Oh, immortal gods!

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS with wine and tapers$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS enters with wine and candles.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Speak no more of her.—Give me a bowl of wine.—$NEWLINE$In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.$NEWLINE$(drinks)$NEWLINE$(drinks)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Don’t talk about her anymore. Give me a bowl of wine. With this toast I bury all bad feelings between us, Cassius. (he drinks)$NEWLINE$(he drinks)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.$NEWLINE$Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup.$NEWLINE$I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.$NEWLINE$(drinks)$NEWLINE$(drinks)
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$My heart is thirsty for that noble promise. Fill my cup, Lucius, until the wine overflows it. I cannot drink too much of Brutus’s love. (he drinks)$NEWLINE$(he drinks)

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: Enter TITINIUS and MESSALA$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS and MESSALA enter.$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Come in, Titinius.—Welcome, good Messala!$NEWLINE$Now sit we close about this taper here$NEWLINE$And call in question our necessities.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Come in, Titinius! Welcome, good Messala. Now let’s sit closely around this candle and discuss our needs.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Portia, art thou gone?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Portia, are you really gone?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No more, I pray you.$NEWLINE$—Messala, I have here receivèd letters$NEWLINE$That young Octavius and Mark Antony$NEWLINE$Come down upon us with a mighty power,$NEWLINE$Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No more about that, please. Messala, I have received these letters explaining that young Octavius and Mark Antony are rushing toward Philippi and bearing down upon us with a mighty power.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$I have received letters that say the same.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$With what addition?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$And anything else?

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$That by proscription and bills of outlawry,$NEWLINE$Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus$NEWLINE$Have put to death an hundred senators.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$That with a series of legal writs, Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus have put a hundred senators to death.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Therein our letters do not well agree.$NEWLINE$Mine speak of seventy senators that died$NEWLINE$By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$On that point, our letters don’t agree. My letters say only seventy senators were killed, one being Cicero.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Cicero one?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Cicero too?

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Cicero is dead,$NEWLINE$And by that order of proscription.$NEWLINE$(to BRUTUS) Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Cicero is dead, by their decree. (to BRUTUS) Have you received letters from your wife, my lord?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, Messala.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, Messala.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$And you haven’t heard any news about her in your letters?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Nothing, Messala.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Nothing, Messala.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$That methinks is strange.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$I think that’s strange.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why ask you? Hear you aught of her in yours?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why do you ask? Have you heard something of her in your letters?

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$No, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$No, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Now, as you’re a Roman, tell me the truth.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell.$NEWLINE$For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Then you must take the truth I have to tell like a Roman. It’s certain that she is dead, and she died in a strange way.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala.$NEWLINE$With meditating that she must die once,$NEWLINE$I have the patience to endure it now.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Well, good-bye, Portia. We all must die, Messala. Having already thought about the fact that she would have to die sometime, I can endure her death now.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Even so great men great losses should endure.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$That’s the way great men ought to endure great losses.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I have as much of this in art as you,$NEWLINE$But yet my nature could not bear it so.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I’ve practiced Stoicism with as much devotion as you, but I still couldn’t bear this news like you do.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Well, to our work alive. What do you think$NEWLINE$Of marching to Philippi presently?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Well, let’s move on to our work with the living. What do you think of marching to Philippi immediately?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I do not think it good.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I don’t think it’s a good idea.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Your reason?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why not?

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$This it is:$NEWLINE$'Tis better that the enemy seek us.$NEWLINE$So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,$NEWLINE$Doing himself offense, whilst we, lying still,$NEWLINE$Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Here’s why: it’d be better for the enemy to come after us. That way, he’ll waste his provisions and tire out his soldiers, weakening his own capacities, while we, lying still, are rested, energetic, and nimble.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good reasons must of force give place to better.$NEWLINE$The people ’twixt Philippi and this ground$NEWLINE$Do stand but in a forced affection,$NEWLINE$For they have grudged us contribution.$NEWLINE$The enemy, marching along by them,$NEWLINE$By them shall make a fuller number up,$NEWLINE$Come on refreshed, new-added, and encouraged,$NEWLINE$From which advantage shall we cut him off$NEWLINE$If at Philippi we do face him there,$NEWLINE$These people at our back.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Your reasons are good, but I have better reasons for doing the opposite. The people who live between here and Philippi are loyal to us only because we force them to be. We made them contribute to our efforts against their will. The enemy, marching past them, will add them to its numbers, then come at us refreshed, newly reinforced, and full of courage. Thus we must cut him off from this advantage. If we meet him at Philippi, these people will be at our backs.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Hear me, good brother—
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Listen to me, good brother.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Under your pardon. You must note beside,$NEWLINE$That we have tried the utmost of our friends,$NEWLINE$Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe.$NEWLINE$The enemy increaseth every day.$NEWLINE$We, at the height, are ready to decline.$NEWLINE$There is a tide in the affairs of men,$NEWLINE$Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;$NEWLINE$Omitted, all the voyage of their life$NEWLINE$Is bound in shallows and in miseries.$NEWLINE$On such a full sea are we now afloat,$NEWLINE$And we must take the current when it serves$NEWLINE$Or lose our ventures.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Begging your pardon, I’ll continue what I was saying. You must also take into account that we’ve gotten as much from our friends as they can give. Our regiments are full to the brim; our cause is ready.$NEWLINE$The enemy gets larger each day. We, now at our largest, can only decrease. There’s a tidal movement in men’s affairs. Seizing the highest tide leads on to fortune. If high tide is let to pass, all the rest of the voyage of their lives will be marked by difficulty and misery. It’s on such a high tide that we’re now floating, and we must take the current when it is offered, or lose our campaign.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Then, with your will, go on.$NEWLINE$We’ll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$If that’s what you want, all right. We’ll go forward with you and meet them at Philippi.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$The deep of night is crept upon our talk,$NEWLINE$And nature must obey necessity,$NEWLINE$Which we will niggard with a little rest.$NEWLINE$There is no more to say?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$It’s now late at night, and actions must accommodate bodily needs, which we’ll satisfy with only a short rest. That’s all there is to say.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$No more. Good night.$NEWLINE$Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$There’s nothing else. Good night. We’ll rise and leave early tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucius!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucius!

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS enters.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: My gown.
paragraphs.translated: My nightgown.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCIUS$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS exits.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: Farewell, good Messala.—$NEWLINE$Good night, Titinius.—Noble, noble Cassius,$NEWLINE$Good night and good repose.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, good Messala. Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius, good night and sleep well.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$O my dear brother,$NEWLINE$This was an ill beginning of the night.$NEWLINE$Never come such division ’tween our souls.$NEWLINE$Let it not, Brutus.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Oh my dear brother! This was a bad start to the night. Let’s pray that we never come into conflict like that again. Let’s not, Brutus.

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIUS with the gown$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS enters with the nightgown.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Everything is well.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Everything’s fine.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Good night, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Good night, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good night, good brother.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good night, good brother.

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS, MESSALA$NEWLINE$Good night, Lord Brutus.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS, MESSALA$NEWLINE$Good night, Lord Brutus.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Farewell, everyone.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Farewell, everyone.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CASSIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA exit.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA

paragraphs.original: Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?
paragraphs.translated: Give me the gown. Where’s your lute?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Here in the tent.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Here in the tent.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What, thou speak’st drowsily?$NEWLINE$Poor knave, I blame thee not. Thou art o'erwatched.$NEWLINE$Call Claudio and some other of my men.$NEWLINE$I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$What, are you sleepy? Poor boy, I don’t blame you; you’ve stayed awake too long. Call Claudio and some of my other men. I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Varrus and Claudio!
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Varrus and Claudio!

paragraphs.original: Enter VARRUS and CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$VARRUS$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS and CLAUDIO enter.$NEWLINE$VARRUS$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original: VARRUS$NEWLINE$Calls my lord?
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS$NEWLINE$Did you call, my lord?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep.$NEWLINE$It may be I shall raise you by and by$NEWLINE$On business to my brother Cassius.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Sirs, I ask you to sleep in my tent. I might wake you up in a while to send you on an errand to my brother Cassius.

paragraphs.original: VARRUS$NEWLINE$So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS$NEWLINE$If you like, we’ll stand by and wait to do whatever you need.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I will not have it so. Lie down, good sirs.$NEWLINE$It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.$NEWLINE$—Look, Lucius, here’s the book I sought for so.$NEWLINE$I put it in the pocket of my gown.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, please, lie down, good sirs, because I might change my mind. Look, Lucius, here’s the book I was searching for. I put it in the pocket of my nightgown.

paragraphs.original: VARRUS and CLAUDIO lie down$NEWLINE$VARRUS$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS and CLAUDIO lie down.$NEWLINE$VARRUS$NEWLINE$CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I was sure your lordship did not give it me.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I was sure that you hadn’t given it to me.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.$NEWLINE$Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,$NEWLINE$And touch thy instrument a strain or two?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Bear with me, good boy. I’ve become very forgetful. Can you stay awake a bit longer and play a few tunes on your lute?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Ay, my lord, an ’t please you.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord, if you would like.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$It does, my boy.$NEWLINE$I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I would, my boy. I ask too much of you, but you’re always willing.

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$It is my duty, sir.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$It’s my duty, sir.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I should not urge thy duty past thy might.$NEWLINE$I know young bloods look for a time of rest.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$I shouldn’t make you do more than you’re able. I know that young men look forward to their rest.

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I have slept, my lord, already.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$I’ve already slept, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again.$NEWLINE$I will not hold thee long. If I do live,$NEWLINE$I will be good to thee.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$That was good planning, and you’ll sleep some more. I won’t keep you very long. If I live through this, I’ll be good to you.

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS plays music and sings a song, falling asleep$NEWLINE$LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS plays music and sings a song, then falls asleep.$NEWLINE$LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber,$NEWLINE$Layst thou thy leaden mace upon my boy$NEWLINE$That plays thee music?—Gentle knave, good night.$NEWLINE$I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee.$NEWLINE$If thou dost nod, thou break’st thy instrument.$NEWLINE$I’ll take it from thee. And, good boy, good night.$NEWLINE$—Let me see, let me see. Is not the leaf turned down$NEWLINE$Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.
paragraphs.translated: This is a sleepy tune. Oh, deadening sleep, have you taken over my boy who plays music for you? Gentle boy, good night. I won’t trouble you so much as to wake you. If you were to droop down, you’d break your instrument, and so I’ll take it from you. Good night, good boy. Let me see, let me see. Didn’t I turn down the page where I left off reading? Here it is, I think. This candle doesn’t give much light.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST of Caesar$NEWLINE$GHOST
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST of Caesar enters.$NEWLINE$GHOST

paragraphs.original: How ill this taper burns!—Ha, who comes here?$NEWLINE$I think it is the weakness of mine eyes$NEWLINE$That shapes this monstrous apparition.$NEWLINE$It comes upon me.—Art thou any thing?$NEWLINE$Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil$NEWLINE$That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?$NEWLINE$Speak to me what thou art.
paragraphs.translated: What! Who goes there? I think it’s my bad eyesight that’s making me see this horrible vision. It’s coming toward me. Are you real? Are you a god, an angel, or a devil, that you make my blood turn cold and my hair stand up? Tell me what you are.

paragraphs.original: GHOST$NEWLINE$Thy evil spirit, Brutus.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST$NEWLINE$I’m your evil spirit, Brutus.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why comest thou?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why do you come here?

paragraphs.original: GHOST$NEWLINE$To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST$NEWLINE$To tell you that you’ll see me at Philippi.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Well, then I shall see thee again?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Then I’ll see you again?

paragraphs.original: GHOST$NEWLINE$Ay, at Philippi.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST$NEWLINE$Yes, at Philippi.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Alright, then I’ll see you at Philippi.

paragraphs.original: Exit GHOST$NEWLINE$GHOST
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST exits.$NEWLINE$GHOST

paragraphs.original: Now I have taken heart thou vanishest.$NEWLINE$Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.$NEWLINE$—Boy, Lucius!—Varrus!—Claudio!—Sirs, awake!$NEWLINE$—Claudio!
paragraphs.translated: Just as you go, I find the courage to talk to you. Evil spirit, I want to talk some more. Boy, Lucius! Varrus! Claudio! Sirs, awake! Claudio!

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$The strings, my lord, are false.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$My lord, the strings are out of tune.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He thinks he still is at his instrument.$NEWLINE$Lucius, awake.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$He thinks he’s still playing his instrument. Lucius, wake up!

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$My lord?
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Were you dreaming, Lucius? Is that why you cried out?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$My lord, I do not know that I did cry.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$My lord, I don’t think I cried out.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yes, that thou didst. Didst thou see any thing?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yes, you did. Did you see anything?

paragraphs.original: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Nothing, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: LUCIUS$NEWLINE$Nothing, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Sleep again, Lucius.—Sirrah Claudio!$NEWLINE$(to VARRUS)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Fellow thou, awake!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Go back to sleep, Lucius. Claudio! (to VARRUS) You there, wake up!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VARRUS$NEWLINE$My lord?
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$My lord?
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why did you cry out in your sleep?

paragraphs.original: VARRUS, CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Did we, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS, CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Did we, my lord?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Ay. Saw you anything?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yes. Did you see anything?

paragraphs.original: VARRUS$NEWLINE$No, my lord, I saw nothing.
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS$NEWLINE$No, my lord, I didn’t see anything.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Nor I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Me neither, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Go and commend me to my brother Cassius.$NEWLINE$Bid him set on his powers betimes before,$NEWLINE$And we will follow.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Go to my brother Cassius. Order him to advance his forces first thing, and we’ll follow.

paragraphs.original: VARRUS, CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$It shall be done, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: VARRUS, CLAUDIO$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits in different directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS and ANTONY enter with their army.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd.$NEWLINE$You said the enemy would not come down$NEWLINE$But keep the hills and upper regions.$NEWLINE$It proves not so. Their battles are at hand.$NEWLINE$They mean to warn us at Philippi here,$NEWLINE$Answering before we do demand of them.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Now, Antony, our prayers have been answered. You said the enemy wouldn’t come down but keep to the hills and upper regions. It seems not. Their forces are nearby. They intend to challenge us here at Philippi, responding to our challenge before we’ve even challenged him.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know$NEWLINE$Wherefore they do it. They could be content$NEWLINE$To visit other places, and come down$NEWLINE$With fearful bravery, thinking by this face$NEWLINE$To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage.$NEWLINE$But ’tis not so.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I know how they think, and I understand why they’re doing this. They really wish they were somewhere else, but they want to descend on us, looking fierce so we’ll think they’re brave. But they aren’t.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Prepare you, generals.$NEWLINE$The enemy comes on in gallant show.$NEWLINE$Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,$NEWLINE$And something to be done immediately.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Prepare yourselves, generals. The enemy approaches with great display. They show their bloody heralds of battle, and something must be done immediately.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Octavius, lead your battle softly on,$NEWLINE$Upon the left hand of the even field.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Octavius, lead your forces slowly out to the left side of the level field.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Upon the right hand I. Keep thou the left.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll go to the right side. You stay on the left.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Why do you cross me in this exigent?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Why are you defying me in this urgent matter?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$I do not cross you. But I will do so.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$I’m not defying you, but it’s what I’m going to do.

paragraphs.original: March. Drum. Enter BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and their army, including LUCILLIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA
paragraphs.translated: The sound of soldiers marching, and a drum. BRUTUS and CASSIUS enter with their army, which includes LUCILLIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$They stand and would have parley.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$They’ve stopped. They want to talk.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Stand fast, Titinius. We must out and talk.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Stay here, Titinius. We have to go out and talk to them.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony, should we give the signal to attack?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.$NEWLINE$Make forth. The generals would have some words.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, Octavius Caesar, we’ll respond to their charge. Go forward. The generals want to speak with us.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$(to his army) Stir not until the signal.$NEWLINE$(to his army)
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$(to his army) Don’t move until we give the signal.$NEWLINE$(to his army)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Words before blows. Is it so, countrymen?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Words before fighting. Is that how it is, countrymen?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Not that we love words better, as you do.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Not that we love words more than fighting, like you do.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.$NEWLINE$Witness the hole you made in Caesar’s heart,$NEWLINE$Crying “Long live, hail, Caesar!”
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Brutus, you give a nice speech along with your evil strokes. Think of the hole you made in Caesar’s heart when you cried, “Long live Caesar! Hail Caesar!”

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Antony,$NEWLINE$The posture of your blows are yet unknown.$NEWLINE$But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees$NEWLINE$And leave them honeyless.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Antony, we don’t yet know what kind of blows you can inflict. But your words are as sweet as honey—you’ve stolen from the bees and left them with nothing.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Not stingless too?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I took their stings too, wouldn’t you say?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh, yes, and soundless too.$NEWLINE$For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony,$NEWLINE$And very wisely threat before you sting.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh, yes, and you’ve left them silent too, because you stole their buzzing, Antony. You very wisely warn us before you sting.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers$NEWLINE$Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar.$NEWLINE$You showed your teeth like apes, and fawned like hounds,$NEWLINE$And bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet,$NEWLINE$Whilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind$NEWLINE$Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Villains, you didn’t do even that much when your vile daggers struck each other as they hacked up Caesar’s sides. You smiled like apes and fawned like dogs and bowed like servants, kissing Caesar’s feet. And all the while, damned Casca, like a dog, struck Caesar on the neck from behind. Oh, you flatterers!

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself.$NEWLINE$This tongue had not offended so today$NEWLINE$If Cassius might have ruled.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Flatterers! Now, Brutus, you have only yourself to thank. Antony wouldn’t be here to offend us today if you’d listened to me earlier.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Come, come, the cause. If arguing make us sweat,$NEWLINE$The proof of it will turn to redder drops.$NEWLINE$(draws his sword) Look, I draw a sword against conspirators.$NEWLINE$(draws his sword)$NEWLINE$When think you that the sword goes up again?$NEWLINE$Never, till Caesar’s three and thirty wounds$NEWLINE$Be well avenged, or till another Caesar$NEWLINE$Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Come, come, let’s remember why we’re here. If arguing makes us sweat, the real trial will turn that water to blood. (he draws his sword) Look: I draw my sword against conspirators. When do you think I’ll put it away? Never, until Caesar’s thirty-three wounds are well avenged, or until I too have been killed by you.$NEWLINE$(he draws his sword)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands$NEWLINE$Unless thou bring’st them with thee.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Caesar, you’re not going to be killed by a traitor—unless you kill yourself..

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$So I hope.$NEWLINE$I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$I hope you’re right. I wasn’t born to die on your sword.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,$NEWLINE$Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$If you were the noblest of your family, young man, you couldn’t die more honorably.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honor,$NEWLINE$Joined with a masker and a reveler!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$An annoying schoolboy, unworthy of such an honor, joined by a masquerader and a partier!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Old Cassius still.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Still the same old Cassius!

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Come, Antony, away.—$NEWLINE$Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth.$NEWLINE$If you dare fight today, come to the field.$NEWLINE$If not, when you have stomachs.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Come Antony, let’s go. Traitors, we defy you. If you dare to fight today, come to the field. If not, come when you have the courage.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army exit.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Why, now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!$NEWLINE$The storm is up and all is on the hazard.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Now let the wind blow, waves swell, and ships sink! The storm has begun and everything is at stake.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Ho, Lucillius, hark, a word with you.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Lucillius! I’d like a word with you.

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$(stands forth)$NEWLINE$(stands forth)$NEWLINE$My lord?
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$(coming forward) My lord?$NEWLINE$(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS and LUCILLIUS converse apart$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS and LUCILLIUS converse to the side.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Messala!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Messala!

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$(stands forth)$NEWLINE$(stands forth)$NEWLINE$What says my general?
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$(coming forward) What is it, my general?$NEWLINE$(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Messala,$NEWLINE$This is my birthday, as this very day$NEWLINE$Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala.$NEWLINE$Be thou my witness that against my will,$NEWLINE$As Pompey was, am I compelled to set$NEWLINE$Upon one battle all our liberties.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Messala, today is my birthday—I was born on this very day. Give me your hand, Messala.$NEWLINE$You’ll be my witness that I’ve been forced, as Pompey was, to wager all of our freedoms on one battle.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: You know that I held Epicurus strong$NEWLINE$And his opinion. Now I change my mind,$NEWLINE$And partly credit things that do presage.$NEWLINE$Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign$NEWLINE$Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched,$NEWLINE$Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands,$NEWLINE$Who to Philippi here consorted us.$NEWLINE$This morning are they fled away and gone,$NEWLINE$And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites$NEWLINE$Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us$NEWLINE$As we were sickly prey. Their shadows seem$NEWLINE$A canopy most fatal, under which$NEWLINE$Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.
paragraphs.translated: You know that I used to believe in Epicurus and his disregard for omens. I’ve changed my mind now and partly believe in omens. Traveling from Sardis, two mighty eagles fell on our front flag and perched there, eating from the hands of the soldiers who’d accompanied us to Philippi. This morning, they’ve flown away and in their place are ravens, crows, and kites, flying over our heads and looking down on us, as though we were sickly prey. Their shadows are like a deadly canopy, under which our army lies, ready to die.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Believe not so.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Don’t believe in this.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I but believe it partly,$NEWLINE$For I am fresh of spirit and resolved$NEWLINE$To meet all perils very constantly.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$I only partly believe it, for I’m enthusiastic and resolved to meet all dangers without wavering.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(returning with LUCILLIUS) Even so, Lucillius.$NEWLINE$(returning with$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$(returning with LUCILLIUS) —Right, Lucillius.$NEWLINE$(returning with$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Now, most noble Brutus,$NEWLINE$The gods today stand friendly that we may,$NEWLINE$Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.$NEWLINE$But since the affairs of men rest still incertain,$NEWLINE$Let’s reason with the worst that may befall.$NEWLINE$If we do lose this battle, then is this$NEWLINE$The very last time we shall speak together.$NEWLINE$What are you then determinèd to do?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Now, most noble Brutus, the gods are friendly with us today so that we, who want peace, can live on to old age! But since the affairs of men are always uncertain, let’s think about the worst that may happen. If we lose this battle, this is the last time we’ll speak to each other. If we lose, what do you plan to do?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Even by the rule of that philosophy$NEWLINE$By which I did blame Cato for the death$NEWLINE$Which he did give himself (I know not how,$NEWLINE$But I do find it cowardly and vile,$NEWLINE$For fear of what might fall, so to prevent$NEWLINE$The time of life), arming myself with patience$NEWLINE$To stay the providence of some high powers$NEWLINE$That govern us below.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$By the same principle that made me condemn Cato for committing suicide, I plan to be patient and submit to what the gods decide. I don’t know why, but I find it cowardly and vile to kill oneself early to prevent possible suffering later on.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Then if we lose this battle$NEWLINE$You are contented to be led in triumph$NEWLINE$Thorough the streets of Rome?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Then if we lose this battle, you’ll be willing to be led in chains through the streets of Rome?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman,$NEWLINE$That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome.$NEWLINE$He bears too great a mind. But this same day$NEWLINE$Must end that work the ides of March begun.$NEWLINE$And whether we shall meet again I know not.$NEWLINE$Therefore our everlasting farewell take.$NEWLINE$Forever and forever farewell, Cassius.$NEWLINE$If we do meet again, why, we shall smile.$NEWLINE$If not, why then this parting was well made.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, Cassius, no. Don’t imagine that I’ll ever allow myself to return to Rome in chains. My mind is too great for that. But today, the work that March 15th began must end, and I don’t know if we’ll meet again. Therefore, accept my everlasting farewell. Forever and forever, farewell, Cassius! If we meet again, then we’ll smile. If not, then this parting was well done.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Forever and forever farewell, Brutus.$NEWLINE$If we do meet again, we’ll smile indeed.$NEWLINE$If not, ’tis true this parting was well made.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Forever and forever, farewell, Brutus! If we meet again, then we’ll smile indeed. If not, it’s true, this parting was well done.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why then, lead on. Oh, that a man might know$NEWLINE$The end of this day’s business ere it come!$NEWLINE$But it sufficeth that the day will end,$NEWLINE$And then the end is known.—Come, ho! Away!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Well, lead on. Oh, I wish I could know what will happen today before it happens! But it’s enough to know that the day will end, and then the end will be known. Come! Let’s go!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter BRUTUS and MESSALA$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. BRUTUS and MESSALA enter.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills$NEWLINE$Unto the legions on the other side.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these dispatches to our forces on the other side.

paragraphs.original: Low alarum
paragraphs.translated: Faint sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original: Let them set on at once, for I perceive$NEWLINE$But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing,$NEWLINE$And sudden push gives them the overthrow.$NEWLINE$Ride, ride, Messala. Let them all come down.
paragraphs.translated: They should advance immediately, because I sense Octavius’s side is a bit fainthearted right now, and a sudden push would overthrow him. Ride, ride, Messala. Let Cassius’s wing mount a surprise attack.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarums Enter CASSIUS and TITINIUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. CASSIUS and TITINIUS enter.$NEWLINE$CASSIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly!$NEWLINE$Myself have to mine own turned enemy.$NEWLINE$This ensign here of mine was turning back.$NEWLINE$I slew the coward and did take it from him.$NEWLINE$(indicates his standard)$NEWLINE$(indicates his standard)
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Oh, look, Titinius, look! Those villains, our soldiers, flee! I’ve become an enemy to my own soldiers! This standard-bearer here of mine was running away, so I killed him and took the flag from him. (points to his flag)$NEWLINE$(points to his flag)

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early,$NEWLINE$Who, having some advantage on Octavius,$NEWLINE$Took it too eagerly. His soldiers fell to spoil,$NEWLINE$Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Cassius, Brutus gave the orders too soon. Having an advantage over Octavius, he took it too eagerly, and his soldiers began looting, and now we’re surrounded by Antony’s men.

paragraphs.original: Enter PINDARUS$NEWLINE$PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS enters.$NEWLINE$PINDARUS

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$Fly further off, my lord, fly further off.$NEWLINE$Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.$NEWLINE$Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$Retreat further, my lord, retreat further. Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord. Therefore you must run, noble Cassius.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$This hill is far enough.—Look, look, Titinius.$NEWLINE$Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius. Are those my tents on fire?

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$They are, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$They are, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Titinius, if thou lovest me,$NEWLINE$Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him$NEWLINE$Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops$NEWLINE$And here again, that I may rest assured$NEWLINE$Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Titinius, if you love me, get on your horse and spur him on until he’s brought you to those troops and back again, so that I can find out whether those troops are friends or enemies.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$I will be here again, even with a thought.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll be back quicker than you can think a thought.

paragraphs.original: Exit TITINIUS$NEWLINE$TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill.$NEWLINE$My sight was ever thick. Regard Titinius,$NEWLINE$And tell me what thou notest about the field.
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Go, Pindarus, climb a little higher on this hill. My eyesight has always been bad. Watch Titinius and tell me what you see in the field.

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS ascends the hill$NEWLINE$PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS ascends the hill.$NEWLINE$PINDARUS

paragraphs.original: This day I breathed first. Time is come round,$NEWLINE$And where I did begin, there shall I end.$NEWLINE$My life is run his compass.$NEWLINE$(to PINDARUS)    Sirrah, what news?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: Today was the day I breathed my first breath. Time has come round, and I’ll end where I began. My life has run its circle. (to PINDARUS) What can you see, boy?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$(above) O my lord!$NEWLINE$(above)
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$(above) Oh, my lord!$NEWLINE$(above)

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What news?
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$What news?

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$(above) Titinius is enclosèd round about$NEWLINE$(above)$NEWLINE$With horsemen, that make to him on the spur.$NEWLINE$Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him.$NEWLINE$Now, Titinius. Now some light. Oh, he lights too.$NEWLINE$He’s ta'en.
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$(above) Titinius is surrounded by horsemen who are quickly approaching him, yet he spurs onward. Now they’re almost on him. Now, Titinius! Now some dismount. Oh, he gets down too. He’s taken.$NEWLINE$(above)

paragraphs.original: Shout within
paragraphs.translated: A shout offstage.

paragraphs.original: And, hark! They shout for joy.
paragraphs.translated: And listen! They shout for joy.

paragraphs.original: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Come down, behold no more.$NEWLINE$Oh, coward that I am, to live so long$NEWLINE$To see my best friend ta'en before my face!
paragraphs.translated: CASSIUS$NEWLINE$Come down, look no more. Oh, I’m such a coward for living long enough to see my best friend taken before my eyes!

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS returns$NEWLINE$PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS returns.$NEWLINE$PINDARUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Come hither, sirrah.$NEWLINE$In Parthia did I take thee prisoner.$NEWLINE$And then I swore thee, saving of thy life,$NEWLINE$That whatsoever I did bid thee do,$NEWLINE$Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath.$NEWLINE$(gives his sword to PINDARUS)$NEWLINE$(gives his sword to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Now be a free man, and with this good sword$NEWLINE$That ran through Caesar’s bowels, search this bosom.$NEWLINE$Stand not to answer. Here take thou the hilts$NEWLINE$And, when my face is covered, as ’tis now,$NEWLINE$Guide thou the sword.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, boy. I took you prisoner in Parthia, and at that time I made you swear to try to do whatever I ordered you to, except take your own life. Come now, keep your oath. (gives his sword to PINDARUS) Now you’ll be a free man. Take this good sword, which ran through Caesar’s bowels, and plunge it in my chest. Don’t hesitate. Here, take the handle, and when my face is covered as it is now, use the sword.$NEWLINE$(gives his sword to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS stabs CASSIUS$NEWLINE$PINDARUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS stabs CASSIUS.$NEWLINE$PINDARUS$NEWLINE$CASSIUS

paragraphs.original: Caesar, thou art revenged,$NEWLINE$Even with the sword that killed thee.$NEWLINE$(dies)$NEWLINE$(dies)
paragraphs.translated: Caesar, you are revenged with the very same sword that killed you. (he dies)$NEWLINE$(he dies)

paragraphs.original: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$So I am free. Yet would not so have been,$NEWLINE$Durst I have done my will. O Cassius,$NEWLINE$Far from this country Pindarus shall run,$NEWLINE$Where never Roman shall take note of him.
paragraphs.translated: PINDARUS$NEWLINE$So I’m free. But I didn’t want to be free like this. Oh, Cassius, I’ll run far from this country to where no Romans can find me.

paragraphs.original: Exit PINDARUS$NEWLINE$PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter TITINIUS and MESSALA$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS and MESSALA enter.$NEWLINE$TITINIUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius$NEWLINE$Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power,$NEWLINE$As Cassius' legions are by Antony.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$The armies have merely changed places, Titinius, because Octavius has been overthrown by noble Brutus’s forces at the very moment that Antony overthrew Cassius’s legions.

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$These tidings will well comfort Cassius.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$This news will comfort Cassius.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Where did you leave him?
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Where did you leave him?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$All disconsolate,$NEWLINE$With Pindarus his bondman on this hill.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$On this hill and in despair, with his slave Pindarus.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Is not that he that lies upon the ground?
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Isn’t that him on the ground?

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$He lies not like the living. O my heart!
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$He doesn’t seem to be alive. Oh, my heart!

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Is not that he?
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Isn’t that him?

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$No, this was he, Messala,$NEWLINE$But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,$NEWLINE$As in thy red rays thou dost sink tonight,$NEWLINE$So in his red blood Cassius' day is set.$NEWLINE$The sun of Rome is set. Our day is gone.$NEWLINE$Clouds, dews, and dangers come! Our deeds are done.$NEWLINE$Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$No, it was him, Messala, but Cassius is no more. Just as the sun’s rays turn red when it sets, so Cassius has ended his life in a pool of red blood. The sun of Rome has set! Our day is over. Clouds, dew, and dangers approach. We’re finished! He didn’t believe I would ever return on my mission, and so he killed himself.$NEWLINE$was

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.$NEWLINE$O hateful error, melancholy’s child,$NEWLINE$Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men$NEWLINE$The things that are not? O error, soon conceived,$NEWLINE$Thou never comest unto a happy birth$NEWLINE$But kill’st the mother that engendered thee!
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Yes, he killed himself because he thought we’d lost the whole battle. Sadness, which misconstrues reality, gave birth to his errors in thinking—and then destroyed him.

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$What, Pindarus! Where art thou, Pindarus?
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$Pindarus! Where are you, Pindarus?

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet$NEWLINE$The noble Brutus, thrusting this report$NEWLINE$Into his ears. I may say “thrusting” it,$NEWLINE$For piercing steel and darts envenomèd$NEWLINE$Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus$NEWLINE$As tidings of this sight.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Look for him, Titinius, while I go to meet the noble Brutus and force him to hear this news. I say “force” because Brutus would rather I stuck sharp blades and poisoned arrows in his ears than fill them with this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$Hie you, Messala,$NEWLINE$And I will seek for Pindarus the while.
paragraphs.translated: TITINIUS$NEWLINE$Hurry, Messala, and I’ll look for Pindarus in the meantime.

paragraphs.original: Exit MESSALA$NEWLINE$MESSALA
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA exits.$NEWLINE$MESSALA

paragraphs.original: Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?$NEWLINE$Did I not meet thy friends? And did not they$NEWLINE$Put on my brows this wreath of victory$NEWLINE$And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts?$NEWLINE$Alas, thou hast misconstrued everything!$NEWLINE$But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow.$NEWLINE$Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I$NEWLINE$Will do his bidding.$NEWLINE$(lays wreath on CASSIUS’s head) Brutus, come apace,$NEWLINE$(lays wreath on$NEWLINE$’s head)$NEWLINE$And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.$NEWLINE$—By your leave, gods, this is a Roman’s part.$NEWLINE$Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.$NEWLINE$(stabs himself with CASSIUS’s sword and dies)$NEWLINE$(stabs himself with$NEWLINE$’s sword and dies)
paragraphs.translated: Why did you send me out, brave Cassius? Didn’t I meet up with your allies? And didn’t they place the wreath of victory on my brow and order me to give it to you? Didn’t you hear their shouts? Alas, you misunderstood everything! But let me place this wreath on your head. Your Brutus ordered me to give it to you, and I’ll do what he says. (he lays a wreath on CASSIUS’s head) Brutus, come this way and see how much I admired Caius Cassius. With your permission, gods, this is a Roman’s duty. Come, Cassius’s sword, and strike Titinius’s heart. (he stabs himself with CASSIUS’s sword and dies.)$NEWLINE$(he lays a wreath on$NEWLINE$’s head)$NEWLINE$(he stabs himself with$NEWLINE$’s sword and dies.)

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter BRUTUS, MESSALA, young CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, LUCILLIUS, LABIO, and FLAVIO$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$CATO$NEWLINE$STRATO$NEWLINE$VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$LABIO$NEWLINE$FLAVIO
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. BRUTUS, MESSALA, young CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, LUCILLIUS, LABIO, and FLAVIO enter.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$CATO$NEWLINE$STRATO$NEWLINE$VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$LABIO$NEWLINE$FLAVIO

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Where is his body, Messala?

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Over there, where Titinius mourns it.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Titinius' face is upward.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Titinius is lying face-up.

paragraphs.original: CATO$NEWLINE$He is slain.
paragraphs.translated: CATO$NEWLINE$He’s been killed.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!$NEWLINE$Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords$NEWLINE$In our own proper entrails.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Julius Caesar, you are still powerful. Your ghost walks the earth and turns our swords toward our own stomachs.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Low alarums
paragraphs.translated: Faint sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original: CATO$NEWLINE$Brave Titinius!—$NEWLINE$Look whe 'er he have not crowned dead Cassius.
paragraphs.translated: CATO$NEWLINE$Brave Titinius! Look, he even put the crown on dead Cassius!

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Are yet two Romans living such as these?$NEWLINE$—The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!$NEWLINE$It is impossible that ever Rome$NEWLINE$Should breed thy fellow.—Friends, I owe more tears$NEWLINE$To this dead man than you shall see me pay.$NEWLINE$—I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.$NEWLINE$—Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body.$NEWLINE$His funerals shall not be in our camp,$NEWLINE$Lest it discomfort us.—Lucillius, come.—$NEWLINE$And come, young Cato. Let us to the field.$NEWLINE$—Labio and Flavio, set our battles on.$NEWLINE$—'Tis three o'clock, and, Romans, yet ere night$NEWLINE$We shall try fortune in a second fight.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Could you have found two Romans as good as these two? Good-bye to you, the last of all the Romans. Rome will never produce your equal. Friends, I owe more tears to this dead man than you will see me shed. I will find the time to cry for you, Cassius, I’ll find the time. Come, then, and send his body to Thasos. We won’t have his funeral at our camp, because it might make us too sad to fight. Lucillius, come. And come, young Cato. Let’s proceed to the field. Labio and Flavio, push our armies onward. It is three o'clock, and, Romans, before night, we will try our luck in a second battle.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter BRUTUS, MESSALA, CATO, LUCILLIUS, and FLAVIO$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$CATO$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$FLAVIO
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. BRUTUS,MESSALA, CATO, LUCILLIUS, and FLAVIO enter.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$CATO$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$FLAVIO

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Keep on, countrymen. Oh, keep your heads up, even now!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BRUTUS, MESSALA, and FLAVIO$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$FLAVIO
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS, MESSALA, and FLAVIO exit.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$FLAVIO

paragraphs.original: CATO$NEWLINE$What bastard doth not? Who will go with me?$NEWLINE$I will proclaim my name about the field.$NEWLINE$I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!$NEWLINE$A foe to tyrants, and my country’s friend.$NEWLINE$I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
paragraphs.translated: CATO$NEWLINE$Who is so low that he wouldn’t? Who will advance with me? I will proclaim my name around the field. I am the son of Marcus Cato! An enemy to tyrants and a friend to my country. I am the son of Marcus Cato!

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and OCTAVIUS' SOLDIERS Fight$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and OCTAVIUS' SOLDIERS enter and fight.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I!$NEWLINE$Brutus, my country’s friend. Know me for Brutus!
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus. Brutus, my country’s friend. Know that I am Brutus!

paragraphs.original: SOLDIERS kill young CATO$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$CATO
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIERS kill young CATO.$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$CATO

paragraphs.original: O young and noble Cato, art thou down?$NEWLINE$Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius,$NEWLINE$And mayst be honored, being Cato’s son.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, young and noble Cato, have you been slain? Why, you die now as bravely as Titinius. And you, being Cato’s son, will be honored.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(to LUCILLIUS) Yield, or thou diest.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(to LUCILLIUS ) Surrender or you will die.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$Only I yield to die.$NEWLINE$There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight.$NEWLINE$Kill Brutus, and be honored in his death.
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$I’d rather die. Here is some money for you to kill me immediately. Kill Brutus and be honored by the killing.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$We must not. A noble prisoner!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$We must not. He is a noble prisoner!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Room, ho! Tell Antony Brutus is ta'en.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Make room! Tell Antony that Brutus has been taken.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$I’ll tell the news. Here comes the general.$NEWLINE$—Brutus is ta'en, Brutus is ta'en, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$I’ll tell him the news. Oh, here comes the general—Brutus has been caught, Brutus is taken, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where is he?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where is he?

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$Safe, Antony. Brutus is safe enough.$NEWLINE$I dare assure thee that no enemy$NEWLINE$Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus.$NEWLINE$The gods defend him from so great a shame!$NEWLINE$When you do find him, or alive or dead,$NEWLINE$He will be found like Brutus, like himself.
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$He’s safe, Antony. I can assure you that no enemy will ever take the noble Brutus alive. The gods protect him from so great a shame! When you do find him, alive or dead, he’ll be found on his own terms.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to SOLDIERS) This is not Brutus, friend, but, I assure you,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$A prize no less in worth. Keep this man safe.$NEWLINE$Give him all kindness. I had rather have$NEWLINE$Such men my friends than enemies. Go on,$NEWLINE$And see whether Brutus be alive or dead.$NEWLINE$And bring us word unto Octavius' tent$NEWLINE$How everything is chanced.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to SOLDIERS) This isn’t Brutus, friend, but, I assure you, he is a valuable prize. Keep this man safe. Be kind to him. I would rather have such men as friends than enemies. Move on, find out if Brutus is alive or dead, then return to Octavius’s tent to tell us what you’ve learned.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$CLITUS$NEWLINE$STRATO$NEWLINE$VOLUMNIUS
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS enter.$NEWLINE$BRUTUS$NEWLINE$DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$CLITUS$NEWLINE$STRATO$NEWLINE$VOLUMNIUS

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Come, last of my friends, rest on this rock.

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Statilius showed the torchlight but, my lord,$NEWLINE$He came not back. He is or ta'en or slain.
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Statilius waved the torchlight at us, but he hasn’t come back. He’s been captured or killed.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Sit thee down, Clitus. Slaying is the word.$NEWLINE$It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus.$NEWLINE$(whispers to CLITUS)$NEWLINE$(whispers to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Sit down, Clitus. Killed, most likely—it’s become a trend. Listen, Clitus. (he whispers to CLITUS)$NEWLINE$(he whispers to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Who, me, my lord? No, not for all the world.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Peace then! No words.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Silence, then! Don’t give it away.

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$I’ll rather kill myself.
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$I’d rather kill myself.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Hark thee, Dardanius.$NEWLINE$(whispers to DARDANIUS)$NEWLINE$(whispers to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Listen, Dardanius. (he whispers to DARDANIUS)$NEWLINE$(he whispers to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$Shall I do such a deed?
paragraphs.translated: DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$Would I dare do something like that?

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$O Dardanius!
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Oh Dardanius!

paragraphs.original: DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$O Clitus!
paragraphs.translated: DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$Oh Clitus!

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$(aside to DARDANIUS)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$What ill request did Brutus make to thee?
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only DARDANIUS can hear) What awful thing did Brutus ask of you?$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$(aside to CLITUS)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.
paragraphs.translated: DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only CLITUS can hear) To kill him, Clitus. Look, he’s meditating on what to do.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$(aside to DARDANIUS) Now is that noble vessel full of grief,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That it runs over even at his eyes.
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only DARDANIUS can hear) That noble man is so full of grief that it spills out of his eyes.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Come hither, good Volumnius. List a word.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Come here, good Volumnius. Listen a minute.

paragraphs.original: VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$What says my lord?
paragraphs.translated: VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$What is it, my lord?

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Why this, Volumnius:$NEWLINE$The ghost of Caesar hath appeared to me$NEWLINE$Two several times by night. At Sardis once,$NEWLINE$And this last night here in Philippi fields.$NEWLINE$I know my hour is come.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Just this, Volumnius. The ghost of Caesar has appeared to me at night twice. Once at Sardis and once last night, here in Philippi fields. I know that my hour has come.

paragraphs.original: VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$Not so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$No, it hasn’t, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.$NEWLINE$Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes.$NEWLINE$Our enemies have beat us to the pit.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$No, I’m sure it has, Volumnius. You see how the world goes, Volumnius. Our enemies have driven us to the edge of the grave.

paragraphs.original: Low alarums
paragraphs.translated: Faint sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original: It is more worthy to leap in ourselves$NEWLINE$Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius,$NEWLINE$Thou know’st that we two went to school together.$NEWLINE$Even for that our love of old, I prithee,$NEWLINE$Hold thou my sword hilts, whilst I run on it.
paragraphs.translated: It’s nobler to leap in ourselves than dawdle until they push us. Good Volumnius, you know that we went to school together. For the sake of our old friendship, I ask you, hold my sword handle while I run on it.

paragraphs.original: VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$That’s not an office for a friend, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$That’s not a job for a friend, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Alarum still
paragraphs.translated: Continued sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Fly, fly, my lord. There is no tarrying here.
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Run, run, my lord. We can’t wait here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Farewell to you.—And you.—And you, Volumnius.$NEWLINE$—Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep.$NEWLINE$Farewell to thee too, Strato.—Countrymen,$NEWLINE$My heart doth joy that yet in all my life$NEWLINE$I found no man but he was true to me.$NEWLINE$I shall have glory by this losing day$NEWLINE$More than Octavius and Mark Antony$NEWLINE$By this vile conquest shall attain unto.$NEWLINE$So fare you well at once, for Brutus' tongue$NEWLINE$Hath almost ended his life’s history.$NEWLINE$Night hangs upon mine eyes. My bones would rest,$NEWLINE$That have but labored to attain this hour.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Farewell to you, and you, and you, Volumnius. Strato, you’ve slept this whole time. Farewell to you too, Strato. Countrymen, my heart rejoices that in all my life I knew no men who were untrue to me. I’ll have glory in this losing day—more than Octavius and Mark Antony will gain by their foul conquest. So farewell, all, for my tongue has almost finished with its life. I can’t see ahead of me. My bones want to rest after helping me up to this hour.

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Cry within “Fly, fly, fly!”
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. Offstage, someone cries, “Run, run, run!”

paragraphs.original: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Fly, my lord, fly.
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS$NEWLINE$Run, my lord, run.

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Hence. I will follow.
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Go on! I’ll follow.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CLITUS, DARDANIUS, and VOLUMNIUS$NEWLINE$CLITUS$NEWLINE$DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$VOLUMNIUS
paragraphs.translated: CLITUS, DARDANIUS, and VOLUMNIUS exit.$NEWLINE$CLITUS$NEWLINE$DARDANIUS$NEWLINE$VOLUMNIUS

paragraphs.original: I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord.$NEWLINE$Thou art a fellow of a good respect.$NEWLINE$Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it.$NEWLINE$Hold then my sword and turn away thy face$NEWLINE$While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?
paragraphs.translated: I beg you, Strato, stay by me. You’re a man with a good reputation. Your life has had honor in it. Then, hold my sword and turn your face away while I run on it. Will you, Strato?

paragraphs.original: STRATO$NEWLINE$Give me your hand first.$NEWLINE$(holds BRUTUS' sword) Fare you well, my lord.$NEWLINE$(holds$NEWLINE$sword)
paragraphs.translated: STRATO$NEWLINE$Give me your hand, first. (holds BRUTUS' sword) Farewell, my lord.$NEWLINE$(holds$NEWLINE$' sword)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Farewell, good Strato.$NEWLINE$(runs on his sword)    Caesar, now be still.$NEWLINE$(runs on his sword)$NEWLINE$I killed not thee with half so good a will.$NEWLINE$(dies)$NEWLINE$(dies)
paragraphs.translated: BRUTUS$NEWLINE$Farewell, good Strato. (runs on his sword) Caesar, you can rest now. I didn’t kill you half as willingly. (he dies)$NEWLINE$(runs on his sword)$NEWLINE$(he dies)

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Retreat. Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, LUCILLIUS, and the army$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. Trumpets sound a retreat. OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, and LUCILLIUS enter with the army.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$MESSALA$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$What man is that?
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$What man is that?

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$My master’s man.—Strato, where is thy master?
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$My master’s man. Strato, where’s your master?

paragraphs.original: STRATO$NEWLINE$Free from the bondage you are in, Messala.$NEWLINE$The conquerors can but make a fire of him.$NEWLINE$For Brutus only overcame himself,$NEWLINE$And no man else hath honor by his death.
paragraphs.translated: STRATO$NEWLINE$Free from the bondage you are in, Messala. The conquerors can only make a fire of him, because only Brutus triumphed over himself, and no other man gets to triumph in his death.

paragraphs.original: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$So Brutus should be found.—I thank thee, Brutus,$NEWLINE$That thou hast proved Lucillius' saying true.
paragraphs.translated: LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$It’s fitting that Brutus be found like this. Thank you, Brutus, for proving my prediction true.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.$NEWLINE$—Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll take all who served Brutus into my service. You, will you join with me?

paragraphs.original: STRATO$NEWLINE$Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.
paragraphs.translated: STRATO$NEWLINE$Yes, if Messala recommends me to you.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Do so, good Messala.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Do so, good Messala.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$How died my master, Strato?
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$How did my master die, Strato?

paragraphs.original: STRATO$NEWLINE$I held the sword and he did run on it.
paragraphs.translated: STRATO$NEWLINE$I held the sword and he ran on it.

paragraphs.original: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Octavius, then take him to follow thee,$NEWLINE$That did the latest service to my master.
paragraphs.translated: MESSALA$NEWLINE$Then take this man into your service, Octavius, for he did the final service to my master.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$This was the noblest Roman of them all.$NEWLINE$All the conspirators save only he$NEWLINE$Did that they did in envy of great Caesar.$NEWLINE$He only in a general honest thought$NEWLINE$And common good to all, made one of them.$NEWLINE$His life was gentle, and the elements$NEWLINE$So mixed in him that Nature might stand up$NEWLINE$And say to all the world, “This was a man.”
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$This was the noblest Roman of them all. All the rest of the conspirators acted out of jealousy of great Caesar. Only he acted from honesty and for the general good. His life was gentle, and the elements mixed so well in him that Nature might stand up and say to all the world, “This was a man.”

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$According to his virtue let us use him,$NEWLINE$With all respect and rites of burial.$NEWLINE$Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie$NEWLINE$Most like a soldier, ordered honorably.$NEWLINE$So call the field to rest, and let’s away$NEWLINE$To part the glories of this happy day.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$Let’s treat him according to his virtue, with all the respect and rituals of burial. His body will lie in my tent tonight, with the honorable observance that suits a soldier. So order the armies to rest, and let’s go home to share the glories of this happy day.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt omnes
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits.
